item.title: New Device To Be Trialed In Spinal Cord Spasticity [dis:Spasticity, dis:Dystonia]
item.description: New Device To Be Trialed In Spinal Cord Spasticity [dis:Spasticity, dis:Dystonia]
item.content:encoded:
New Device To Be Trialed In Spinal Cord Spasticity [:Neurology:dis:Dystonia, :Neurology:dis:Spasticity]
Neurology7667 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 31 July 2014 | 18:33

Comment: ClinicalTrials.gov is listing a new study which will evaluate extracorporeal shock wave therapy (Storz Medical's Duolith® SD 1 "T-Top" device for the treatment of focal spasticity in patients with spinal cord injury.
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of a one-time ESWT on lower limb spasticity in patients with an incomplete spinal cord injury.
The primary outcome measure for this interventional study will be severity of spasticity (0-2hr) as measured on the Ashworth scale. Secondary measures will be personal goal attainments at day 0,1,3 and 5) and walking sitance and speed (pre and post intervention. Several other scales will be deployed to measure the severity of spasticity.
Enrolment Nos, Timelines & Study Location
20 patients will be enrolled with the study scheduled to start this month and complete in May 2016. The study is to be undertaken by the Swiss Paraplegic Centre in Notwil.
Reference is also made to recent studies which have reported positive effects of extracorporeal shock wave therapy on spasticity in patients with stroke, focal limb dystonia and cerebral palsy. We will look to identify these papers.

ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier:

 NCT02203994

Boehringer Ingelheim Has Planned A Ph1 Trial to Evaluate Combination of Anti-IGF With Enzalutamide For mCRPC Patients (Post-Docetaxel Setting)
Oncology9852 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 31 July 2014 | 18:11

Comment: Boehringer Ingelheim has planned a Ph1 trial to investigate their experimental drug BI-836845, an insulin growth factor inhibitor, in combination with enzalutamide for the treatment of mCRPC patients who progress beyond docetaxel and abiraterone. A Phase 1b expansion cohort will proceed once the maximum tolerated dose has been determined. This will the follow by the randomised ph2 trial with parallel group study design in a 1:1 ratio to compare BI836845+ Enzalutamide vs Enzalutamide monotherapy.

item.title: Acorda Q2 - Key Takeaways - Stroke Trial Now Planned To Start By Year-End
item.description: Acorda Q2 - Key Takeaways - Stroke Trial Now Planned To Start By Year-End
item.content:encoded:
Acorda Q2 - Key Takeaways - Stroke Trial Now Planned To Start By Year-End
Neurology7666 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 31 July 2014 | 18:08

Comment: Acorda's sales of AMPYRAin the second quarter were strong prompting the company to reiterate its net sales guidance for the year of $328-335m. However, the company has now received eight Paragraph IV Certification Notice Letters advising that companies have submitted ANDAs to the FDA requesting permission to manufacture and market a generic version of AMPYRA in July 2017
Status Of The Patent Challenge

The Company has filed patent infringement suits against all ANDA filers to date, triggering a 30-month statutory stay period that restricts FDA from approving an ANDA until July 2017 at the earliest, unless a district court issues a decision adverse to all of Acorda’s asserted Orange Book patents prior to that date. The 30-month stay starts from January 22, 2015, which is the end of the new chemical entity (NCE) exclusivity period. AMPYRA is currently protected by five Orange Book-listed patents, four of which extend into 2025, 2026 and 2027, respectively.

Acorda Looks Forward To A New Formulation As A Means Of Protection - Inclusion In Ph3 Stroke Study Is Planned

Meanwhile, the company expects to initiate a Phase 3 clinical trial by the end of this year studying the use of dalfampridine administered twice-daily (BID) to improve walking in people who have experienced a stroke. The start of this study is delayed compared to previous estimates but we note that the group is working with external partners to develop a new once-daily (QD) formulation that could be included in future studies.

Source: www.acorda.com

item.title: Valeant Q2 Earnings Figures - Transparency Markedly Enhanced As Allergan's Criticisms Are Addressed [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Valeant Q2 Earnings Figures - Transparency Markedly Enhanced As Allergan's Criticisms Are Addressed [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Q2 Earnings Figures - Transparency Markedly Enhanced As Allergan's Criticisms Are Addressed [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7664 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 31 July 2014 | 17:37

Comment: Valeant has reported an accelerating growth picture and revenues seemingly in line with consensus. Increased transparency is apparent and shows how diversified the business is with the group's top 20 global brands generating 31% of revenue ($1.2bn) growing 22% y/y and 124% year to date. Guidance has been lowered to reflect the sale of facial injectables to Galderma, where revenues interestingly appear to be above market consensus at $230m.
Valeant has provided 2015-16 guidance under two scenarios: debt repayment and acquisition. What is notable is that even without acquisition Valeant is expecting high-single organic growth and cash EPS of >15% and #20% in 2015 and 2016, suggesting that it is forecasting strong underlying growth in the business.
The slides below highlight some of the key points made in the presentation, and data that in certain instances effectively counters Allergan's accusations. Details of the next steps in the acquisition process are also outlined plus indications given on how the integration process may take place if Valeant is successful.

item.title: Eligard 6M Now Reimbursed In Italy [class:Antihormonals, comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy]
item.description: Eligard 6M Now Reimbursed In Italy [class:Antihormonals, comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy]
item.content:encoded:
Eligard 6M Now Reimbursed In Italy [:Oncology:class:Antihormonals, :Oncology:comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy]
Oncology9851 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 31 July 2014 | 16:17

Comment: Thanks to Michela Maraschi (Uro-Oncology Franchise Marketing), we understand that Eligard 6M is now officially reimbursed in Italy.
In the Official Journal n. 179 of 29.7.2014 the authorisation for the reimbursement of Eligard 6 months has been published.
Official prices, at the gros of the mandatory discount, are:
- PP : € 815,76
- Ex-factory: €494,28
Official prices at the net of the mandatory discounts (-5%; -5%) are
- PP : €736,22
- Ex-factory: €446,09
Astellas has agreed with HAs an additional undisclosed discount.
Official price, at the gros of the undisclosed discount, is twice the price of the 3 months formulation.

item.title: Bayer Q2 Figures-Key Takeaways [dis:Prostate]
item.description: Bayer Q2 Figures-Key Takeaways [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Bayer Q2 Figures-Key Takeaways [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9850 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 30 July 2014 | 18:53

Comment: Bayer today reported strong demand for its top five new drugs including its prostate cancer drug Xofigo (Alphardin), whilst total sales and profits were dampened by the strength of the Euro.
Pharmaceuticals generated an impressive 10% sales growth to almost EUR 3.0 billion. The growth was driven by the group's launch products, Xarelto, Eylea, Stivarga, Xofigo and Adempas, which collectively posted sales of EUR 702 million. Sales of Xarelto maintained the strong growth momentum of prior quarters. Eylea grew strongly as well, mainly in Western Europe and the group's cancer drugs, Stivarga and Xofigo (€43m), made encouraging contributions to the sales development.
The performance of the group's established Pharma products was more mixed in the quarter.
On the positive side, sales of Nexavar rose by 3% with particular contributions from the emerging markets and the U.S. Mirena recorded sales gains of 13%, mainly as a result of price increases in the U.S., and Aspirin Cardio experienced a substantial increase in demand, especially in China, resulting in overall sales growth of 9%.

On the negative side, Kogenate sales declined by 17%, mainly due to capacity constraints that were caused by utilization of existing manufacturing capacity for the development of the group's next generation hemophilia product.

Sales of Betaferon receded by 16% mainly due to increased competition in the U.S. Sales of the YAZ family contracted by 3% and sales growth in the U.S. only partly compensated for the revenue decline in Western Europe due to generic competition.

Xofigo Update

Xofigo now is approved in 38 countries and launched in 18, and in Europe that includes Germany, Austria, U.K., Ireland, France, Netherlands and a set of smaller countries. It's very early days but it is perceived to be going well. So far about 4,100 U.S. patients have received Xofigo since launch and in Europe it is getting close to 1,000 patients.

Pipeline Update
Bayer has five focus projects in its pipeline.
  • Molidustat, which is a therapy for kidney disease, has three Phase II studies ongoing and results are expected during the second half of 2014.
  • Copanlisib, a PI3K inhibitor PhII results are expected in the first half of 2015.
  • Vilaprisan a progesterone receptor antagonist targeting uterine fibroids. A PhII clinical trial is ongoing and primary study completion is expected during 2016.
  • Finerenone has two studies ongoing looking at different indications. One is in worsening chronic heart failure and the second diabetic neuropathy. Results are expected during the second half of 2014.
  • Vericiguat which is a sGC modulator which part of a partnership with Merck; is being evlauted in worsening CHF in two different populations: one with reduced injection fraction and the other with preserved injection fraction and results are exected by first part of 2015.

item.title: PhII ATL1103 Acromegaly Study Results Expected By End August [dis:Acromegaly]
item.description: PhII ATL1103 Acromegaly Study Results Expected By End August [dis:Acromegaly]
item.content:encoded:
PhII ATL1103 Acromegaly Study Results Expected By End August [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly]
Endocrinology7751 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 30 July 2014 | 18:26

Comment: Antisense Therapeutics has reported completion of enrolment in its 26 patient phII acromegaly trial with results now expected by the end of August 2014.
So far there have been no patient withdrawals or reports of any serious adverse events related to dosing with ATL1103. Patients will continue to be monitored for two months after their last dose.
Primary Study Endpoint
The primary efficacy endpoint of this trial is percentage reduction from baseline in each patients serum IGF-1 levels to their levels one week after the last dose.
Interim Results
Interim data was reported back in December 2013 from 8 patients who had completed their dosing. Their results provided indicative data of efficacy with ATL1103, with reductions in IGF-1 in line with what could be therapeutically effective in the treatment of acromegaly.
Source: www.antisense.com

Comments
The company has reported that the Ph2 trial met its primary efficacy endpoint, showing a statistically significant average reduction in the serum insulin-like growth factor levels of 26% from baseline. Management plans to conduct a small study at a higher dose than 400mg for potential use in a Ph3 trial.
Preparation for the Ph3
Preparatory work for a Ph3 trial of 6-12 months of treatment includes manufacture and formulation of drug product and further animal toxicology studies which the company plans to undertake with a future development Partner.
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Endocrinology7784 / 03 September 2014 / 17:18:31 o'clock CEST

item.title: Merck Serono's Anti-PD1 Is Being Evaluated In A Ph1 Trial Including mCRPC Patients
item.description: Merck Serono's Anti-PD1 Is Being Evaluated In A Ph1 Trial Including mCRPC Patients
item.content:encoded:
Merck Serono's Anti-PD1 Is Being Evaluated In A Ph1 Trial Including mCRPC Patients
Oncology9849 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 29 July 2014 | 18:50

Comment: Merck Serono announced the initiation of an international Ph2 study to assess the efficacy and safety of MSB0010718C (anti PDL1) in patients with metastatic Merkel Cell carcinoma (a rare and aggressive type of skin cancer). The PD-L1/PD-1 pathway is implicated as a major mechanism by which tumours evade elimination by the immune system. In addition to this new study, MSB0010718C is also being explored in a Ph1 dose escalation study and the study is currently recruiting patients into expansion cohorts in 7 cancer types including castration resistant prostate cancer, colorectal cancer, gastric/gastroeophogeal cancer, melanoma, metastatic breast cancer, non small cell lung cancer, and ovarian cancer.
The development of anti-PD1/PDL1 monoclonal antibody was the hottest topic in ASCO this year, and this is certainly reflected by the size of the audience during the presentation. Merck Serono is slightly behind the race, however, MSB-0010718C is the first anti-PD1 to be evaluated for the treatment of mCRPC patients. Currently mCRPC patients are being recruited as the secondary cohorts only. Given the previous negative results of ipilimumab (another immune oncology agent, BMS) in heavily treated mCRPC patients, the success of anti-PD1 in mCRPC will remain elusive and require further investigation. The fate of anti-PD1/PDL1 will probably become clearer once we learn more from the trial outcome of ipilimumab in chemo naïve mCRPC setting.
Anti-PD1/PDL1 Monoclonal Antibody in Clinical Development Company/Manufacture Highest Development Phase
pembrolizumab Merck & Co., Inc. (MSD) Pre-Registration
nivolumab BMS/Ono Japan Approved /ROW Pre-Registration
MEDI-4736 Medimmune/AZ III
MPDL3280A Roche II
MSB-0010718C Merck KGaA (Merck Serono) II
Pidilizumab CureTech Ltd. II
BMS-936559

BMS

 I
MEDI-0680

Medimmune/AZ

 I
Trial Details: NCT01772004 (expected enrolment = 590)
MSB0010718C (anti PD-L1) will be administered in study location using a protocol-defined dose escalation scheme until confirmed progression, unacceptable toxicity, or if any criterion for withdrawal from the trial or investigational medicinal product occurs. After determination of the dose and regimen for Expansion Phase, MSB0010718C will be administered to subjects divided into 3 primary cohorts of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), gastric/gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) cancer and metastatic breast cancer (MBC); and 4 secondary cohorts of colorectal cancer (CRC), castrate-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), melanoma, and ovarian cancer.
source: Pharma eTrack; clinicaltrial.gov

item.title: Zealand Pharma Concludes $402m Peptide Deal With Boehringer Ingelheim [dis:Diabetes, class:GLP1]
item.description: Zealand Pharma Concludes $402m Peptide Deal With Boehringer Ingelheim [dis:Diabetes, class:GLP1]
item.content:encoded:
Zealand Pharma Concludes $402m Peptide Deal With Boehringer Ingelheim [:Endocrinology:class:GLP1, :Endocrinology:dis:Diabetes]
Endocrinology7750 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 July 2014 | 18:12

Comment: Zealand Pharma has signed a second collaboration agreement with Boehringer Ingelheim to advance a novel peptide medicine for an undisclosed cardio-metabolic indication.
Deal Terms
Zealand is eligible to receive up to €295m in potential milestone payments for the first commercialised product plus research funding and roylaties.
In return Boehringer will obtain global exclusive development and commercialisation rights to products under the agreement, with Zealnd retaining co-commercialisation rights in Scandanavi.
Existing Collaboration
The first agreement, between both comapnies was signed in June 2011. The collaboration is ongoing for the development and commercialization of novel glucagon/GLP-1 dual-acting peptide therapeutics to treat patients with Type 2 diabetes and/or obesity.
Zealand has a partnering strategy for the development and commercialization of its products and in addition to its license agreement with Sanofi in Type 2 diabetes covering the marketed product Lyxumia® , the company has a collaboration with Lilly in diabetes and obesity, one with Helsinn Healthcare in chemotherapy induced diarrhea and a license agreement with AbbVie in acute kidney injury.
Source: www.zealandpharma.com

item.title: Glide Pharma In-licenes Novel Diagnostic Technology For Prostate Cancer [sub:Diagnostic, dis:Prostate]
item.description: Glide Pharma In-licenes Novel Diagnostic Technology For Prostate Cancer [sub:Diagnostic, dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Glide Pharma In-licenes Novel Diagnostic Technology For Prostate Cancer [:Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:sub:Diagnostic]
Oncology9848 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 July 2014 | 17:59

Comment: Glide has acquired an exclusive worldwide licence to an innovative prostate cancer diagnostic technology from FScan Ltd, a Durham University spin-out company, a technology that it hopes one day may replace PSA measurements.
Deal Terms
Under the terms of the agreement, Glide Pharma will pay an upfront fee, development and commercial milestone payments, and royalties on future product sales. Glide Pharma has also taken an option for additional exclusive licences to FScan diagnostic technologies, for use in other conditions.
What Does The Technology Involve?
The licensed technology pioneers the use of lanthanide complexes for the non-invasive, rapid and accurate measurement of citrate levels in seminal fluid. The link between citrate levels and prostate cancer is well documented, providing the opportunity to develop an effective diagnostic test. Further clinical validation of this approach is currently underway in studies co-ordinated by Professor Mark Emberton, Consultant Urologist at University College London.
Limitations Of Existing PSA Measurements
The current routinely-used prostate-specific antigen (PSA) diagnostic has major limitations, with inaccurate results leading to large numbers of patients undergoing unnecessary additional testing and biopsy. A rapid, accurate, non-invasive test would meet a major unmet clinical need, and consequently has significant commercial potential. According to Glide Pharma, approximately 24 million PSA tests are conducted each year in the US alone, with the worldwide market valued at more than $2 billion.
Next Steps
Glide Pharma plans to provide the technology initially as an analyte specific reagent in the USA. In the longer-term, the company intends to develop a prostate cancer diagnostic test, and to pursue regulatory approval in the US and Europe.
Source: www.glidepharma.com

item.title: Reckitt Benckiser To Create Stand-Alone Pharmaceutical Business [news]
item.description: Reckitt Benckiser To Create Stand-Alone Pharmaceutical Business [news]
item.content:encoded:
Reckitt Benckiser To Create Stand-Alone Pharmaceutical Business [:PharmaWorld:news]
PharmaWorld10924 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 July 2014 | 17:01

Comment: Reckitt Benckiser yesterday announced its intentions to create a stand-alone pharmaceutical business based around the treatment of addiction in its many forms. Included was reference to a derivative of the spasticity drug Arbaclofen which it is developing for alchohol addicition.
Background
Right from January 2012 onwards, Reckitt management have stated that RBP is not core to RB. Having waited to see the impact of generic entry on the business it is now in a better position to assess prospects and a valuation for the business.
What RB has created is a global leadership position in the world of addiction treatment, which is fast-growing, under-served market.

RB management are not ruling out selling this business. The preparations for a separation of RBP from RB are to a large extent common, whatever the form of the separation.

It believes RBP will be a magnet for interesting business development opportunities particularly in the under-served, fast-growing and large area of addiction treatment. This is the reason why it is going to pursue the de-merger with full energy.

Pipeline Perspective

From a pipeline perspective, Shaun Thaxter President & CEO of RBP noted that the group has moved on considerably over the last two years. It has in-licensed two new technologies, one, is arbaclofen placarbil, for the treatment of alcohol use, use disorders, and the other is Nasal Naloxone, which is an overdose rescue medication. And there are more opportunities moving forward. RBP is continuing to look for opportunities in cocaine/methamphetamine and cannabis addiction.

Source: www.reckittbenckiser.com

item.title: Bioniche To File NDA For Bladder Cancer Drug MCNA [dis:Bladder, news]
item.description: Bioniche To File NDA For Bladder Cancer Drug MCNA [dis:Bladder, news]
item.content:encoded:
Bioniche To File NDA For Bladder Cancer Drug MCNA [:Oncology:dis:Bladder, :Oncology:news]
Oncology9847 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 July 2014 | 10:47

Comment: Bioniche Life Sciences Inc. has provided an update on its flagship Phase 3 program, Mycobacterial Cell Wall-Nucleic Acid Complex (MCNA) sterile suspension for the treatment of patients with BCG refractory high grade non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC), noting that it will now file for US approval and seek external partners for commercialisation.
Outcome Of Regulatory Discussions
Following several months of active dialogue with the U.S FDA, concerning the most appropriate regulatory pathway for MCNA approval in the United States, Bioniche has received written guidance. This guidance provides regulatory clarity and permits the submission of an MCNA Biological License Application (BLA) for U.S. marketing approval review based on Bioniche's existing clinical trial data set.
In accordance with this feedback and in preparation for a timely and efficient submission of its MCNA BLA, Bioniche has engaged a top-tier global regulatory consulting firm that will help in the review and final preparation of the BLA. Bioniche will provide guidance on the anticipated timelines of this BLA submission following the completion of a full assessment of the regulatory tasks required to complete all BLA requirements.
Commenting on this development Dr. Michael Berendt, CEO of Bioniche Life Sciences Inc. stated
"This is the beginning of a new and significant transformative path for BCG refractory bladder cancer patients as well as for Bioniche and its shareholders. We are excited to have the opportunity to file a BLA for MCNA based upon our existing regulatory dossier and are determined and committed to making MCNA available to high grade non-muscle invasive bladder cancer patients who have failed BCG treatment and who are in dire need of treatment options beyond cystectomy."
Focus Now On Increasing Awareness of MCNA and Partnering Discussions
With regulatory clarity in hand, Bioniche is now in a position to advance discussions with potential partners who have demonstrated a commercial interest in MCNA for both the U.S. and other world-wide markets.
In parallel and in further support of its MCNA partnering discussions and so as to increase MCNA visibility within the broader urology community, Bioniche and its collaborators have prepared a clinical manuscript, describing MCNA Phase 3 results and post-study analyses, that is being submitted to a top-tier urology journal.
Source: www.bioniche.com

item.title: Soft Intelligence Regarding Sun Pharma's Activities With Octreotide [sub:Hybrids, prod:Octreotide, news]
item.description: Soft Intelligence Regarding Sun Pharma's Activities With Octreotide [sub:Hybrids, prod:Octreotide, news]
item.content:encoded:
Soft Intelligence Regarding Sun Pharma's Activities With Octreotide [:Endocrinology:news, :Endocrinology:prod:Octreotide, :Endocrinology:sub:Hybrids]
Endocrinology7749 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 25 July 2014 | 17:53

Comment: External intelligence has established that no clinical development activity has yet been initiated in the US or the EU with SPARC's (Sun Pharma) 1M or 3M formulations of octreotide. Sun Pharma was hoping to utilise Indian data for approval but no such agreement has been reached with either the EMA or FDA suggesting an abreviated clinical trial programme will be required. The group's 1M octreotide formulation was launched in India Q12009 and the 3M formulation is expected to be approved in India Q42014, having been filed in February this year.
Whilst it is not clear to SPARC what the FDA or EMA will actually require, one source speculated a clinical development timeframe of 17-18 months for the 1M and 25-30 months for the 3M (assuming a combined short phI/II followed by a phIII). An alternative could be that the authorities accept Indian phI/II data but require a phIII study for registration.
Based on the last public communicaton by SPARC on this topic in March 2013, an IND filing for either the 1M or 3M or both could be made in FY2015 (in or before Q116)
One benchmark that could potentially be used as a comparison is the groups's paclitaxel injection concentrate for nanodispersion PICN, publically disclosed timelines for which are avaiable.
  • Q2 2011 PICN IND filed - 505(b)2 regualtory route to be used
  • Q4 2013 Successful PICN phII meeting with the FDA announced
  • Q3 2014 PhIII protocol to be submitted to the FDA
  • Q4 2014 PhIII trial to be initiated.
  • 2018 target filing.
One final point to be confirmed, was that SPARC has not yet succeeded in finding a development partner for either the 1M or 3M formulation.
Source: DIG Worldwide

item.title: Ono and BMS Has Entered An Agreement For Co-Developing And Commercialising BMS' Immuno-Oncology Assests
item.description: Ono and BMS Has Entered An Agreement For Co-Developing And Commercialising BMS' Immuno-Oncology Assests
item.content:encoded:
Ono and BMS Has Entered An Agreement For Co-Developing And Commercialising BMS' Immuno-Oncology Assests
Oncology9845 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 24 July 2014 | 18:02

Comment: Following Ono's announcement for Opdivo (nivolumab)'s approval in Japan (Oncology9821:The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan), BMS and Ono Pharm Co,.Ltd, have now entered a collaboration agreement to develop and commercialize multiple immunotherapies as single agents and combination regimens as treatment of cancer in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. Under the agreement, Ono Pharma and BMS will develop and commercialize Opdivo (nivolumab) and ipilimumab (outside Japan Yervoy) across a broad range of tumor types in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan.
The agreement also includes additional early-stage clinical immuno-oncology assets from Bristol-Myers Squibb:
  • Lirilumab, an antibody that blocks the KIR receptor on natural killer cells
  • Urelumab, an agonist of the CD137 co-stimulatory receptor
  • BMS-986016, a LAG3 immune checkpoint inhibitor.
Development costs and commercial profits are shared equally when Opdivo is used in combination with any Bristol-Myers Squibb compound (Ipilimumab, lirilumab, urelumab, BMS-986016). When Opdivo is used as a single agent, ONO will fund the substantial majority of development costs and receive the substantial majority of commercial profits. For a Bristol-Myers Squibb compound used as monotherapy, or two Bristol-Myers Squibb compounds used in a combination regimen, Bristol-Myers Squibb will fund the substantial majority of development costs and receive the substantial majority of commercial profits.
Ipilimumab, a CTLA-4 immune checkpoint inhibitor, is approved in Taiwan for the treatment of patients with advanced melanoma who have received prior therapy, and is in late stage development as a potential treatment option for melanoma, small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) in Japan.
Ono Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd. is specialized in the production and sale of prescription pharmaceuticals and diagnostic reagents. Ono currently has marketed products for the treatment of
  • type II diabetes;
  • chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting;
  • osteoporosis
  • Alzheimer’s disease;
  • OAB
  • peripheral circulatory disorder;
  • bronchial asthma and allergic rhinitis;
  • diabetic peripheral neuropathy;
  • chronic pancreatitis
  • postoperative reflux esophagitis;
  • tachyarrhythmia during and post operation
  • RA
Opdivo will be Ono's first oncology marketed product. The company operates in Japan, South Korea, the UK and the US. Ono Pharmaceutical is headquartered in Chuo ku, Osaka, Japan and currently has co-promoting partnership with :
  • Merck &Co
  • Valeant Pharm North America
  • BMS
  • Novartis
  • Helsinn Healthcare
  • Palon AG
  • Progenics Pharm Inc
  • Kadmon Corp LLC
  • Onyx Pharm
  • Les Laboratoires Servier
  • Amgen
  • Merck KGaA
  • Eial
  • AstraZeneca

item.title: Roche Q2 Figures- Key Takeaway Octreolin Development Is Stopped [dis:Acromegaly, prod:Octreotide, headline, :Oncology:dis:Bladder]
item.description: Roche Q2 Figures- Key Takeaway Octreolin Development Is Stopped [dis:Acromegaly, prod:Octreotide, headline, :Oncology:dis:Bladder]
item.content:encoded:
Roche Q2 Figures- Key Takeaway Octreolin Development Is Stopped [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:headline, :Endocrinology:prod:Octreotide, :Oncology:dis:Bladder]
Endocrinology7742 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 24 July 2014 | 14:09

Comment: Roche has reported a solid performance with sales being driven by growth of the group's new breast cancer drugs (Perjeta and Kaldyca) and by strong sales of diagnostics. Octreolin phIII data was highlighted, as was the decision NOT to proceed further with a submission following interaction with the regulatory authorities in the second quarter. Meanwhile, Roche's ant-PDL1 immunotherapy will apparently move into phIII development for bladder cancer before the year end, with a phII study having started in Q214 in locally advanced and metastatic patients.
Daniel O'Day's (COO of Roche Pharmaceuticals) specific comments in relation to octreolin were as follows:-
"On Oral Octreotide we had some additional Phase III data plus some regulatory interactions in the second quarter. And we've decided to not move that program ahead so additional Phase III data, plus some regulatory interactions in the second quarter, and we decided to not move that program ahead. So we’ll be removing that program from our Phase III list."
Key Highlights Of Roche's Q2 Financial Performance

Whilst sales growth may be strong and newsflow positive for Avastin in terms of recent priority review designations for ovarian and cervical cancer, newsflow for high-risk carcinoid disease and newly diagnosed glioblastoma has not been so good (see below).
Product Pipeline Developments
Key developments with Roche drugs in bladder, pancreatic, prostate and HCC are highlighted below, Commenting on its immunotherapy programme Daniel O'Day made the following remarks:-
It was terrific year at ASCO this year for our cancer immunotherapy program. Those of you that you were able to attend the Roche event where, we highlighted the fact that we have now 20 projects in the clinic or pre-clinically for cancer immunotherapy. We presented of course on our bladder cancer anti- PDL1 ph1 data, which was one of the highlights of the ASCO meeting this year, that received breakthrough therapy designation. We also presented on anti-CSF-1R. And we started to expose you to other compounds we have like anti-OX40 anti-CD40 and our immunotherapy combinations which again, if you remember the cancer immunotherapy cycle, you know we remain convinced that it is extremely important to approach cancer immunotherapy with multiple ways of approaching a cancer immunotherapy cycle and with biomarker strategies to determine which patients might be able to best respond. And we continue to make good progress there.

I remind you we have the -- another cancer type, so this would be the fifth cancer type for Roche for cancer immunotherapy and anti-PDL1 that we'll disclose in the second half of this year.

Just because I can't get away from this data on the right-hand side here, it was extremely encouraging for bladder cancer patients; remember these are patients that are generally over the age of 65, quite compromised. The only available therapy today is chemotherapy and surgery and many of these patients cannot tolerate that. And what we saw in our Phase 1 single arm is a 43% response rate at six weeks. And when you looked at that data at 12 weeks we had a 52% response rate. This is partial response and complete response; of that around 7% were complete responses.

So as you know with the breakthrough therapy status, with discussions with regulatory authorities, we're now moving very aggressively into our larger Phase 2 that's already enrolling and planning for a Phase 3 trial in bladder cancer.

Comments
An addition to that news: according to one answer(*) from of Alan Hippe (CFO) in the Q&A session, the impairment charge related to the decision not to pursue octreolin development accounts for 64mEUR (CHF78million).
Facial value of the Roche Chiasma deal was USD595m, incl USD65m upfront.
"(*)Yes. The question on -- and we have outlined this in fact on Page 65 in our half year report, and because, well, the question is the impairment charges totaling CHF 166 million [136.5mEUR], what was it related to? That was the question. Is that just bito and MetMab, and my answer is no. One point I can outline here is oral octreotide is part of these charges of the CHF 166 million with the CHF 78 million which I mentioned here."
rao36589 / Endocrinology7748 / 25 July 2014 / 10:49:03 o'clock CEST

item.title: Xtandi's Got NICE Thumbs Up This Morning [comp:Astellas, prod:MDV3100, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.description: Xtandi's Got NICE Thumbs Up This Morning [comp:Astellas, prod:MDV3100, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Xtandi's Got NICE Thumbs Up This Morning [:Oncology:comp:Astellas, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:headline, :Oncology:prod:MDV3100]
Oncology9838 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 23 July 2014 | 15:17

Comment: Cost regulators for the NHS in England and Wales issued guidance recommending the use of Xtandi (enzalutamide) for prostate cancer this morning. The use of Xtandi has been given a green light to treat patients with prostate cancer in post-docetaxel setting.

Xtandi costs £2734.67 for one pack of 112 x 40mg capsules, which equates to an average treatment cost of £25,269 (based on 160 mg for a treatment duration for 8.5 months). Astellas has agreed a patient access scheme but the level of discount remains confidential. The Committee accepted that the cost per QALY for Xtandi compared with Johnson & Johnson's Zytiga (abiraterone) is associated with some degree of uncertainty. But it was satisfied that it would remain below £30,000 per QALY gained, and so represents value for money for the NHS.

Source: http://www.nice.org.uk/Guidance/TA3

item.title: A Ph3 Trial Is Planned To Assess Efficacy Of Combination Enzalutamide And Radium223 in mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.description: A Ph3 Trial Is Planned To Assess Efficacy Of Combination Enzalutamide And Radium223 in mCRPC [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
A Ph3 Trial Is Planned To Assess Efficacy Of Combination Enzalutamide And Radium223 in mCRPC [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9837 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 22 July 2014 | 18:41

Comment: This is a EORTC sponsored Ph3 study to evaluate if upfront combination of enzalutamide and radium223 improves radiological progression free survival compared to enzalutamide monotherapy in asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic castration resistant prostate cancer. The study has not yet open for recruitment.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02194842 (PEACE III)
Expected Enrollment = 560
Target Patient Population: asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic (i.e. no opioids and brief pain inventory score) with metastases to bone (≥ 2 bone mets) and progressive castration resistant prostate cancer
Study Expected Start Date December 2014
Study Estimated Primary Completion Date Oct 2018
Primary outcome: radiological PFS (time frame = 46 months after first patient entry)
Secondary Outcome: Overall Survival, First symptomatic skeletal event, time to next systemic therapy, second PFS in sequential regimen, Time to pain progression, adverse events, time to use of opioid analgesics, quality of life
Source: www.clinicaltrials.gov

Comments
A similar Ph2 trial (NCT02225704) sponsored by All Ireland Cooperative Oncology Research Group (ICORG) is also ongoing in Ireland - primarily to determine the safety and tolerability of radium-223 in combination with enzalutamide. Due to the primary objective is to determine safety and tolerability, the trial design is very different from the Ph3 trial as it is an open label study with single group assignment. The total recruitment of 44 patients is expected and the study is expected to complete in Dec 2016. The secondary outcome measure also includes time to clinical and PSA progression, time to first skeletal event, overall survival (for up to 2 years).
Jenny Wu / Oncology9906 / 27 August 2014 / 12:20:18 o'clock CEST

item.title: Allergan Initiates PhIII Crow's Feet Lines Trial In China [sub:Aesthetics, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China, headline]
item.description: Allergan Initiates PhIII Crow's Feet Lines Trial In China [sub:Aesthetics, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Initiates PhIII Crow's Feet Lines Trial In China [:Neurology:headline, :Neurology:prod:Botox, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
Neurology7662 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 22 July 2014 | 17:38

Comment ClinialTrials.gov is listing a new Allergan sponsored phIII aesthetic study in China which is due to commence in October 2014. This is the first such regulatory study Allergan has undertaken in China.
This study will evaluate the safety and efficacy of BOTOX® compared with placebo in patients with moderate to severe crow's feet lines (lateral canthal lines) and was listed for the first time late last week.
Key Endpoints
Primary Outcome Measures:
  • Investigator's Assessment of Crow's Feet Lines (CFL) Severity at Maximum Smile Using the 4-point Facial Wrinkle Scale (FWS-A) [ Time Frame: Day 30 ]
Secondary Outcome Measures:
  • Investigator's Assessment of CFL Severity at Rest Using the 4-point FWS-A [ Time Frame: Day 30 ]
  • Subject's Global Assessment of Change in CFL Using a 7-point Scale [ Time Frame: Day 30 ]
  • Subject's Assessment of CFL Severity at Maximum Smile Using the 4-point FWS-A [ Time Frame: Day 30 ]
  • Subject's Assessment of Age-related Facial Appearance as Measured by the Self-Perception of Age Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Day 30 ]

Enrollment & Timelines

400 patients will be recruited with expected study completion according to the primary endpoint in August 2015.

ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02195687

item.title: Combination Approach of Two Cancer Vaccines Received FDA Breakthrough Designation
item.description: Combination Approach of Two Cancer Vaccines Received FDA Breakthrough Designation
item.content:encoded:
Combination Approach of Two Cancer Vaccines Received FDA Breakthrough Designation
Oncology9836 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 22 July 2014 | 17:16

Comment: CRS-207 and GVAX combination has received breakthrough therapy designation for treatment of metastatic pancreatic patients. Both therapeutic vaccines are developed by Aduro Biotech Inc., a private biotechnology company focusing primarily on development of immunotherapy for cancer.
The designation was based on findings from a Ph2 randomized, controlled, multicentre study, which enrolled 93 patients who failed or refused prior therapy. The findings were presented at the GI ASCO and demonstrated a statistically significant survival benefit in patients receiving GVAX + CRS 207 versus GVAX alone. The median overall survival of patients receiving the combination was 6.1 months compared to 3.9 months (GVAX alone) with a hazard ration of 0.59 (one sided p=0.0172).
Aduro is currently conducting a 240 patient Phase 2b clinical trial (ECLIPSE; NCT02004262) in metastatic pancreatic cancer patients who have progressed after at least one line of therapy. The randomized, controlled 3-arm trial will involve over 20 clinical trial sites in the U.S. and Canada and will evaluate the safety, immune response and efficacy of the combination immunotherapy of GVAX Pancreas and CRS-207 compared to chemotherapy or to CRS-207 alone. The primary endpoint of the trial is overall survival.
Source: www.adurobiotech.com

item.title: Glide Pharma Completes Pre-Clinical POC With Novel Solid Dose Formulation Of Octreotide [headline, dis:Acromegaly, dis:pNET, :PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery]
item.description: Glide Pharma Completes Pre-Clinical POC With Novel Solid Dose Formulation Of Octreotide [headline, dis:Acromegaly, dis:pNET, :PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery]
item.content:encoded:
Glide Pharma Completes Pre-Clinical POC With Novel Solid Dose Formulation Of Octreotide [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET, :Endocrinology:headline, :PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery]
Endocrinology7738 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 22 July 2014 | 16:02

Comment: Glide Pharma, a pharmaceutical development and device company focused on solid dose formulations of therapeutics and vaccines, has announced that its solid formulation of octreotide acetate achieved successful results in a pre-clinical proof-of-concept study comparing it with the currently marketed liquid product (Sandostatin®). A clinical POC is planned to complete in 2015.
Route To The Clinic
Based on these results, the company intends to transfer the formulation production process to a contract manufacturing organisation (CMO), and to advance Glide octreotide delivered with the needle-free Glide solid dose injector (SDI®) into clinical trials in 2015.
Pre-Clinical Findings
The pre-clinical study compared the pharmacokinetic profile of the most widely used clinical dose of Sandostatin (100 mcg) with that of Glide’s octreotide solid dose formulation. The results demonstrated that there was no statistical difference between the two profiles (p<0.05).
Next Steps
Dr Mark Carnegie-Brown, Glide Pharma’s CEO, commented, “These results represent a significant milestone, both in the development of our final clinical formulation for Glide octreotide and of our scale-up capabilities. Together, these enable us to transfer the formulation manufacturing process to a CMO later in the year. This progress is mirrored in our device scale-up programme, and as a result we plan to complete an octreotide clinical proof-of-concept study with our Glide SDI® device in 2015.”
What Is The Profile Of The New Formulation & How Is It Administered
Glide Pharma's SSDI® is an innovative, patented drug delivery system for the injection of drugs and vaccines in solid doses.
The Glide SDI® comprises two main components:
  • The reusable Glide actuator powered by a mechanical spring
  • The disposable cassette pre-loaded with the drug formulation
All components, apart from the reusable actuator are sterile.
The core of Glide technology is a tiny, solid dose of active pharmaceutical. This is supplied contained in a disposable, plastic cassette in sterile packaging. Just prior to use, the cassette is inserted into the mechanical reuseable actuator. The spring powered actuator is primed by being pushed against the skin. It then automatically triggers at a preset spring force and delivers the implant through the skin into the body.
The dosing process is completed in a fraction of a second. The solid dose is 4 mm in length and pointed at one end.
Glide's Development Pipeline
Glide recently made two new appointments, that of Richard Bungay as Chief Financial Officer and Tony Mills as Director of Business Development. Both Mr Bungay and Dr Mills have extensive experience of the life sciences industry.
Richard Bungay has over 20 years’ corporate experience of the biotechnology and pharmaceutical sectors. His recent roles include CFO at Verona Pharma Plc and CEO of Chroma Therapeutics, prior to which he was Chroma’s CFO. Previously, he was Director of Corporate Communications and Strategic Planning at Celltech, following a period as Finance Director for AstraZeneca’s Respiratory and Inflammation Therapy Area. He also held a number of finance positions at Celltech, including Financial Controller. He qualified as a Chartered Accountant at Deloitte.
Tony Mills brings over 25 years’ commercial experience of the life sciences industry to Glide. He joins the company from the drug delivery company Q Chip Ltd where he was Chief Commercial Officer. He was also Vice President, Business Development at BioVex Ltd, and held several roles at BTG International including Vice President, Genomics and Proteomics. He holds a PhD in Virology from Liverpool University.
Glide Pharma is privately owned. Investors include Invesco Perpetual, Oxford Technology 3 VCT plc, Oxford Technology 4 VCT plc, Hygea VCT plc, Oxford Capital Partners, business angels and management
Source: www.glidepharma.com

item.title: Valeant Complains To The Regulators About Allergan's Misleading Statements [comp:Allergan, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.description: Valeant Complains To The Regulators About Allergan's Misleading Statements [comp:Allergan, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Complains To The Regulators About Allergan's Misleading Statements [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :Neurology:prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
Neurology7660 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 21 July 2014 | 19:05

Comment: Valeant has complained to the financial regulator in Quebec and the US SEC about false and misleading statements Allergan has made about its business. It issued a slide presentation on Friday highlighting some of the inaccuracies and outlining the growth it has achieved with Bausch & Lomb since the business was acquired, something Allergan has and continues to dispute. It is interesting to note the level of cost synergies Valeant has planned versus the cost savings announced by Allergan today ($2.7bn by an unspecified timeline vs. $475m in 2015).
A selection of the key slides is highlighted below.
Allergan's response to new Bausch & Lomb Growth Figures
David Pyott stated today "On July 18, Valeant pre-announced sales figures for Bausch & Lomb for Q2. We were impressed by some of the eye-popping growth numbers, which are outside any range of normal growth of these global ophthalmic market segments. We would encourage investors to ask Valeant [ph] about in-market growth relative to inventory changes as well as any rebating or promotional programs. Finally, we also look forward to Bausch & Lomb growth figures for Q3 so the trends can be monitored."
Source: valeant.com

item.title: Allergan Cuts Costs - Challenging What More Valeant Could Achieve [headline, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.description: Allergan Cuts Costs - Challenging What More Valeant Could Achieve [headline, prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Cuts Costs - Challenging What More Valeant Could Achieve [:Neurology:headline, :Neurology:prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
Neurology7659 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 21 July 2014 | 18:52

Comment: Alongside its Q2 earnings figures, Allergan has announced that it will cut its global workforce by 13% (1500 jobs) as a part of a restructuring programme intended to boost profilt growth over the next six years and achieve what maybe Valeant was planning to do but on its own.
The Restructuring Programme
The scope of the cost-cutting programme is more than analysts had been anticipating (range 5-10%). It will create savings of $475m in 2015 and enhance earnings per share by around $10 per share. Some of the detail of what is planned is highlighted in the slides below.
Key Takeaways From Q2 Figures
Allergan has posted the strongest increase in absolute dollar sales in any quarter in its history with strong contributions from nearly all of its businesses and major products.
Overall sales increased 15.9% in dollars and by 16.3% in local currencies reflecting strong underlying demand and the impact of many regulatory approvals all over the world.

The upswing in earnings was even more notable than the growth in sales with non-GAAP EPS $1.51, +23.8% versus Q2 of 2013. EPS. The revised outlook for EPS for full year 2014 is now in the range of 20% to 22% growth versus 2013.

Individual Business Performances

Ophthalmic Pharmaceuticals.

Q2 sales year-over-year grew strongly at 14.8% in local currencies and 14.5% in dollars. Year-to-date growth has been diversified with every operating region growing double digits, namely North America, Europe, Africa and Middle East, Latin America, and Asia-Pacific.

Botox Performance

Q2 sales increased year over year by 13.7% in local currencies, with double digit performance in both the therapeutic and aesthetic categories by 12.9% in dollars.

In the U.S., a strong upswing in sales for chronic migraine and the two approved bladder conditions were observed as we have continued to enhance our patient access programs, physician training, and practice efficiency support. In addition with the benefit of the upper limb spasticity indication, and what it claimes is weakened competition, sales are growing double digit in the neuro rehabilitation channel.

Regarding overactive bladder mangement are excited by a new print campaign entitled "Calm Your Bladder" and which will be initiated on TV in August. The American Urology Association and the society for Euro dynamics and female urology updated their guidelines in May that established BOTOX as the only standard, third-line treatment after firstly, behavioral therapy and secondly pharmacological treatment typically anticholinergics drugs.

Recent regulatory approvals for BOTOX,

Allergan now has lower limb spasticity approval in 10 of the 14 countries through the mutual recognition procedure in Europe and with this approval in all of the major western European markets it claims to be growing BOTOX therapeutic in Western markets at over 10%.

Additionally, overactive bladder was approved in France, Taiwan, and Ecuador and neurogenic bladder in Malaysia.

Aesthetic Performance

Allergan estimate, based on survey data, that the U.S. market year to date grew high single digits in the quarter with its sales growth being further boosted by our 3% price increase posted in January.

BOTOX market share remained high in June with over 77% Xeomin's re-entry has resulted in it now having a 7% share whil Dysport it claims has lost one point to 16% In Europe, it suggests it is successfully holding share in a growing market as it deals with price competition from Galderma and Merck's.

To quote Allergan the "blowout in the quarter with 46% growth in local currencies and in dollars was its filler range propelled by the launch of VOLUMA in the U.S. but also by the introduction of VOLBELLA and VOLIFT in many foreign markets. Every operating region recorded huge growth.

Source: www.allergan.com

item.title: AbbVie Successfully Acquires Shire [sub:Acquisition]
item.description: AbbVie Successfully Acquires Shire [sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
AbbVie Successfully Acquires Shire [:PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
PharmaWorld10921 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 18 July 2014 | 16:15

Comment: AbbVie succeeded today in buying Dublin-based Shire for £32 billion in a deal that will allow it to slash its tax bill by relocating to Britain.
Deal Terms
London listed Shire which makes medicines to treat rare diseases, fought off four earlier bids from AbbVie until the U.S. firm raised its price to 52.48 pounds per share - made up of 24.44 pounds in cash and 0.8960 new AbbVie shares.
Rational For AbbVie
Chicago-based AbbVie is buying Shire to cut both its U.S. tax bill and its reliance on arthritis drug Humira, the world's top selling medicine which loses U.S. patent protection in 2016.
AbbVie, which generates nearly 60 percent of its revenue from Humira, had until today to announce a firm offer for Shire, extend the deadline or walk away under UK takeover rules. It now plans to create a combined company incorporated in Jersey, the Channel Islands, which will pay an effective tax of about 13 percent, sharply lower than its current rate of about 22 percent, making the deal one of the biggest driven by the tactic known as tax inversion.
AbbVie's agreed price represents a premium of about 53 percent to Shire's share price on May 2, the last business day before AbbVie's first offer, which was rebuffed by Shire.
Source: Reuters

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Alkermes Sets Sight On Biogen Idec's Tecfidera [news]
item.description: Alkermes Sets Sight On Biogen Idec's Tecfidera [news]
item.content:encoded:
Alkermes Sets Sight On Biogen Idec's Tecfidera [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7658 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 18 July 2014 | 16:08

Comment Alkermes has announced that it is moving a new drug candidate into phI development for multiple sclerosis. The drug ALKS 8700 is novel and designed to convert into monomethyl fumarate (MMF). Biogen-Idec currently markets a twice daily formulation of MMF (Tecfidera) which is reaching blockbuster status as a therapy for MS.
Trial Design
Alkermes is initiating a 125 patient randomised phI trial to determine safety and tolerability of multiple formulations and doses of the new oral drug
Differentiating Properties
The company believes it has a shot at developing a successor that will allow for once-a-day dosing with fewer side effects.
We expect the results of this study to be highly informative and determine the therapeutic utility and differentiating features of ALKS 8700," Chief Medical Officer Elliot Ehrich said in a statement. "ALKS 8700 leverages Alkermes' expertise in prodrug chemistry and oral controlled-release formulations to offer potential differentiated tolerability and dosing for patients with MS."
Source: alkermes.com

NET Patient Foundation Calls For Support From UK Parliamentarians [:Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET, :Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7737 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 18 July 2014 | 12:59

Comment: The UK NET Patient Foundation is oranganising an event on the 4th November at the House of Commons aiming to increase awareness amongst parliamentairainas about NET and the challenges involved in timely diagnosis.
It also hopes to communicate the importance of NET centres of excellence and to bring NETs to the forefront of the cancer agenda.
The event will be hoseted the the MP Eric Ollerenshaw.
An invitation is extended to NET specialists , GPs and patients to attend from every region in the UK.
Attedance can be arranged by contacting Alex on 02035421118 or at netparliamentevent@theopen-road.com

item.title: Speculation Of Roche Buying Exelixis To Complete Its Melanoma Portfolio
item.description: Speculation Of Roche Buying Exelixis To Complete Its Melanoma Portfolio
item.content:encoded:
Speculation Of Roche Buying Exelixis To Complete Its Melanoma Portfolio
Oncology9833 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 17 July 2014 | 18:19

Comment: There have been some forms of speculative discussion amongst healthcare investors over the possibility of Roche buying Exelixis in order to capture the full economics of cobimetinib. Exelixis and Roche announced the positive results for the combination trial of cobimetinib with Roche's Zelboraf (vemurafenib) in metastatic melanoma patients with BRAF mutation. Investor estimates a potential price point of $1b bid depending on the timing. If this becomes reality, cabozantinib could represent a higher competitive threat entry in CRPC provided if positive results are announced from Exelixis' two Ph III studies of cabozantinib.
Currently Exelixis has a worldwide co-development agreement with Genentech for cobimetinib, under which Exelixis received initial upfront and milestone payments for signing the agreement and submitting the IND. Exelixis was responsible for development of cobimetinib through the end of phase 1, at which point Genentech exercised its option to further develop the compound. Under the agreement, Exelixis is entitled to an initial equal share of U.S. profits and losses, which will decrease as sales increase, and will share equally in the U.S. marketing and commercialization costs. Exelixis is eligible to receive royalties on any sales of the product outside the United States.
Cobimetinib is a potent and highly selective MEK inhibitor that has demonstrated a statistically significant improvement in PFS with Roche's Zelboraf (vemurafenib) for metastatic melanoma patients harbouring BRAF mutation. Roche's Zelboraf is approved and becoming established in melanoma. Analysts believe that Zelboraf will become standard of care for metastatic melanoma patients harbouring BRAF mutation. On its own, Zelboraf is already a $400m drug worldwide and analyst forecast cobimetinib and Zelboraf combination represent a $600m - $1 billion revenue opportunity for Roche in the US alone. Under current agreement, Exelixis is eligible for 50% profit share in the U.S. and a low-teens royalty overseas. This is a lot for Roche to be giving away to Exelixis. Although historically Roche has not acquired its cancer drug development partners, the large revenue opportunity may trigger an 'exception' decision.
Cometriq (cabozantinib) is currently Exelixis' only marketed product. It has been approved for medullary thyroid cancer. The most advanced clinical development programmes for cabozantinib are the two Ph3 (COMET-1 and COMET-2) trials in mCRPC patients who had been previously treated with abiraterone, enzalutamide or docetaxel. Results are expected to be announced end of this year although the confidence amongst the analysts are not very high. Despite of this, some investors believe cabozantinib could have a better shot in two other ongoing Ph3 studies in mRCC and HCC.
  1. cabo clinical trial.JPG  (103 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jew60237

item.title: Merz To Relocate Its US HQ To Raleigh North Carolina [comp:Merz, class:BotulinumToxins, prod:Xeomin, sub:Aesthetics]
item.description: Merz To Relocate Its US HQ To Raleigh North Carolina [comp:Merz, class:BotulinumToxins, prod:Xeomin, sub:Aesthetics]
item.content:encoded:
Merz To Relocate Its US HQ To Raleigh North Carolina [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:comp:Merz, :Neurology:prod:Xeomin, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7657 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 17 July 2014 | 17:17

Comment: Merz believes the move to Raleigh from Greensboro will accelerate "its vision of becoming the world's most admired, trusted and innovative aesthetics and neurotoxin company", according to Merz's North American President and CEO Bill Humphries.
The decision to centralize around Raleigh has taken more than a year to conclude with various metropolitan areas considered.
Why Raleigh?
Home to three Tier-One research universities, two of which have dermatology and neurology teaching programs, Raleigh is the heart of the country's life sciences industry, with more than 42,800 biotech employees and the highest concentration of doctorate degrees in the U.S.
Commenting on the development Michael McMyne Head of North American Operations stated:-

"Our investment in Raleigh is a testament to the area's talented workforce, business-friendly environment and high quality of life. We look forward to partnering with the state, Wake County Economic Development, Raleigh Economic Development and the Greater Raleigh Chamber of Commerce to invest in workforce development and job creation, further strengthening the Raleigh business community."
Timeline For The Relocation & Staff Projections

The relocation will take place in a phased approach over the coming year. Merz has executed a lease at 6501 Six Forks Road for 60,000 square feet, which will be custom-built to meet the company's needs today and for future growth. The new headquarters is expected to house 250 employees, including 50 net new jobs to the state of North Carolina.
Source: www.merzus.com

item.title: Novartis Q2 Figures - Key Takeaways [dis:Acromegaly, comp:Novartis, dis:Cushing, dis:MidGutNET, headline]
item.description: Novartis Q2 Figures - Key Takeaways [dis:Acromegaly, comp:Novartis, dis:Cushing, dis:MidGutNET, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Novartis Q2 Figures - Key Takeaways [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:dis:Cushing, :Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET, :Endocrinology:headline]
Endocrinology7735 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 17 July 2014 | 17:04

Comment: Q2 sales & operating figures came in below consensus due to a weak performance from the outgoing vaccines and animal health. However, full year guidance was confirmed, with cost savings and business transformation expected to boost margins. Comments about Sandostatin and Signifor were not particularly noteworthy although phIII results for Signifor in acromegaly were briefly highlighted and the company confirmed its expectation of both FDA & CHMP action for acromegaly in the 2H2014.
New Business Structure
With the exit from vaccines and animal health plus the acquisition of GSK's oncology products, Novartis will concentrate on three "powerhouse divisions" of pharmaceuticals, eyecare and generics with a single shared back-office organisation providing support.
Sales are expected to grow in the low-to-mid single digit percentage range this year as the company braces itself for generic competition to Diovan to lop $2.7bn off its top line, as Ranbaxy was granted approval for the first US generic at the end of June (see.
Pharmaceuticals Performance
Sandostatin's Performance
Sandostatin sales in the second quarter grew by 3% to $417m. US sales grew by 5% to $185m whilst sales in the ROW grew by 2% to $252m.

In January 2014, the ICA opened an investigation to assess whether Novartis Farma S.p.A. and Italfarmaco S.p.A. colluded on the supply of octreotide acetate (Sandostatin LAR and Longastatina®LAR, respectively) to prevent competition in tenders issued by the regions of Emilia Romagna, Veneto and Lombardia.

Oncology sales amounted to USD 3.0 billion (+4% cc). Excluding Zometa (USD 76 million, -52% cc), Oncology sales were up 8% (cc). By brand, growth was driven mainly by Afinitor (USD 384 million, +25% cc), Tasigna (USD 373 million, +18% cc) and Jakavi (USD 69 million, +100% cc).

Source: novartis.com

item.title: Billionaire Investor Paulson Strongly Supports Valeant As An Acquiror of Allergan [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Billionaire Investor Paulson Strongly Supports Valeant As An Acquiror of Allergan [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Billionaire Investor Paulson Strongly Supports Valeant As An Acquiror of Allergan [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7656 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 17 July 2014 | 12:54

Comment: John Paulson on Wednesday endorsed Valeant as a "very serious acquiror" and predicted that Allergan will not be able to rebuff Valeant without making an acquisition of its own.
Paulson's Significant Holding In Allergan
Paulson's hedge fund holds a roughly $1bn stake or 6 million shares in Allergan and announced on Wednesday his support for the Valeant bid at the CNBC Institutional Investor Delivering Alpha Conference.
Paulson called Mike Pearson, Valeant's CEO a very cost concious executive who has added significant value for shareholders in the last few years.
Ackman's Reaction To Recent Events
Institutional investor Ackman who is mounting a proxy battle to try and force Allergan's board to discuss the Valeant bid on Wednesday accused Allergan of violating its fiduciary duty for not entering negotations.
Ackman is apparently hosting a call with investors today which will focus on Allergan's corporate goveranance and other aspects of its business
Paulson earned his respect as a serious investor when he made a good call on the overheated housing market right in 2007.
Source: Reuters

item.title: Pfizer To Acquire Private US Sterile Injectable Company [sub:DrugDelivery, sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Pfizer To Acquire Private US Sterile Injectable Company [sub:DrugDelivery, sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer To Acquire Private US Sterile Injectable Company [:PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, :PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery]
PharmaWorld10920 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 16 July 2014 | 19:25

Comment: Pfizer has announced today it will acquire Innopharm for $225m with up to $135m of contingent milestone payments. The company is a specialist in developing complex injectable delivery forms including pens and depot injectables. The acquisition is intended to strengthen the presence of Pfizer Injectables, part of its Global Established Pharma Business.
Pfizer's Current Presence In The Sterile Injectable Market
Pfizer's current active sterile injectable portfolio consists of 44 products with over 190 presentations in the U.S. The new Pfizer portfolio of seventy three products will include currently marketed, as well as products filed with the FDA.
Innopharm's Expertise
Innopharm develops novel formulations of existing drugs, including hard-to-make products, such as those that require complex manufacturing capabilities or have bio-equivalency challenges, in areas such as cancer and central nervous disorders.
Commenting on the agreement John Young group president, Pfizer Global Established Pharma (GEP) stated; "Today’s announcement is an important milestone as we continue to look for innovative growth opportunities for our sterile injectables portfolio, which will increase to seventy three products with this acquisition,”
Source: www.innopharmainc.com

item.title: Sun Pharma Acquires Nucleur Medicine Specialist [sub:Diagnostic]
item.description: Sun Pharma Acquires Nucleur Medicine Specialist [sub:Diagnostic]
item.content:encoded:
Sun Pharma Acquires Nucleur Medicine Specialist [:Oncology:sub:Diagnostic]
Oncology9832 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 16 July 2014 | 16:53

Comment: Sun Pharma has acquired Pharmalucence Inc pharmaceutical company. The company develops, manufactures and supplies human injectable pharmaceuticals. In particular it is a speciliast in the production of injectable nuclear medicines with its oncology product portfolio including sestamibi injection, mebrofenin, pyrophosphate injection, preparation of technetium tc99m disofenin, and sulfur colloid injection. Deal terms have not been disclosed.
Pharmalucence is headquartered in Billerica, Massachusetts and employes 100 people.
As of this year it has a new 70,000sq.ft sterile fill and finish injectable facility making it the region's first CMO to utilize fully automated and isolated aseptic technology capable of producing small clinical fills up to full commercial scale production for markets worldwide. In April 2014 it submitted its DMF with the plan that the plant will become operational by early Q4 2014. The first product to be produced in the pl;ant will be the group's sulfur colloid injection.
The strategic importance of this acquisition to Sun Pharma at this point is not completely clear, albeit this oncology diagnostic business may well complement Sun Pharma's US oncology operations.
source: www.sunpharma.com

item.title: J&J Q2 Earnings Presentation Key Take Away [comp:JnJ, headline]
item.description: J&J Q2 Earnings Presentation Key Take Away [comp:JnJ, headline]
item.content:encoded:
J&J Q2 Earnings Presentation Key Take Away [:Oncology:comp:JnJ, :Oncology:headline]
Oncology9830 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 15 July 2014 | 18:37

Comment: During J&J Q2 Earnings Webcast today, J&J announced sales of $19.5 billion for the second quarter of 2014, an increase of 9.1% as compared to the second quarter of 2013. Operational results increased 9.4% and the negative impact of currency was 0.3%. Domestic sales increased 14.9%. International sales increased 4.4%, reflecting operational growth of 5.0% and a negative currency impact of 0.6%. Zytiga continues to demonstrate strong performance with Q2 sales of $562m representing >40% YoY growth worldwide.
Focusing on their Pharmaceutical Business, worldwide sales of $8.5 billion for the second quarter represented an increase of 21.1% versus the prior year on a total and operational basis. Domestic sales increased 36.6%. International sales increased 6.8% which reflected an operational increase of 6.9% and a negative currency impact of 0.1%. The newly launched products, in particular, Olysio for hepatitis C, are the main drivers of the strong sales.
Zytiga and Imbruvica in oncology are also being highlighted as the significant contributors of the growth. Joaquin Duato (Worldwide Chairman, Pharamceutical group) commented "Zytiga is the most successful oral oncology launch in history and metastatic castration sensitive registration trial is on track." Zytiga continues to hold significant market share in the U.S. (~34% MS), gaining 1.2 points versus the first quarter this year. Zytiga generated second quarter sales of $562 million representing more than 40% growth year-over-year worldwide. Nearly 60% of these sales in the quarter were outside the U.S.
Alex Gorsky (CEO, Johnson&Jonson) reassured the continuous investment in R&D in our five therapeutic areas and approximately 20% to 21% of sales will be put down for plans to file more than 10 new drugs and 25 line extensions between 2013 and 2017. Further investment with smaller scale acquisitions and early stage licensing agreements will surface through the innovation centers.
J&J's ambition is to
  1. establish unparalleled global development capabilities and have set industry benchmark for timelines for filing submissions and productivity and also for speed to market - 14 new products launched in the past 5 years (including 3 NMEs);
  2. deliver more than 10 potential NMEs and more than 25 significant line extensions between 2013-2017.
  1. Enter immuno oncology where there is promising new science and have established several collaborations.
Source: http://www.jnj.com/

item.title: Progress With The PhIII Programme For Plecanatide In Constipation [dis:Constipation, dis:IBS, news]
item.description: Progress With The PhIII Programme For Plecanatide In Constipation [dis:Constipation, dis:IBS, news]
item.content:encoded:
Progress With The PhIII Programme For Plecanatide In Constipation [:GastroEnterology:dis:Constipation, :GastroEnterology:dis:IBS, :GastroEnterology:news]
GastroEnterology2000 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 15 July 2014 | 17:31

Comment: Synergy Pharmaceuticals has announced that it has reached the halfway mark for total enrollment in the first pivotal phase 3 trial of plecanatide in patients with chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC).
PhIII Pivotal Programme For Plecanatide
The trial is currently being conducted at 180 sites and has randomized approximately 675 CIC patients. This is the first of two ongoing pivotal phase 3 trials designed to confirm the efficacy and safety of both 3.0 mg and 6.0 mg plecanatide doses versus placebo in CIC patients.
Synergy announced the initiation of its second phase 3 CIC trial in April 2014.
About Plecanatide & Additional Programmes

Plecanatide is Synergy’s lead uroguanylin analog in late-stage clinical development to treat patients with CIC and IBS-C. Uroguanylin is a natural gastrointestinal (GI) hormone produced by humans in the small intestine and plays a key role in regulating the normal functioning of the digestive tract through its activity on the guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) receptor. The GC-C receptor is known to be a primary source for stimulating a variety of beneficial physiological responses.
Orally administered plecanatide mimics uroguanylin's functions by binding to and activating the GC-C receptor to stimulate fluid and ion transit required for normal bowel function.
Synergy has successfully completed a phase 2b trial of plecanatide in 951 patients with CIC and is currently enrolling patients in two pivotal phase 3 CIC trials.
The company also recently announced positive top-line data results from a phase 2b dose-ranging study with plecanatide in patients with IBS-C. Synergy plans to initiate its pivotal phase 3 IBS-C program in the fourth quarter of 2014.
Source: synergy.com

It is essentially challenging Valeant management to adhere to its promise of improved disclosure by listing a long list of items it expects disclosure on during the group's Q2 earnings call (31st July).
Key growth concerns highlighted by Allergan relate to both that of Bausch & Lomb post acquisition and Valeant's share loss in neurotoxin and fillers post the Medicis acquisition. Of course Allergan fails to mention its own loss of share in toxins as a result of Xeomin's gains.

item.title: re: The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan
item.description: re: The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan
item.content:encoded:
re: The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan
Oncology9829 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 14 July 2014 | 17:55

The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan [:Oncology:class:MonoclonalAntibody, :Oncology:comp:BMS, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
Comment: BMS is slightly ahead of the race as its anti-PD1, nivolumab, has been approved for use in melanoma in Japan on 7th July 2014. Ono Pharmaceutical has the marketing rights in Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Bristol-Myers Squibb retains the rights elsewhere worldwide. Nivolumab was submitted under a rolling BLA in the US in April. This is one of the most highly anticipated drug approvals in oncology — the product has shown unprecedented response in melanoma, as well as several other tumour types.  ...
Jenny Wu / Oncology9821 / 09 July 2014 / 16:45:09 o'clock CEST
Comment: Bristol-Myers Squibb Company announced that, following discussions with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the company is planning a Q3 submission of a Biologics Licensing Application (BLA) for Opdivo® (nivolumab) for previously treated advanced melanoma. This will mark the second tumor type for which Bristol-Myers Squibb has a regulatory submission underway for Opdivo in the U.S. The advanced melanoma BLA is based on data from Checkmate -037, a multinational, multicenter, randomized open-label Phase 3 trial evaluating Opdivo compared to dacarbazine (DTIC) or carboplatin/paclitaxel in patients with unresectable or metastatic melanoma who have been previously treated with Yervoy® (ipilimumab) and, if BRAF-mutation positive, a BRAF inhibitor regimen.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9829 / 14 July 2014 / 17:55:46 o'clock CEST

item.title: A "Potentially" New Delivery System For Triptorelin
item.description: A "Potentially" New Delivery System For Triptorelin
item.content:encoded:
A "Potentially" New Delivery System For Triptorelin
Oncology9828 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 14 July 2014 | 17:52

Comment: An Iranian Group from Tehran University of Medical Sciences has published an article in Asian Journal of Pharmaceutics to evaluate a new composite of poly-lactic-co-glycolic acid (PLGA) and hyaluronic acid (HA) was designed and prepared in the form of implants containing triptorelin.
Impants technology have advantages over microparticles due to possibility of direct administration to the target site, requiring lower dosing frequency with longer duration. The major drawback of implant technology mainly due to the requirement for invasive procedure as well as risk of local immunological rejection. Omid's group utilised hyaluronic acid - a nature anionic polymer - as part of the formulation in the implants to overcome the risk of immunologic reactions at the administration site.
PLGA is synthetic polyester with biocompatibility and biodegradability in both crystalline and amorphous forms and offers flexibility related to processing. Currently, triptorelin salt is encapsulated in this polymer along with other solvents. Omid et al. postulated that designing a composite containing both PLGA and HA in an optimized ratio could create a similar drug release pattern similar to current triptorelin's formulation. This could also represent a promising delivery vehicle for other protein or peptides.
Source: Design, Preparation and characterization of novel poly-lactic-co-glycolic acid hyaluronic acid implants containing triptorelin acetate. Omid N.J. et al. Asian J Pharmaceutics Vol 8 Issue 1 2014 p.18-26. (Full Text link is available through PEARL).

item.title: Auspex Expects Financing to Bring Approx. $60M [dis:Huntington, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.description: Auspex Expects Financing to Bring Approx. $60M [dis:Huntington, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.content:encoded:
Auspex Expects Financing to Bring Approx. $60M [:Neurology:dis:Huntington, :PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
Neurology7654 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 11 July 2014 | 15:20

Comment: Auspex has announced the pricing of its underwritten public offering of 3,150,000 shares of common stock at a price to the public of $19.25 per share. The company expects readouts of SD-809, a deuterium-substituted version of Xenazine (tetrabenazine), for HD in Q4:14. Beyond SD-809, pipeline lists almost half a dozen earlier-stage, and still un-partnered additional deuterium substitution molecules in development. These earlier-stage opportunities remain unmodeled for now, but this platform could start to make some noise following initial SD-809 clinical validation.
Catalysts

SD-809 is being initially evaluated for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington’s disease.

  • ASPX anticipates pivotal data Q414, followed by US NDA filing and a potential first commercial product by YE15.

SD-809 also has potential applications in tardive dyskinesia and Tourette syndrome.

  • SD-809's Phase 2/3 tardive dyskinesia (TD) study is ongoing, with possible top-line data by mid-2015.

Interim Data

Design: The ARC-HD Switch trial is an open-label study examining safety/tolerability and chorea control in Huntington’s Disease patients who switch from treatment with Xenazine (tetrabenazine) to ASPX’s SD-809

Findings: interim analysis occurred after 12 patients were enrolled and had reached the week 1 time point.

Mean change in total chorea score at week 1 (n=12) and week 4 (n=8) were -0.83±0.51 and -0.75±0.75, respectively.

Safety: No SAEs encountered in the trial

See Neurology7623: Auspex - A Late-stage Development Company With An Asset Potential In Multiple Hyperkinetic Movement Disorders.
