item.title: Shareholders in Allergan Encourage CEO to Do a Large Acquisition [comp:Allergan]
item.description: Shareholders in Allergan Encourage CEO to Do a Large Acquisition [comp:Allergan]
item.content:encoded:
Shareholders in Allergan Encourage CEO to Do a Large Acquisition [:Neurology:comp:Allergan]
Neurology7653 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 11 July 2014 | 14:14

Comment: In an interview with the Financial Times (FT), CEO of Allergan has recognised that the company which has $14bn of cash on its balance sheet, is contemplating a deal, and should "act sooner than rather later if it was going to make an acquisition". Pyott indicated to Reuters the profile for a 'suitable acquisition', which is detailed below.
Suitable Acquisition / Partner Asset
- specialized, with differentiated technology
- with great connectivity with the physicians, and customer based
- with a growth profile (" ... acquiring a company with a 1% growth makes no sense"), and value creation
He outlined that "if aided by tax better, but if not it's ok as well".
Speculations Around Shire Still Ongoing
Some analysts have speculated that Shire could be a good partner for Allergan, with the Irish drugmaker currently considering a $51.5-billion bid from AbbVie.
A top 15 shareholder in both Allergan and Shire told the FT that the UK company would be more likely to accept an offer from Allergan than from AbbVie, even at a lower price, and that he would support such a choice because of Allergan’s faster growth prospects.
Source: Thomson

item.title: Key Messages from Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) Financial Results
item.description: Key Messages from Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) Financial Results
item.content:encoded:
Key Messages from Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) Financial Results
Endocrinology7734 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 10 July 2014 | 16:31

Comment: Sales in 2013 increased by 31.77% to €53.8M (from €40.8M in 2012).The year was marked by the continued expansion of the company's Molecular Nuclear Medicine (MNM) network, with the creation of AAA Poland and the signing of an agreement with the U. of Warsaw to operate its production site in 2014. Management indicated that Ph3 trial for Lu-DOTATATE (Lutathera®) is progressing as planned.
Strategic Milestones
A €4.8 million capital increase was completed in April 2013 to help fund expansion plans and finance clinical trials of a promising portfolio of MNM product candidates (See Endocrinology7371: Advanced Accelerator Applications (AAA) Reports Completion of €4.8M Capital Increase).
In March 2014, AAA received orphan drug designation from FDA and EMA for Gallium-68 DOTATATE for use in patients with GEP NETs
Recent Progress
In early 2014 AAA acquired Imaging Equipment Limited (IEL) giving the Company its first direct presence in the UK and Ireland, and a strong presence in all Europe’s G5 countries.
AAA continued its global expansion with the opening of an office in New York to support ongoing clinical studies for Ga-68 DOTATATE and Lu-DOTATATE.
AAA also recently started operations in its new French site in Marseille which produced and delivered its first doses of GLUSCAN® on 12 May 2014.

item.title: Entremed Now CASI Pharm. Receives US ODD for its HCC Drug Candidate
item.description: Entremed Now CASI Pharm. Receives US ODD for its HCC Drug Candidate
item.content:encoded:
Entremed Now CASI Pharm. Receives US ODD for its HCC Drug Candidate
Oncology9824 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 July 2014 | 17:49

Comment: The Company underwent a name change to CASI in June 2014 to reflect the Company’s shift to a new development model that includes a focus on the Chinese pharmaceutical market. Next steps for ENMD-2076 in HCC and/or in fibrolamellar carcinoma are being finalized. The drug is an orally-active, Aurora A/angiogenic kinase inhibitor with a unique kinase selectivity profile and multiple mechanisms of action.
ENMD-2076 Profile
ENMD-2076 has been shown to inhibit a distinct profile of angiogenic tyrosine kinase targets in addition to the Aurora A kinase. Aurora kinases are key regulators of mitosis (cell division), and are often over-expressed in human cancers. ENMD-2076 also targets the VEGFR, Flt-3 and FGFR3 kinases, which have been shown to play important roles in the pathology of several cancers.
ENMD-2076 has shown promising activity in Phase I clinical trials in many different solid tumor cancers including ovarian, breast, liver, renal and sarcoma, as well as in leukemia, and multiple myeloma, and is completing a Phase II clinical trial for ovarian cancer.
CASI is conducting a Phase II study of ENMD-2076 in triple-negative breast cancer, a Phase II study in advanced/metastatic soft tissue sarcoma, and a Phase II study in advanced ovarian clear cell carcinomas in North America. Pending approval by the CFDA, the Company intends to expand these trials into China. ENMD-2076 has received orphan drug designation from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of ovarian cancer, multiple myeloma and acute myeloid leukemia.
ENMD-2076 has strong global intellectual property protections worldwide with patents approved or pending for approvals in the US, Canada, Japan and many other countries. On May 6, 2013, the Chinese State Intellectual Property Office issued a patent for ENMD-2076 covering composition of matter and uses to treat various cancers.
Source: CASI Pharm

item.title: U.S.-Based Evolus to Start POC Trial of Daewoong's BTX-A for GL [class:BotulinumToxins, sub:Aesthetics, headline]
item.description: U.S.-Based Evolus to Start POC Trial of Daewoong's BTX-A for GL [class:BotulinumToxins, sub:Aesthetics, headline]
item.content:encoded:
U.S.-Based Evolus to Start POC Trial of Daewoong's BTX-A for GL [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:headline, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7650 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 July 2014 | 17:16

Comment: Approx. three hundred and fifty subjects will be enrolled, and injected with DWP-450 over the course of the 365 day study. PE will assess safety (incidence, severity and duration of any adverse reactions during the study period). The trial will take place in one single site in the U.S (ATS Clinical Research in Santa Monica, CA).
Trial Details
- Reference: NCT02184988
- Timelines: Start date August 2014 - Completion date August 2015 / October 2015
- Protocol: intra-muscularly injection into a total of 5 sites: the mid-line of the procures muscle, the inferomedial aspect of each corrugator muscle and the superior middle aspect of each corrugator, at least 1 cm above the bony orbital rim.
- Dosage: Each site is injected with 0.1 ml (4U), for a total of 20 U and 0.5 ml.
- Recruitment: Both genders
  • Subjects must be an adult 18 years of age or over
  • Subject has moderate to severe glabellar lines on maximum frown as assessed by the investigator using the GLS
  • Subject is willing and able to complete the entire course of the study

item.title: The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan [comp:BMS, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan, class:MonoclonalAntibody]
item.description: The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan [comp:BMS, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan, class:MonoclonalAntibody]
item.content:encoded:
The First Anti-PD-1 Has been Approved In Japan [:Oncology:class:MonoclonalAntibody, :Oncology:comp:BMS, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
Oncology9821 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 09 July 2014 | 16:45

Comment: BMS is slightly ahead of the race as its anti-PD1, nivolumab, has been approved for use in melanoma in Japan on 7th July 2014. Ono Pharmaceutical has the marketing rights in Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Bristol-Myers Squibb retains the rights elsewhere worldwide. Nivolumab was submitted under a rolling BLA in the US in April. This is one of the most highly anticipated drug approvals in oncology — the product has shown unprecedented response in melanoma, as well as several other tumour types.
Anti-PD-1/L1 as a class has dominated the news coming out of ASCO for the last 2 years. It has led to a huge interest in immunotherapy, and manipulation of the PD pathway in particular, and many pharmaceutical companies are investing in this research area, considered to be one of the most promising in the whole cancer field. Cancer immunotherapies such as the anti-PD-1/PD-L1 agents are predicted to be one of the key growth categories in the cancer immunotherapy market, which is predicted to grow from $1.1bn in 2012 to nearly $9bn in 2022 in the US, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, UK and Japan (Decision Resources).
Interestingly, melanoma is very rare in Far East countries, and Ono Pharm will provide the drug free of charge as soon as it is available until the time that it is listed on the national health insurance price list. Due to lack of sufficient patients available in Japanese clinical trials, the company is required to perform a postmarketing use/results survey covering all cases until data on a certain minimum number of patients have been accumulated. Although the clinical efficacy of nivolumab was first demonstrated in melanoma, it has since shown efficacy in a number of other tumor types, and Bristol-Myers Squibb has numerous studies with the drug ongoing. In the United States, the US Food and Drug Administration has granted a fast track designation for melanoma, non-small-cell lung cancer, and renal cell carcinoma, and it was recently granted breakthrough therapy designation for the treatment of patients with Hodgkin's lymphoma after failure of autologous stem cell transplant and brentuximab.
BMS is very closely tailed by Merck&Co (MSD)'s anti-PD1, pembrolizumab, for the treamtment of advanced melanoma. On 1st July, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has accepted Merck & Co's filing for for the treatment of advanced melanoma, putting it in contention to be the first drug in its class to reach the EU market. Pembrolizumab (formerly lambrolizumab; MK-3475) is one of the highlights of Merck's R&D pipeline and is being evaluated across more than 30 types of cancer, with peak sales estimated to reach around $500m in melanoma alone. Additional regulatory filings in other countries outside of Europe are planned by the end of 2014. Pembrolizumab was filed in US in January and could be approved by the FDA as early as October. In February 2014, Merck formed collaborations with Pfizer, Amgen and Incyte to explore the use of pembrolizumab in combination with other drugs across a variety of tumour types, including melanoma, renal cell carcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and breast cancer.
Other anti-PD1 or anti-PDL1 drugs coming through development include Roche's MPDL-3280A, while AstraZeneca and Novartis are also active in this area.

Comments
Comment: Bristol-Myers Squibb Company announced that, following discussions with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the company is planning a Q3 submission of a Biologics Licensing Application (BLA) for Opdivo® (nivolumab) for previously treated advanced melanoma. This will mark the second tumor type for which Bristol-Myers Squibb has a regulatory submission underway for Opdivo in the U.S. The advanced melanoma BLA is based on data from Checkmate -037, a multinational, multicenter, randomized open-label Phase 3 trial evaluating Opdivo compared to dacarbazine (DTIC) or carboplatin/paclitaxel in patients with unresectable or metastatic melanoma who have been previously treated with Yervoy® (ipilimumab) and, if BRAF-mutation positive, a BRAF inhibitor regimen.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9829 / 14 July 2014 / 17:55:46 o'clock CEST

item.title: Synergy's Plecanatide Expected to Enter Ph3 for IBS-C in Q4:14
item.description: Synergy's Plecanatide Expected to Enter Ph3 for IBS-C in Q4:14
item.content:encoded:
Synergy's Plecanatide Expected to Enter Ph3 for IBS-C in Q4:14
GastroEnterology1995 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 July 2014 | 15:58

Comment: Synergy Pharm has successfully completed an end-of-Ph2 meeting with the FDA, in which the regulatory agency gave the company the goahead to proceed into Ph3 testing. Analysts think that Salix may be interested in plecanatide as it would give it the ability to target all forms of IBS (since Salix already has Xifaxan for IBS-D).
Results from Ph2b

Synergy recently reported favorable results from a Ph2b trial of plecanatide in IBS-C, which appears to position the drug as a safer and equivalently efficacious option vs. linaclotide across the board, in both chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) as well as IBS-C.

Complete data from this trial, including the discontinuation rate due to diarrhea, could be presented at the American College of Gastroenterology (ACG) Meeting in Philadelphia, PA in October 2014.

Also see GastroEnterology1972: Positive Top-Line Data from a 424-Patients Ph2b Trial of Plecanatide for IBS-C.

item.title: Strategic Rationale of the Salix and Cosmo Unit Transaction [dis:Diarrhoea, headline, sub:CRCPrevention]
item.description: Strategic Rationale of the Salix and Cosmo Unit Transaction [dis:Diarrhoea, headline, sub:CRCPrevention]
item.content:encoded:
Strategic Rationale of the Salix and Cosmo Unit Transaction [:GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea, :GastroEnterology:headline, :GastroEnterology:sub:CRCPrevention]
GastroEnterology1993 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 July 2014 | 15:26

Comment: Salix has announced it is buying the part of Cosmo that is based in Ireland in an all-stock deal to become an Irish company and lower its tax rate. The combination makes strategic sense for Salix, as it further enhances its position as a leader to treat gastrointestinal diseases and disorders. Cosmo is the inventor and developer of Lialda and Uceris, has three products on the market and six in clinical development. Based on announced deal terms, analysts calculate that Salix is paying $1.74bn for the Cosmo assets (20% of current, outstanding shares).
Rationale for Salix
The company's strategy is to take GI products to both gastroenterologists and primary care.
Product Strategy - One of the benefit of the transaction for Salix is the addition of 2 promising Cosmo's drugs:
  • rifamycin MMX
    • in Ph3 testing for traveller diarrhea, with launch expected in H2:2017
    • in Ph2 for uncomplicated diverticulitis in adults >18 yeas old, with launch expected H1:2019
  • methylene blue MMX (to aid in the detection of colon cancer (launch expected H2:2017)
Growth Strategy- Management noted on the call the new tax structure will make Salix more competitive for future deals. While itmanagement indicated they are not shifting current Salix products' IP to Ireland, products acquired from Cosmo Tech will remain in the Irish subsidiary and will benefit from favorable tax rates. Further M&A/licensing deals would benefit from lower tax rates going forward under the new company.
Financial Strategy - To reduce Salix effective long-term tax rate from the high 30% range to the low 20% range. Upon the closing of the transaction, the new company will be incoporated in Ireland.
Please find attached the full presentation
  1. salix-combines-with-cosmo-presentation.pdf  (545,2 KB)

item.title: Patent and Trial Updates on Antisense's Acromegaly Program [dis:Acromegaly, :PharmaWorld:sub:IP, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Patent and Trial Updates on Antisense's Acromegaly Program [dis:Acromegaly, :PharmaWorld:sub:IP, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Patent and Trial Updates on Antisense's Acromegaly Program [:Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, :PharmaWorld:sub:IP]
Endocrinology7733 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 09 July 2014 | 11:47

Comment: The Canadian Patent Office has allowed patent application for ATL1103, which covers its use until February 2024. In addition, the company has confirmed that the results of the PE endpoint of the Ph2 trial are expected by the end of August 2014. Beginning of 2014, mangement reported interest from pharma companies in partnering the Ph3 development.
Patent Situation
Canadian Patent Office has allowed patent application 2,517,101 entitled “A Modified Oligonucleotide for inhibition of Growth Hormone Receptor Expression” which covers the Company’s growth hormone receptor (GHr) targeting drug ATL1103 and its use until February 2024.

The Canadian patent forms part of the Company’s extensive portfolio of intellectual property protecting ATL1103 and its applications in the modulation of Insulin-like Growth Factor-I (IGF-I) in the treatment of the growth disorder acromegaly and other diseases. This portfolio includes patents that have been granted and are now registered in the United States, Japan, New Zealand and Australia. In addition patent applications are in advanced stages of prosecution in Europe. Additionally, International application PCT/AU2013/000095 has been lodged covering the use of ATL1103 in combination with the GHr antagonist Somavert, for the treatment of acromegaly and cancer.
In the US, patent protection covers ATL1103 until January 2025, and in Canada and other jurisdictions to February 2024. In the US, Japan, Europe and Australia claims to ATL1103 can be extended up to a further 5 years. The International PCT application once granted, would cover the use of ATL1103 in combination with Somavert until 2032.
Ph2 Clinical Trial Update for Acromegaly
24 patients have completed the full 13 weeks of dosing in the trial. The opportunity presented for the Company to enrol an additional 2 acromegalic patients into the trial (now 26 in total) who will receive their final dose of ATL1103 by 19 July 2014, which will mark the completion of all dosing in the trial.
Safety : to date there have been no treatment related patient withdrawals from the trial or reports of any treatment related serious adverse events.

The Company expects to receive the results of the primary efficacy endpoint of the trial, being the statistical analysis of the change (percentage reduction) from each patient’s baseline (start of the study) serum IGF-I levels to their levels one week after the completion of dosing with ATL1103, by the end of August 2014.
ATL1103 Profile
- second generation antisense drug designed to block growth hormone receptor (GHr) expression thereby reducing levels of the hormone insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I) in the blood and is a potential treatment for diseases associated with excessive growth hormone action.
Important Milestones
Endocrinology6786: ALT1103 Successfully Meets PhI Trial Endpoint
Endocrinology7552: Positive Results from the Interim Analysis of Antisense's ATL1103 for Acromegaly

item.title: ENDO Insights Part II - Key Intelligence On Pasireotide & Novarits's New Cushing's Therapy LC1699 [headline, dis:Cushing, dis:Acromegaly, dis:MidGutNET, dis:pNET, comp:Novartis, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
item.description: ENDO Insights Part II - Key Intelligence On Pasireotide & Novarits's New Cushing's Therapy LC1699 [headline, dis:Cushing, dis:Acromegaly, dis:MidGutNET, dis:pNET, comp:Novartis, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
item.content:encoded:
ENDO Insights Part II - Key Intelligence On Pasireotide & Novarits's New Cushing's Therapy LC1699 [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:dis:Cushing, :Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET, :Endocrinology:headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
Endocrinology7721 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 08 July 2014 | 18:32

Comment:-Additional insight from ENDO focuses on Novartis''s pasiroetide both regard to timelines for approval of the acromegaly indication in the US and a future phIII NET trial, to commence in 2015. Additionally, It was noted that development work has started with a fluid-crystal formulation of pasireotide. PhII results for Novartis's new Cushing's therapy LC1699 were also presented, with an acknowledgement that a confirmatory phIII study LINC3 is now planned in a larger population.
Summary of Key Soft Intelligence:
  • Pasireotide LAR has been submitted for approval both with the FDA and the EAM with an advisory board (FDA) due to meet in September and expected outcome in November 2014.
  • The high costs of the drug was referenced by several speaker over the duration of the congress
  • A phIII trial of pasireotide LAR in NET is expected to commence in 2015 (confirmed by George Shen Novartis USA (first author of poster SUN-0617 entitled PK/PD analysis of pasireotide LAR and octreotide LAR support the efficacy results of the randomised , double-blind phIII study of patients with medically naive acromegaly). Personnel at the Novartis medical booth confirmed that a clinical trial of pasireotide LAR in NET was in discussion but could not confirm the timelines.
  • Shen also confirmed that development work has started with a fluid crystal formulation of pasireotide and that phI studies are in discussion for all indications.
  • Regarding Sandostatatin LAR, confirmation was obtained that the new device will be introduced to the US market very soon.
Pasireotide
Highlights of the key studies presented in oral and poster form.
Novartis had a notable presence at the meeting with several company sponsored oral and poster presentations updating the audience on the results of the phIII multicentre randomised PAOLA trial (data first reported at the ECE in April see Endocrinology7670: Insights From The ECE Meeting & Upcoming ENDO Congress). Phase III multicenter, randomised study (PAOLA) clinical study demonstrating that Pasireotide LAR has superior efficacy over octreotide LAR and lanreotide ATG in patients with inadequately controlled acromegaly The study was presented by Annamaria Colao Italy PP17-2, SUN0591. The following slides are from the poster preview session.
A copy of the poster is attached.
Poster 0615: Exploratory Data Evaluating the Effect Of Pasiroetide on GH, IGF-1, IGFBP-2, IGFBP-3, HbA1c and Glucose in Patients with Inadequately Controlled Acromegaly Enrolled in a 24-Week Study (PAOLA) presented by HA Schmid et al
Results & Conclusions- Elevated GH causes insulin resistance; therefore patients with inadequately controlled acromegaly may be particularly sensitive to developing pasireotide- induced hyperglycaemia. Given the increased glucose levels, the increase in IGFBP-2 levels was an unexpected observation. The effects of pasireotide LAR on glucose homeostasis may be attenuated by increased insulin sensitivity due to the compensatory increase in IGFBP-2. The approximate 50% of the population who did not receive antidiabetic medication had significantly lower baseline glucose levels than those who did, and pasireotide- induced hyperglycaemia was mild and decreased over time. A copy of the poster is attached.
Poster 0617: PK and PD Analyses of Pasireotide LAR and Ocreotide LAR Support the Efficacy Results of a randomised, Double-Blind, Phase III study in patients with Medically Naive Acromegaly, presented by G. Shen et al.
Summary: Pasireotide LAR was superior to octreotide LAR at providing biochemical control (GH and IGF-1) in patients with medically naive acromegaly in a 12 month study. The PK/PD of pasireotide and octreotide in these patients is reported here. A copy of the poster is attached.
Poster 0619: Is clinical practice reflective of Acromegaly treatment guidelines? Results From a Survey of treating Physicians in 45 countries, presented by GK Stalla et al.
Summary: Although guidelines for the treatment of acromegaly recommend control of both GH and IGF-1, 56% of the physicians responding to this survey consider it acceptable for a patient to have IGF-1>ULN, and 18% consider IGF-1≥1.5xULN acceptable. Although this lack of urgency to treat may reflect challenges in clinical practice, it suggests that many patients with acromegaly remain on the same treatment despite being inadequately controlled, which may impact on long-term patient outcomes, as well as on the cost of disease management. A copy of the poster is attached.
Poster 0726: An Acromegaly, Open-Label, Multi-Center, Safety Monitoring Program for Treating Patients with SOM230 (pasireotide) LAR who have need to receive medical therapy (ACCESS), presented by A Glamocak et al.
Summary: The primary objective of the ACCESS study is to document the safety of pasireotide LAR in patients with acromegaly. The primary endpoint of the study is the proportion of patients who experience a treatment-emergent grade 3 or 4 adverse event or a serious AE. The trial is ongoing and results are not currently available. A copy of the poster is attached.
Poster 0715: Study Design of a Phase II Trial of subcutaneous Pasireotide alone or in combination with Cabergoline in patients with Cushings Disease, presented by Maria Fleseriu et al.
This study was designed to evaluate safety and efficacy of pasireotide alone or in combination with cabergoline as a stepwise approach in patients with CD. This presentation described the study design of the phase II multicenter, prospective, international, open-label, non-comparative with patients with confirmed diagnosis of CD. A copy of the poster is attached.
Other Novartis-sponsored posters described reviews and patterns of pharmacologic treatments in patients with acromegaly (0592- Patterns of Pharmacologic treatment in US patients with acromegaly, JD Carmichael et al. & 16399- Systemic review of real-world evidence on treatment of Acromegaly, Nellesen D et al.) and a further three posters described the treatment patterns, clinical and economic burden of Cushings Disease (0645, 0646, & 0647, all presented by T Burton et al.) Poster 0592 is attached with some of the key data shown below.
LC1699 PhII Cushing's Results
The results from a 22-week multicenter, open-label study of LC1699 (a potent inhibitor of 11β-hydroxylase) in patients with Cushing’s disease were presented which demonstrated that LC1699 normalised urinary free cortisol levels in these patients (Rosario Pivonello, OR17-4).

item.title: Novartis Supports Ethical Clinical Research [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Oncology:comp:Novartis]
item.description: Novartis Supports Ethical Clinical Research [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Oncology:comp:Novartis]
item.content:encoded:
Novartis Supports Ethical Clinical Research [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Oncology:comp:Novartis]
PharmaWorld10917 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 08 July 2014 | 17:37

Comment: Novartis has released new global guidelines for Investigator Initiated Trials (IITs). The guidelines are designed to reinforce the company's commitment to the principles of ethics, governance and transparency, and its support of ethical clinical research.
New Guidelines Principles
  • "Compliance with the highest ethical and scientific standards
  • Robust medical and scientific governance systems within Novartis
  • Global training on the guidelines for Novartis associates including the rules of independence of third party investigators/sponsors
  • Financial transparency on funding support
  • Contractual requirement of third party sponsors to publish findings and report any safety information
  • Ongoing tracking and monitoring within Novartis and transparent sharing of information with investigators/sponsors"
Source: Novartis

item.title: New Trial of Sativex as an Add-on Therapy in Subjects With Spasticity Due to MS [dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: New Trial of Sativex as an Add-on Therapy in Subjects With Spasticity Due to MS [dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
New Trial of Sativex as an Add-on Therapy in Subjects With Spasticity Due to MS [:Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Neurology7644 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 07 July 2014 | 17:23

Comment: The Ph3 trial is planned to start end of Q3 2014 to determine the effective dose range and to demonstrate a non-effective dose range of Sativex compared with placebo in relieving symptoms of spasticity due to multiple sclerosis (MS). Locations have been listed in the US and UK.
Trial Details
Reference: NCT01868048

Primary Outcomes Measures

  • Physician Global Impression of Change (PGIC) questionnaire [ Time Frame: This is completed by the physician at each visit whilst using the study medication. ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]
  • Change in mean Modified Ashworth Scale score from baseline to the end of treatment period. [ Time Frame: The Modified Ashworth Scale will be performed at each visit of the study ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ] All 20 muscle groups were assessed for spasticity (using a 0-4 scale): 0= no increase in muscle tone to 4=considerable increase in muscle tone, passive movement is difficult. The score for all 20 muscle groups were added to give a total score out of 80. A decrease in score indicates an improvement in condition.
Recruitment: Approx 711
  • The subject is at least 18 years of age or older.
  • Diagnosed with any disease sub-type of multiple sclerosis of at least six months duration.
  • Spasticity due to multiple sclerosis of at least six months duration, which is not wholly relieved with current anti-spasticity therapy, and which is expected to remain stable for the duration of the study.
  • Subject must be receiving at least one of the following anti-spasticity therapies to be eligible: Baclofen, Tizanidine, Clonazepam, Diazepam, Dantrolene.
  • Subject is willing to maintain anti-spasticity medication at a stable dose for the duration of the study and should be stable for 30 days prior to screening.
  • If the subject is currently taking disease-modifying medication, this must be at a stable dose for at least three months prior to the screening visit; the dose must also remain stable for the duration of the study.

Timelines

Start date: Sept 2014 Completion date December 2016.

About the Collaboration

The collaboration includes a number of parallel and inter- connected projects that will cover pre-clinical, translational and clinical phases of drug development.

The parties will also create a joint Strategic Collaboration Plan that will be supervised by a Joint Steering Committee.

Prior Collaboration

As part of a prior alliance, AstraZeneca already has several pre- clinical and clinical projects ongoing at Gustave Roussy.

item.title: Key Insights From the WCGC Meeting in Barcelona 25th-28th June
item.description: Key Insights From the WCGC Meeting in Barcelona 25th-28th June
item.content:encoded:
Key Insights From the WCGC Meeting in Barcelona 25th-28th June
Endocrinology7717 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 04 July 2014 | 14:25

Comment: Thanks to Eva Pineda (Medical advisor, Comm.Ope. Specialty Care), we can share her report from ESMO's 16th World Congress on Gastrointestinal Cancer in Barcelona. Key points to emerge are that the CO-OPERATE II data will be presented at ESMO, whilst RADIANT-4 data is now likely to appear next year. Importantly, initial data from the SWOG trial of octreotide/bevacizumab vs interferon/octreotide has demonstrated no significant difference based on central radiology (a disappointing outcome for Roche).
Report Plus Key Slides
Around 4000 Oncologist/ 70 speakers of all continents (information coming of the Technical Secretary) attended the 16th edition of WCGC traditionally based in Barcelona.,
Medical Oncologists explained that the relevant new onco medical information is presented mainly in ASCO, congress that traditionally occurs just 3 weeks before this one. WCGC is an adequate forum to communicate new data just when has not been possible to do it in Chicago (deadline over...), for example, Phase III CT data of Sutent in pNETs where presented here. They believe that ASCO (end May, Chicago) and ESMO (end of September, Europe) have to be considered as the Oncology Congresses of reference.
NETs session
Around 2500-2800 delegates attended this General Session
Chairs: M Ducreux (Gustave Roussy, France) and R Salazar (Catalan Institute of Oncology, Spain)
  1. Recommendations for the management of pNETs
Dr Wiedenmann, planned speaker for this talk, had problems due to France air-traffic controllers strike and he was not able to attend the Congress. Dr Ruszniewski gave the talk with Dr Wiedenmann’ slides.
Some interesting points discussed:
  • Biotherapy is the most frequent first line medical treatment for NEN in Germany (36,7%)
  • Guidelines: Using current ENETs Guidelines 2012 as reference
  • for pNETs with liver metastasis without extrahepatic involvement: in those patients with bilobar liver extension of pNETs, SSA was presented as a treatment option instead to surgery but just after Chemo and, mainly, MTT.
  • for pNETs with metastatic, non resectable pNET: no changes were suggested
  • Dr Ruszniewski mentioned Cooperate 2 data (everolimus+ LAR vs everolimus) could be presented in ESMO 2014
  • Clarinet: presentation of the study design, patient distribution, PFS (overall and by subgroups). He mentioned the clinical relevance of pNET subgroup as well as the sample size was calculated for overall population no for pNET subgroup.
  • Cost: comparative of the german cost of standard chemo (998 €/month) vs temozolamida/capecitabine (3327 €/month), everolimus (4723 €/month) and Sutininib (5630€/month) was showed.
2. Recommendations for the management of intestinal NETs. Dr Pavel
Some interesting presented data:
  • A systematic review of the incidence of neuroendocrine tumours
  • Just 10-30% of intestinal NET are associated with carcinoid syndrome.
  • In those refractory carcinoid syndromes: dose escalation of both SSAs was suggested as first option, after that she recommend to add IFN and PPRT treatment. She also mentioned pasireotide and telotristat.
  • Data of phase II telotristat study was showed and information that a phase III is ongoing was given.
  • RADIANT 4 recruitment is over: data could be presented next year
  • “Wait and see” still is an alternative for those patients with stable disease and/or low Ki67. She recommends image test/6 months and, as soon as growth is detected (no RECIST criteria required), to start treatment. PROMID Overal Survival data (ASCO 2013) were used to justify this positioning.
  • Very nice comparative between PROMID and CLARINET designs. Data of CLARINET global PFS, midgut and subgroups were discussed
  • Guidelines: Using current ENETs Guidelines 2012 as reference
  • She mentioned Octreotide LAR is described at ENETs Guidelines as the standard of treatment for well differentiated midgut NET.
    • for midgut NETs with liver metastasis without extrahepatic involvement: SSA could be the first treatment option instead of surgery in those patients with bilobar liver extension
    • for midgut NETs with metastatic, non resectable disease: SSAs can be a first option not only for G1 with low tumor burden but also G2 with Ki67<10% and high tumour burden
  • Review of the ongoing CT in midgut NETs
3. Liver directed therapy for liver mestastases. Dr Ruszniewski
  • Chemoembolization is a potential treatment of refractory carcinoid syndrome
4. Efficacy and toxicity of PRRT. Dr Kwekkeboom (Rotterdam)
Some burning data:
· On going clinical trial: Chemosensitisation with Capecitabine before PRRT
  • Lutathera results avaialable data in 2016
  • Prospective trial of the neoadjucant use of Lutathera in patients with nonfunctioning pancreatic NETS proposed by Kweekboom in which predeined cirteria of tumor resectability should be incorporated
5. Q& A
1 to Prof Pavel about wait and see positioning
2 Dr Ruzsniewsky, and in an unrequested situation, commented: “To be honest, no differences between both SSAs should exists”. In that moment , already out of time, no more than 200 delegates where at the session room
Posters
Just five NETs posters where presented:
  • Presentation of insulinoma in developing countries: experience of 7 insulinomas in India
  • Most prevalent of pNETs in everyday clinical practice: review of papers published in different platforms (Brazil)
  • Retrospective study of the prognostic value of various pathological and immunohistochemical features in tissue samples of patients with pNETs: 37 patients, Australia
  • Gastric NET: a single center experience: 25 patients, Greece
  • Efficacy of LA SSA in patients with highly differentiated GEP NETs: 44 patients, Russia (just abstract available, no poster presented)
Exhibit Area
Booths/Stands:
  • Merck- Serono, Roche, Sirtex, Bayer (all of them Platino Sponsors)
  • Celgene, Amgen, Lilly , Sanofi (all of them Bronze Sponsors)
  • Taiho, Nordic (Contributors)
  • Nutricia: just exhibitor
No booth of Novartis, neither Pfizer.
Novartis Oncology was the sponsor of Ciber café

item.title: Bayer Inks Strategic Research Alliance for Endometriosis and Uterine Fibroids [comp:BayerSchering, dis:Gynea]
item.description: Bayer Inks Strategic Research Alliance for Endometriosis and Uterine Fibroids [comp:BayerSchering, dis:Gynea]
item.content:encoded:
Bayer Inks Strategic Research Alliance for Endometriosis and Uterine Fibroids [:Oncology:comp:BayerSchering, :Oncology:dis:Gynea]
Oncology9816 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 July 2014 | 14:52

Comment: Bayer and the University of Oxford will share responsibilities from basic research to early clinical trials in these two diseases.
Terms of the Alliance
Location
Joint research projects will be performed at the University of Oxford and at the Bayer HealthCare R&D Center in Berlin, Germany.
Duration
The collaboration will be for an initial period of 2 years but is open for extension for up to 5 years.
Development
Bayer is eligible to license both targets and potential drug candidates exclusively and will then be responsible for any subsequent clinical development and commercialization.
Financials
The University of Oxford will receive undisclosed milestone and royalty payments depending on the successful development and approval of potential drug candidates

item.title: BINDS Therapeutics Ends Nanotechnology Collaboration with Amgen [comp:Amgen, class:KinaseInhibitors, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
item.description: BINDS Therapeutics Ends Nanotechnology Collaboration with Amgen [comp:Amgen, class:KinaseInhibitors, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
item.content:encoded:
BINDS Therapeutics Ends Nanotechnology Collaboration with Amgen [:Oncology:class:KinaseInhibitors, :Oncology:comp:Amgen, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
Oncology9815 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 July 2014 | 14:45

Comment: The goal of this research collaboration was to optimize a specific therapeutic payload from Amgen. Despite achieving the objective of high tumor concentrations, the results were not sufficiently compelling to proceed forward and both companies have agreed that the program will not be continued.
About the Amgen Collaboration
Please see Oncology8714: Amgen and BIND Biosciences Sign $180M Nanomedicine Deal.
Partnership Ongoing with Leading Pharma Companies
- with Pfizer (http://ir.bindtherapeutics.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=791529) - BIND and Pfizer have entered into a global collaboration agreement to develop and commercialize Accurins™ utilizing select small-molecule targeted therapies. The collaboration aims to employ BIND's Medicinal Nanoengineering® platform to impart tissue and cellular targeting capabilities to molecularly targeted drugs.
- with AstraZeneca (Oncology8906: AZ & BIND Therapeutics Announce Worldwide Development & Commercialisation Agreement For Cancer Nanomedicine).
- with Roche (http://ir.bindtherapeutics.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=855513) - BIND and Roche have entered into a research agreement to discover novel nanomedicines. This collaboration will focus on combining BIND’s Accurin™ technology with Roche’s proprietary therapeutic payloads and targeting ligands to create Accurins for the treatment of diseases in a number of therapeutic areas outside of oncology.

item.title: New Guidelines Presented at the 47th Annual Meeting of the ESPGHAN (June 9-12) [dis:Diarrhoea, sub:Probiotics, :PharmaWorld:congress:OTHERS, :PharmaWorld:news]
item.description: New Guidelines Presented at the 47th Annual Meeting of the ESPGHAN (June 9-12) [dis:Diarrhoea, sub:Probiotics, :PharmaWorld:congress:OTHERS, :PharmaWorld:news]
item.content:encoded:
New Guidelines Presented at the 47th Annual Meeting of the ESPGHAN (June 9-12) [:GastroEnterology:dis:Diarrhoea, :GastroEnterology:sub:Probiotics, :PharmaWorld:congress:OTHERS, :PharmaWorld:news]
GastroEnterology1987 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 03 July 2014 | 11:50

Comment: The new guidelines were discussed at The European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology Hepatology and Nutrition (ESPGHAN). ESPGHAN and the European Society for Paediatric Infectious Diseases (ESPID) have closely worked on this production, with Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM) methodology. It was highlighted that Racecadotril, specific probiotics and also Smecta are recommended “weakly” based on “moderate quality evidence” to manage acute gastroenteritis in children, while gelatinne tannate is not recommended due to lack of evidence of efficacy. Thanks to Hélène Mathiex (Primary Care; Medical Development) please find below the main interesting points.
Main Points for Ipsen
Pr Alfredo Guarino was the Chairman and introduced the session .
- Pathogens - epidemiology
New rotavirus strain, and Norovirus are the more frequent
It seems that Rotavirus vaccination has not be able to decrease the number of acute gastroenteritis, and there is an important increase of Norovirus.
Salmonella is decreasing.
- Management of Acute diarrhoea
A phone call to the pediatrician or general physician would be appropriate to appreciate the severity, and the need of medical consultation ( which could be frequently avoided if correct phone contact). The Doctor could give the advice for the treatment. ORS is the 1st line treatment in children should be always available at home.
- Drug treatment
o Loperamide : NOT recommended (safety issues).
o Diosmectite : 2 news RCTs - may be considered : weak reco, moderate quality evidence.
o Racecadotril : 9 RCTs- may be considered : weak reco, moderate quality evidence (idem Smecta).
o Bismuth ; NOT recommended (safety issues).
o Zn : not recommended in EU (developed countries) as lack of evidence of efficacy.
o Probiotics : only 2 strains may be considered : weak reco, moderate quality evidence: Lactobacillus GG and S. Boulardii, some are NOT recommended (safety issues++), other are simply not sufficiently efficient.
o Prebiotics : not recommended as lack of evidence of efficacy.
o Synbiotics : not recommended as lack of evidence of efficacy.
o Gelatinne Tannate : not recommended as lack of evidence of efficacy.
The wording “ may be considered” refers to the difference between ORS which is mandatory and the drug which is not.
- In case of hospitalization, the potential treatments in addition to rehydration could be probiotics (which decrease the hospitalization by 1 day) or the immunoglobulins.
Conclusion
  • Smecta and racecadotril are on the same level, as probiotics. But these last have the advantage to be also considered during hospitalization.
  • To be also highlighted : the position on Zn, which is not WHO position (WHO being focused on developing countries).
Reference of the Publication
European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition/European Society for Paediatric Infectious Diseases Evidence-based Guidelines for the Management of Acute Gastroenteritis in Children in Europe: Update 2014.
Authors Guarino Alfredo; Ashkenazi Shai; Gendrel Dominique; Vecchio Andrea Lo; Shamir Raanan; Szajewska Hania
Affiliation *Department of Pediatrics, University of Naples Federico II, Naples, Italy .dag.Schneider Children's Medical Center, Petach-Tikva, and Felsenstein Medical Research Center, Sackler Faculty of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel .dbldag.University Paris 5 and Necker-Enfants-Malades, Paris, France Schneider Children's Medical Center, Petach-Tikva, and Institute of Gastroenterology, Nutrition, and Liver Diseases, Sackler Faculty of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, Israel , Medical University of Warsaw, Department of Pediatrics, Warsaw, Poland., Europe; Italy; France; Israel; Poland;
Source Journal of pediatric gastroenterology and nutrition, (2014 Mar 31) . (Electronic Publication Date: 31 Mar 2014) . Jul 2014 ; vol. 59: iss. 1: pp 132-152E-ISSN: 1536-4801. L-ISSN: 0277-2116., 2014, 10.1097/MPG.0000000000000375

item.title: Rottapharm Madaus Sets Price Range for IPO [:PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.description: Rottapharm Madaus Sets Price Range for IPO [:PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
item.content:encoded:
Rottapharm Madaus Sets Price Range for IPO [:PharmaWorld:sub:Finance]
GastroEnterology1986 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 July 2014 | 17:53

Comment: The company, focused on research in areas like anti-inflammatory-anti-rheumatic, bone metabolism, menopause & gastrointestinal disorders, intends to use the net proceeds from the offering to fund new acquisitions, launch new products and expand into new markets.
Financial Details of the IPO

Rottapharm said that it expected an IPO of its shares later this month to value the company at up to 1.8 million euros (about $2.46 billion).

Rottapharm, which operates under the name Rottapharm|Madaus, said that it expected to price its offering of 50 million shares at €7.25 to €9 a share. The bottom end of the price range would value the company at about €1.45 billion.

The offering represents about 25 percent of Rottapharm’s share capital, and it expects to list on the Mercato Telematico Azionario of the Borsa Italiana exchange in Milan

Company's Top10 Products
With the acquisition of the German Madaus Pharma, specialized in the production of natural pharmaceutics, Rottapharm strengthened a route already undertaken by many of its brands: from natural origin to active principle.
Company Strategy
Rottapharm|Madaus's strategy is set on growth not only through continuous investment in R&D and the consequent launching of new and innovative products, but also through possible new acquisitions in foreign countries.
Ongoing Trials
Please see http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results?recr=Open&spons=Rottapharm

item.title: Raptor Pharmaceuticals Enters Into $70m Financing Traction With HealthCare Royalty Partners
item.description: Raptor Pharmaceuticals Enters Into $70m Financing Traction With HealthCare Royalty Partners
item.content:encoded:
Raptor Pharmaceuticals Enters Into $70m Financing Traction With HealthCare Royalty Partners
PharmaWorld10911 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 July 2014 | 17:52

Comment: Orphan Drug Company Raptor has entered into an agreement with HC Royalty Partners for $70m in funding which includes $60m in new convertivle senior notes. The new capital will be used for expansion of the company's manufacturing capacity, for expansion of commercial operations in Europe for Procysbi (a drug expected to generate global net revenue of $55-65m this year) and the advancement of the company's development programs which include's RP-103 for Huntington's Disease.
Terms of the agreement
Under the terms of the financing agreement, the convertible notes to be issued to HC Royalty and its affiliates will pay interest quarterly at a rate of 8.0% per year. The notes mature on August 1, 2019 unless earlier converted, redeemed or repurchased in accordance with their terms prior to such date. Prior to August 1, 2019 the notes are convertible into shares of Raptor common stock at an initial conversion rate of 57.14 shares per $1,000 principal amount of notes, subject to adjustment, which is equivalent to a conversion price of $17.50 per share, representing a 49.6% premium over the closing price of Raptor's common stock of $11.70 per share on July 1, 2014. In addition, the notes are subject to automatic conversion into shares of Raptor common stock or redemption, at Raptor's election subject to certain conditions, if Raptor's share price is at or above 175% of the conversion price over a 30 consecutive day period. Any payment of the principal amount of the notes will be subject to a 10% payment premium.
The terms of the loan agreement signed December 20, 2012 have been revised to provide for an additional $10 million in funding. The base interest rate has been revised to an annual fixed rate of 8.0% compared to the original 10.75%. The Synthetic Royalty variable rate has been consolidated and revised to 8.0% on the first $50 million of revenue, from the original two-tier rate of 12.25% on the first $25 million and 6.0% on the second $25 million of net revenue. The second tier of 2.0% on net sales above $50 million remains unchanged. The scheduled maturity date of the term loans under the loan agreement is March 31, 2020. Starting on June 30, 2015, the term loans are scheduled to be repaid in equal quarterly principal payments of $3 million, with the remaining principal paid on the scheduled maturity date. All amounts owed under the loan agreement will continue to be secured by substantially all assets of the company.
With the new financing, Raptor will have $120m in cash on its balance sheet.
Deal Perspectives
Commenting on the agreement Raptor's CEO stated "This financing with HC Roylaty demsontrates their belief in Raptor's future prospects, provides balance sheet strength, and reduces the cost of capital of our debt facility."
Clark Futch Founding Managing Director of HC Royalty notes that:- "TheRaptor's franchise which includs PROCYBI is an asset of significant value that has performed above our expectations. We continue to believe cystinosis continues to present a significant global market opportunity for the company".
Company Development Pipeline
Source: www.raptor.com

item.title: Novartis to Start Registration Trial with LC1699 for Cushing's Disease [dis:Cushing, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, comp:Novartis]
item.description: Novartis to Start Registration Trial with LC1699 for Cushing's Disease [dis:Cushing, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, comp:Novartis]
item.content:encoded:
Novartis to Start Registration Trial with LC1699 for Cushing's Disease [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:dis:Cushing, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Endocrinology7714 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 July 2014 | 17:16

Comment: This pivotal trial intends to support the registration of LCI699 for the treatment of patients with Cushing's disease in the EU, Japan, and other countries. It is running in parallel with another trial started in March 2011 which will determine whether the drug can safely reduce the level of urinary free cortisol in patients with Cushing's disease (NCT01331239).
Registration Study Details
NCT02180217
Recruitment: approx 132
Timelines start date July 2014 / Completion May 2018
PE: Proportion of randomized patients with: mUFC </= ULN [ Time Frame: Week 34 (8 weeks) ]

Recent Reference

Conclusion from a multi-center, POC study has recently shown that LCI699, a potent 11β-hydroxylase inhibitor, was efficacious and well tolerated in patients with Cushing's disease.
J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2014 Apr;99(4):1375-83. doi: 10.1210/jc.2013-2117. Epub 2013 Dec 11. - LCI699, a potent 11β-hydroxylase inhibitor, normalizes urinary cortisol in patients with Cushing's disease: results from a multicenter, proof-of-concept study.
Bertagna X1, Pivonello R, Fleseriu M, Zhang Y, Robinson P, Taylor A, Watson CE, Maldonado M, Hamrahian AH, Boscaro M, Biller BM.

item.description: New Trial Evaluating Gallium-68 DOTA-TOC Imaging of Somatostatin Receptor Positive Malignancies [sub:Diagnostic, dis:MidGutNET, dis:pNET]
item.content:encoded:
New Trial Evaluating Gallium-68 DOTA-TOC Imaging of Somatostatin Receptor Positive Malignancies [:Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET, :Endocrinology:dis:pNET, :Endocrinology:sub:Diagnostic]
Endocrinology7712 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 July 2014 | 16:26

Comment: The University of California is sponsoring a new phII efficacy study to determine if Gallium-68 labeled DOTA-TOC PET/C T will result in the delineation of more lesions in patients with SSA receptor positivie malignancies than with conventional imaging with Octreoscan.
The conditions to be evaluated include neuroendocrine tumours, paranganglioma, carcinoid tumours and neuroblastoma.
Study Numbers & Timelines
The 120 patient study started in June and is due to collect in terms of primary outcome measures in June 2016
Primary Outcome Measures:
  • Number of lesions visualized [ Time Frame: 24 hours from injection of DOTA-TOC ]
ClinicalTrials Identifier:- NCT02177773

item.title: New Allergan Sponsored Aesthetic Trial Evaluating Combined Facial Treatment - HARMONY Study [sub:Aesthetics, news]
item.description: New Allergan Sponsored Aesthetic Trial Evaluating Combined Facial Treatment - HARMONY Study [sub:Aesthetics, news]
item.content:encoded:
New Allergan Sponsored Aesthetic Trial Evaluating Combined Facial Treatment - HARMONY Study [:Neurology:news, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7643 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 02 July 2014 | 15:59

Comment: Allergan is listing in ClinicalTrials.gov a new US phIV patient satisfaction study which will evaluate the aesthetic and psychological impact of comined treatment with BOTOX® Cosmetic, JUVÉDERM® ULTRA XC, JUVÉDERM® ULTRA PLUS XC, JUVÉDERM® VOLUMA® XC, and LATISSE® (bimatoprost ophthalmic solution) for facial rrhytides, crow's feet lines, glabellar line and nasolabial fold.
Patients Nos and Timelines
The study was due to start this June and complete in April 2015 and involve 100 patients.
Key Endpoints
Primary Outcome Measures:
  • Change from Baseline in Satisfaction with Facial Appearance Overall Using a 10-item Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ]
Secondary Outcome Measures:
  • Change from Baseline in Aging Appearance Using a 7-item Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ]
  • Change from Baseline in Age Appraisal Using a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ] [
  • Change from Baseline in Social Confidence Using an 8-item Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ]
  • Change from Baseline in Psychological Well-Being Using a 10-item Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ]
  • Patient's Self- Perception of Age Using a 3-item Questionnaire [ Time Frame: Baseline, Month 4 ] [ Designated as safety issue: No ]

ClinicalTrial Identifier:- NCT02176356

item.title: Pharma Mar to Distribute GP Pharm's Politrate® (leuprorelin) in Italy [prod:Leuprorelin, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy, headline]
item.description: Pharma Mar to Distribute GP Pharm's Politrate® (leuprorelin) in Italy [prod:Leuprorelin, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Pharma Mar to Distribute GP Pharm's Politrate® (leuprorelin) in Italy [:DKPHybrids:headline, :DKPHybrids:prod:Leuprorelin, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Italy]
DKPHybrids250 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 July 2014 | 13:01

Comment: The agreement designates Pharma Mar S.R.L. as the sole distributor of Politrate® in Italy; the product will be supplied to Pharma Mar S.R.L. by GP Pharm. Pharma Mar plans to begin distributing Politrate® in Italy in October. Initially the 1M dosage will be distributed, with plans to subsequently add the 3M dose.
Presence on the French Territory
End of May, the company started commercial activities, with a sales team of 14 persons
  • as per today, Lurate®/Politrate® is not registered in France.
Rationale for Pharma Mar
The agreement is synergic with PharmaMar's commercial activities in other EU countries and is part of the company's strategy of enhancing its sales network by adding other products to its portfolio.
  • PharmaMar has a specialised sales team for the commercialisation in Europe.
  • Sales in the big Western European countries are covered by a sales network established for PharmaMar under an agreement with Quintiles Group organised in nine territories.
  • In the rest of Europe, promotional and sales distribution agreements have been signed with Swedish Orphan Biovitrum for the Nordic countries and Eastern Europe, and with Genesis Pharma for Greece, Cyprus and the Balkan region
Regulatory Status of Politrate®/Lutrate®
Lutrate® 1 month has been approved in 23 countries of the European Union, including Spain, Germany, the United Kingdom and Italy.
It is expected to be available shortly in the US (the registration dossier for Lutrate® Depot 1 and 3 months is expected to be submitted in the US in the second half of 2014) and many other countries.
The registration dossier for Lutrate® Depot 3 months was submitted (DCP with Spain as the reference country) in April 2014.
GP Pharm is currently developing Lutrate® Depot 6 months.
Pharma Mar SnapShot
PharmaMar is a Spanish member of the Zeltia Group, a leader in the development of antitumor drugs of marine origin
Pipeline
Source: GP Pharm / Pharma Mar

Comments
Thanks to Michela Maraschi we have been informed that Politrate 1 month will reach the market in Italy from January 19th.
Price at the NET of the mandatory discounts (-5%; -5%)
EFP: €84,83
PP: €140,01
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / DKPHybrids258 / 14 January 2015 / 16:48:47 o'clock CET

item.title: Genentech Acquires Next Generation Therapy for the Treatment of Hormone-Driven Cancers [news, :Endocrinology:comp:Roche, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Genentech Acquires Next Generation Therapy for the Treatment of Hormone-Driven Cancers [news, :Endocrinology:comp:Roche, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Genentech Acquires Next Generation Therapy for the Treatment of Hormone-Driven Cancers [:Endocrinology:comp:Roche, :Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Oncology9813 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 02 July 2014 | 10:39

Comment: The $1.7 bn acquisition of Seragon Pharmaceuicals, will expand Genentech's pipeline in next-generation therapies that target the estrogen receptor to treat hormone-receptor positive cancer (such as ER+ breast cancer), and provide the opportunity to accelerate development of Selective Estrogen Receptor Degrader (SERD) platform. Of note, Seragon was spun out of Aragon Pharm. in 2013 following its acquisition by J&J.
Rationale for the Deal
Roche has long dominated the field of breast cancer with drugs such as Herceptin and recently won approval for Kadcyla and Perjeta, two treatments for patients whose cancer cells contain increased amounts of the protein known as HER2.
Financial Terms
$725 million in cash up front along with $1.0 billion in contingent development milestone payments.
The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2014.
Seragon Pipeline
Lead candidate is ARN-810, currently in Ph1 for the treatment of endocrine-resistant breast cancer.
Seragon is developing a 2nd SERD compound that is chemically and pharmacologically distinct from ARN-810 that not only has potential in ER+ breast cancer but also ER+ endometrial and ovarian cancer.
Potential Competition
Breast cancer indication of Astellas' Xtandi and ARN-810 are in Ph2 and Ph1, respectively.
ARN-810 utilizes a new mechanism called SERD (selective estrogen receptor degraders), Xtandi is an oral androgen receptor blocker.
ARN-810 is being created by companies which boast a solid track record with ARN-509, and thus could be a potential competitor of Xtandi.
Seragon SnapShot
Founded in 2013
Seragon is based in San Diego, CA and financed by legacy Aragon investors The Column Group, OrbiMed Advisors, Aisling Capital, TopSpin and venBio.
Richard Heyman, former CEO of Aragon, has been named CEO of Seragon.

item.title: TheraCoat Seeks Strategic Partners for its TCGel in Bladder Diseases [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:iOAB, :PharmaWorld:sub:xLicensing]
item.description: TheraCoat Seeks Strategic Partners for its TCGel in Bladder Diseases [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:iOAB, :PharmaWorld:sub:xLicensing]
item.content:encoded:
TheraCoat Seeks Strategic Partners for its TCGel in Bladder Diseases [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:dis:iOAB, :PharmaWorld:sub:xLicensing]
Neurology7639 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 01 July 2014 | 18:04

Comment: TCGel is a novel Internal Cavity Drug Retention (ICDR) system via reverse thermal gelation technology. In ongoing trials, it is assessed with mitomycin for NMIBC and BTX for use in OAB. is in the process of raising USD 10m for a minority stake to support clinical trials in Europe and the US.
Theracoat Profile
- founded in 2004 by uro-oncologists, experts in polymer formulation and veterans in the medical device.
- Headquarters are located in Israel with an office in US.
- Business Development (for partnering opportunities, Dr Sari Prutchi Sagiv at: sari.sagiv@theracoat.com)
  • A strategic partner, such as a pharma company with generic or therapeutic drugs in urology or bladder cancer, could be a potential investor. Strategic players could also help take TheraCoat to market
  • Management could consider co-development, in-licensing and out-licensing partnerships, among others.
From http://theracoat.com, see original source.
Ongoing Trials
Please see http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/results/displayOpt?flds=a&flds=b&flds=f&flds=c&flds=k&flds=n&submit_fld_opt=on&term=theracoat&recr=Open&show_flds=Y
  • NCT02179099 - Safety and Efficacy of Intravesical Botulinum Toxin in TC-3 Gel in OAB Patients (Phase1/Phase2)
  • NCT01997983 - Efficacy and Safety of Intravesical Instillations of Botulinum Toxin in TC-3 Gel in IC Patients(Phase1/Phase2)
  • NCT01803295 - Evaluating the Effect of Pre-TURBT Intravesical Instillation of Mitomycin C (MMC) Mixed With TC-3 Gel in Patients With Non Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer (NMIBC)
  • NCT01799499 - A Prospective Open Label Comparative Dose Ranging Study Evaluating the Effect of Pre-TURBT Intravesical Instillation of Mitomycin C (MMC) Mixed With TC-3 Gel in Patients With Non Muscle Invasive Bladder Cancer (NMIBC)
Technology
Please see http://theracoat.com/technology/
Pipeline

item.title: Novartis About To Be Hit By The US Launch Of Generic Diovan [sub:Generics, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.description: Novartis About To Be Hit By The US Launch Of Generic Diovan [sub:Generics, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.content:encoded:
Novartis About To Be Hit By The US Launch Of Generic Diovan [:PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:Generics]
PharmaWorld10910 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 01 July 2014 | 10:17

Comment: The long-delayed and highly anticipated launch of generic Diovan is about to happen. This represents a potenitally significant boost for the Indian drugmaker Ranbaxy Laboratories and its owner Sun Pharmaceuticals but a significant threat to Novartis and its $1.7bn of US Diovan sales.
Diovan went of patent in the US in 2012 and Ranbaxy has the 180-day first-to-file exclusivity on the drug. However with bans imposed on Ranbaxy's 5 FDA-approved plants because of quality issues it has been impossible for Ranbaxy to get a product to market.
Recent Developments
Last Thursday the FDA approved Ranbaxy's Ohm Laboratories in New Jersey to start making valsartan the generic of Diovan in 40mg, 80mg, 160mg and 320mg doses. It is the only one of Ranb axy's 5 FDA-approved plants that has escaped bans for sales in the US. As soon as sufficient supplies have been manufactured to meet the needs of the market the generic version will be launched.
The delay has been a windfall for Novartis which should have been dealing with plunging sales but instead reported W/W revenues of $3.5bn of which the US contributed $1.7bn.
Source: Fiercepharma

item.title: Allergan's R&D Business Update Call - Mix Of Good & Bad News But Nothing On Toxins [comp:Allergan, dis:Migraine, news]
item.description: Allergan's R&D Business Update Call - Mix Of Good & Bad News But Nothing On Toxins [comp:Allergan, dis:Migraine, news]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan's R&D Business Update Call - Mix Of Good & Bad News But Nothing On Toxins [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :Neurology:dis:Migraine, :Neurology:news]
Neurology7638 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 01 July 2014 | 09:45

Comment: Allergan hosted a short webcast yesterday to comment on three key R&D developments: i) new information of DARPin vs Lucentis in AMD; ii) approval of Osurdex in a subpopulation of diabetic macular edema patients; and, iii) another complete response letter from the FDA on the migraine drug Levadex which will delay the next FDA action until at least Q215 and iv) good durability data on bimatoprost SR implants.
DAPRin vs. Lucentis Data In AMD (Age-related Macular Degeneration)
Leerink analysts are suggesting that whilst at first sight it looks as though the phIII DAPRin efficacy data was numerically better at 16 weeks on second appraisal there is a belief that Lucentis underperformed. The analysts state: "While we believe AGN's conclusion that "abicipar at the 2mg dose is at least as effective as monthly Lucnetis with a longer duration of action" is consistent with the phII data, a comparison of data in the labels for both Lucentis and Eylea suggests that 5.3 letters would be a relatively poor performance for Lucentis. The 10% frequency of inflammation also compares unfavourable to the 1 and 2% rates listed on the labels for Lucentis and Eylea. Meanwhile, advancing treatments in development at Novartis and Regeneron as well as gene therapy options raise questions about DARPin's commercial potential.
Bimatoprost Glaucoma Data Looks Good
Allergan has reviewed phII data and the analysis suggests efficacy that is comparable to daily topical bimatoprost with a duration of four to six months. The data has been shared with the FDA and the agency is supportive of the company's decision to advance into phIII clinical development. PhIII trials will be intitiated by the end of 2014. Based on this data and the FDA response David Pyott suggestsed that the product may prove to be a "game-changer" in the treatment of glaucoma. Apparently 20% of patients are currently not well managed with topical drugs and compliance remains a huge issue with patients losing vision as a result. So despite the availability of generic daily formulations Allergan believes it will have strong pharmacoeconomic data to justify good reimbursment.
Levadex (Semprana) Delay Raises Questions About Allergan's Purchase of MAPP for $1bn
This is the third complete response letter from the FDA citing Levadex manufacturing issues. The two specific items listed in the CRL are related to specifications around content uniformity, on the improved canister-filling process, and on standards for the device actuation. There were no issues related to the clinical safety and efficacy of the product, and Allergan received draft labeling from the FDA for the product in June 2013. Allergan plans to meet with the FDA, and we will work to fully address these issues to the satisfaction of the agency. The company estimates that the next FDA action will occur by the end of second quarter 2015.
Osurdex Label Expansion
Allergan was happy to announce the label expansion for Osurdex to treatment a sub-population of diabetic macular oedema patients.
Ozurdex works by releasing the steroid dexamethasone over time to suppress inflammation, which plays a key role in the development of DME. Leerink analysts believe this approval represents a positive but modest commercial opportunity for the drug of around $100-259m.
Source: allergan.com

item.title: Merz NA Adds Novel Retinoid Compound for Skin Conditions [:Neurology:comp:Merz, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
item.description: Merz NA Adds Novel Retinoid Compound for Skin Conditions [:Neurology:comp:Merz, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
item.content:encoded:
Merz NA Adds Novel Retinoid Compound for Skin Conditions [:Neurology:comp:Merz, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
PharmaWorld10908 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 01 July 2014 | 09:16

Comment: Merz North America and Brickell Biotech have signed an agreement granting Merz an exclusive NA license, with additional internationa rights, to develop a novel retinoid compound for the treatment of acne and psoriasis. Brickell Biotech's lead compound BBI-4000, a novel topical soft anticholingeric, is being developed for the treatment of hyperhidrosis, with initial human clinical studies planned to commence during 2014.
Terms of the Agreement
- Merz NA will assume the full cost and responsibility for future development and commercialization, initially for North America
- Terms and finanacials remain confidential
About Brickell Biotech
Pipeline
Background
- founded in Nov 2009
- private
- Management team http://www.brickellbio.com/company/team.htm
About BBI-3000
- novel, potent topical/oral retinoid, acting as a highly selective RXR agonist
Source: Merz; brickell Biotech

item.title: Recent Event with Management Highlights the "New Novartis" [comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:comp:Novartis]
item.description: Recent Event with Management Highlights the "New Novartis" [comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:comp:Novartis]
item.content:encoded:
Recent Event with Management Highlights the "New Novartis" [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Oncology:comp:Novartis]
Oncology9808 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 30 June 2014 | 14:24

Comment: With 20 Novartis executives from all of the company businesses, Joseph Jimenez provided his "view of the world over the next ten years". Chronic diseases (such as diabetes and dementia), reimbursement, innovation will have a profound impact on the H/C industry. Management highlighted its technologies and innovative therapies that can help manage an aging population in heart failure, oncology, dermatology, respiratory diseases, and cell therapy. Pipeline holds promising potential for >14 blockbusters by 2018. For J Jimenez, innovation and scale are critical to "win in a future world".
Projected Blockbusters
Planned Filings 2014 to >2018
Estimation About Chronic Diseases
Management estimates " ... there will be an additional 100 diabetics in the world bringing that total to 500 million by the year 20255. We estimate that there will be somewhere between 50 and 100 million people with dementia by the year 2025. Chronic disease will move from about 60% of the disease burden today to over 70% by the year 2025. This is going to have a profound impact on the healthcare industry".
Pressure on Payers and Reimbursements
" ... governments are going to have to make trade offs between other social programs; education, transportation. That is going to put pressure on payers in the next ten years to look at reimbursement. We believe that reimbursement, if you're incrementally better or if you're not better is going to become tougher and tougher to get reimbursement".
" .. Because governments are going to push more and more spending on to the patient. They're going to have to take a more active role in their own healthcare".
About the Two Scenarios
J Jimenez reported that " ... The first one is a more negative scenario. I call this the brutal world in which there is slow economic growth. Healthcare is growing ahead of economic growth. Reimbursement, the true innovators are getting reimbursement. They're thriving in an environment like that. But if you're not innovating, you're in trouble in this scenario.
A second and more positive scenario is if you look at the technologies that starting to emerge for healthcare companies, developing new and innovative therapies that can help manage an aging population in heat failure, in oncology, in respiratory disease become bigger and bigger. New breakthroughs that we have not seen in the last ten years help payers manage an aging population. This is a much more positive view of what can happen over the next ten years".
New Novartis's Strategy Focuses on Three Businesses
  • Pharmaceutical business, which is over $30 billion
  • Alcon Eye Care business which is $10 billion
  • Sandoz Generics business, which is about $10 billion
Drugs with Strong Potential
Potential first in class and / or best in class
Novartis Oncology
- is pursuing personalized cellular immunotherpay with a portfolio of CARTs
- a broad pipeline, with agents covering most oncogenic pathways
- combinations are expected to be the future of targeted therapy
Full presentation @12
