item.title: ENDO Insights - Two Key Presentations On Oral Octreotide (Roche) & Octreoide SC Depot (Novartis) [comp:Novartis, comp:Roche, dis:Acromegaly, headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
item.description: ENDO Insights - Two Key Presentations On Oral Octreotide (Roche) & Octreoide SC Depot (Novartis) [comp:Novartis, comp:Roche, dis:Acromegaly, headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
item.content:encoded:
ENDO Insights - Two Key Presentations On Oral Octreotide (Roche) & Octreoide SC Depot (Novartis) [:Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:comp:Roche, :Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:ENDO]
Endocrinology7706 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 30 June 2014 | 13:51

Comment: Feedback from ENDO from has provided us with details of two key presentations made during one of the oral abstract sessions. The slides provide more detail than available before and together with the Q/A some interesting insight into perhaps some of the issues each product faces. Notably from a safety & adequate efficacy perspective with octreolin and a safety and sustained efficacy perspective for octreotide sc depot (previously known as CAM2029). Confirmation was also obtained that octreotide sc depot is now being further evaluated in a phII European study in both NET and acromegaly patients.
Shlomo Melmed's Presentation On Octreolin (oral octreotide)
Study Design
As can be seen from the slide below, the core treatment period with octreolin started at least 4 weeks after the last SSA injection. Oral octreotide was administered twice daily on an empty stomach at least one hour prior to a meal or 2 hours after a meal in a step up dose of 40, 60 and 80 mg/day. Per protocol subjects entered the fixed dose period when IGF-1 levels were normalised or stable for at least 2 consecutive visits. Subjects could revert to parenteral somatostatin analogues at any time for safety or efficacy reasons
Baseline characteristics are summarised below:-
Sixty three% of patients received octreotide LAR and 37% received lanreotide. Two hundred and thirty five patients were screened and 155 were enrolled into the study as shown in the slide below. Most patients failing to meet inclusion criteria had higher levels of IGF-1 despite being on injectable somatostatin analogues. Following dose titration 65 subjects were on 40mg, 33 subjects were on 60mg and 57 subjects needed 80mg. 53 subjects discontinued the treatment. The main reasons were treatment failure in 24 patients all having been titrated to the highest dose. Of the 102 subjects who completed the study, 86% elected to continue an extension period.
Key Efficacy Findings
91 subjects entered the fixed dose as responders and 82 ended the fixed dose period

The data above shows that all 110 patients who entered the fixed dose period maintained both IGF-1 and GH levels.

Similarly, the slide below shows this graphically for both the mITT and Completers & Responders population and that IGF-1 levels were unchanged between baseline and the end of the fixed dose period in both populations.
The PK profile of octreolin in a sub-set of patients during the fixed dose period is shown below and demonstrates dose propotionallity.
Safety Profile
Seventeen Serious AEs were recorded during the trial. Details of some and reasons for discontinuation due to other side-effects are shown below together with the more commonly observed side-effects consitent with the known safety profile of octreotide LAR:-
Overall Conclusions & Q&A
Question from the Chairperson, Anthony Heaney, USA:
“I was interested in the levels of GH with oral octreotide...
Response- “That is a good question and is one we are thinking about. It simply may be that the drug is more effective at suppressing growth hormone, as we know from other studies that GH and IGF-1 levels are not linear, and there is a non linear relationship between GH and IGF-1. And finally in terms of the measurement itself, the GH levels were all measured within 2 hours following the oral octreotide dose, and therefore were more reflective of the oral octreotide whereas the IGF-1 levels were more reflective of a long term sustained effect of the drug rather than the acute effect. It is an interesting observation which emerged from the data and it is something which we will be pursuing”.
Question from AnaMaria Colao, Italy:
“Shlomo, excellent presentation and very promising data for acromegaly patients. My question concerns the dose which was from 40-80mg/day, this must mean that a lot of the drug is lost because it is what we may give a month with injectable octreotide. So what cost do we expect to pay for this preparation to account for all the octreotide used?”
Response: “I am just a scientist and have no idea what the cost of the medicine will be”.
Question from audience:
“Yesterday we heard that new clinical guidelines indicate that we should only use IGF-1 levels to measure efficacy of a drug and here you suggest we need to measure IGF-1 and GH levels? So what is the best course to take”?
Response: “At the moment this drug has not been approved and the clinical guidelines state that the measurement of IGF-1 as an indicator of efficacy remains. But next year or year after when the clinical guidelines are reviewed again, this drug should be approved and then this question will be taken into account. But at the moment oral octreotide is not approved”.
Additional intelligence was obtained that the Phase 3 study of OOA in acromegaly was recently submitted to the NEJM with first author Shlomo Melmed
John Roberts (Novartis PK/PD Dept) Presentation On The PK/PD Profile Of CAM2029
This data was formely presented in poster form at the ECE meeting in late April
The following advantages of the novel depot octreotide formulation were noted:-
A few slides described the 45 degree angle of subcutaneous administration and the formation of a gel-like crystal deposit.
Study Design
After a 7-day washout healthy volunteers were randomised to three repeat once monthly injections of three different variations of formulations of octreotide sc depot compared to octreotide LAR, and IGF-1 levels were measured as depicted below:-

As can be seen, there was an immediate peak in terms of IGF-1 response followed by a sustained release of drug over 28 days.

The following 2 slides show a comparison of octreotide sc depot-B (30mg) versus octreotide LAR 30mg with mean plasma concentration of octreotide and IGF-1 by sampling time respectively. Octreotide concentrations for octreotide sc depot B equalled or exceeded those for octreotide LAR over the dosing interval on a dose-matched basis. Higher bioavailability (nearly 500%) was observed for octreotide sc depot B versus octreotide LAR. John Roberts stated “We believe this higher bioavailability is exciting as it gives patients more options of regimen selection. It is a sustained release of high levels of octreotide which has not been seen via the sc route before. This is very encouraging data”.

Octreotide sc depot-B showed more rapid and extensive suppression of IGF-1 after the first injection compared with octreotide LAR. Suppression was similar after the second and third injections.

Safety Profile

Safety and tolerability data for octreotide sc depot A, B and C formulations in healthy volunteers were more frequent overall compared with octreotide LAR. By comparison, it will be interesting to see how acromegalic patients will respond to treatment.

In terms of serious adverse events there were 2 that occurred: one possibly drug related and the other one was not, and in terms of discontinuations there were slightly more in the formulation-A group. Most AEs were deemed mild-moderate.
Overall Conclusions and Q&A
John Roberts stated:-
“Due to the high bioavailability seen with octreotide sc depot, we believe this new formulation of octreotide may provide opportunity for individualised dose/interval and may offer enhanced convenience when administered via a prefilled syringe with a thin needle”.

Questions from the audience:

Alan Harris (New York): “I would like to ask whether this new formulation of octreotide (as well as the oral octreotide) will in fact improve what has now become as a very low level of efficacy of octreotide, namely 20%. So basically 80% of patients are no longer controlled with octreotide compared to earlier studies, so do you expect this new formulation to actually improve upon the 20% we have seen reported since 2007”?
Response: Because of the intervals we are presented with we can perhaps be able to use every 2 weeks and we have a lower volume and it is a smaller needle and so we have an opportunity and because of the higher bioavailability seen we expect to see higher response rates in some patients”.
Question from audience (UK): “I am not sure whether the dose and the dose interval may stay the same as the programme evolves. I would like to challenge you on your word “sustained” in your conclusion, the octreotide level is varying because it is a logarithmic scale that you are showing on your graphs, there is a big difference between the peak octreotide level few days afterwards and the trough level that is present for a couple of weeks, is that going to translate into symptoms at the beginning of the treatment cycle of that month”?
Response: “So we do know that from immediate release octreotide that the very high Cmax values are tolerated in patients in the earlier trials that were and in that sense we feel that it is consistent with Cmax in wash out and what’s been really shown today is that we have to target Ctrough because it is the Ctrough that is driving IGF-1 and there is more to find out in the patient studies and how they will react to our new formulation”.
Summary of Dr Dowling's (Ipsen Consultant) discussion with speaker following presentation
Clarification of clinical trial status of CAM2029:
Response:
· Phase 2, initiated by Camurus, is currently ongoing in Europe. Camurus is in control of this study (although John Roberts implied that Novartis may oversee the development of the study and have some input. He re-iterated that Camurus had overall control of the phase 2 study).
· Novartis is currently in discussion on how best to proceed with the planning of phase 3 study. The company is in contact with several health authorities.
· Novartis is looking carefully at dosing regimens with reference to PK/PD data.
· John Roberts stressed the advantage of the sc depot technology in terms of ease and convenience of self-injection. The needle is fine with a pre-filled syringe. Compliance is the key issue.
· He also pointed out that octreotide sc depot may provide opportunity for individualised dose/interval regimens.

item.title: Endpoints of Index's Kappaproct® Reached in Ph3 for UC [dis:IBD, news]
item.description: Endpoints of Index's Kappaproct® Reached in Ph3 for UC [dis:IBD, news]
item.content:encoded:
Endpoints of Index's Kappaproct® Reached in Ph3 for UC [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :GastroEnterology:news]
GastroEnterology1985 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 30 June 2014 | 12:18

Comment: CEO of InDex expects to meet with regulatoriy agencies in EU and US to discuss path to approval. Last April, Almirall licensed the drug for EU, where the drug obtained an orphan drug designation.
About the Results
In the COLLECT study, 131 patients with moderate to severe Ulcerative Colitis with inadequate response to conventional therapy received either Kappaproct® or placebo as an add-on to conventional treatment. Concominant use of TNF-α inhibitors was excluded. The study was conducted at 40 sites in seven European countries (Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Poland and the UK).
Kappaproct was administrated as two single rectal doses, given at week 0 and week 4. The primary endpoint was clinical remission (Rachmilewitz/CAI score of ≤4) measured at week 12.
There was an unexpectedly high remission rate in the control group and there was no statistically significant difference observed on this measure. Statistically significant effects were demonstrated on the secondary endpoints symptomatic remission (blood in stool = none, number of stools weekly.
Current Treatments in UC
Kappaproct® MoA

item.title: re: Merrimack Meets Primary Endpoint of OS In PhIII Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer Study
item.description: re: Merrimack Meets Primary Endpoint of OS In PhIII Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer Study
item.content:encoded:
re: Merrimack Meets Primary Endpoint of OS In PhIII Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer Study
Oncology9807 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 27 June 2014 | 11:26

Merrimack Meets Primary Endpoint of OS In PhIII Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer Study [:Oncology:headline]
Comment: The NAPOLI-1 study evaluating a combination of MM-398 with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) and leucovorin in 2nd line metastatic pancreatic cancer has achieved an overall survival of 6.1 months, a 1.9 month improvement over the 4.2 month survival demonstrated by the control arm of 5-FU and leucovorin alone.  ...
Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK / Oncology9672 / 01 May 2014 / 14:07:44 o'clock CEST
Comment: Merrimack announced detailed results from NAPOLI-1 study (MM-39+5FU+leucovorin in metastatic pancreatic cancer previously treated with gemcitabine based therapy. Detailed results were presented by Andrea Wang-Gillam MD PhD Assistant Professor of Medicine, Washington University School of Medicine during the oral session in ESMO GI held in Barcelona. A statistically significant advantage in PFS was seen with a median of 3.1 months compared to 1.5 in the control arm. A higher overall response rate of 16% was also seen in the combination arm compared to control arm (1%, p<0.001). The most common grade 3 or above adverse events are consistent to those reported in May except neutropenia incidence (20%) was slightly higher than those reported in May.
Abstract #O-0003 NAPOLI-1: Randomized Phase 3 Study of MM-398 (nal-IRI), with or without 5-Fluorouracil and Leucovorin, versus 5-Fluorouracil and Leucovorin, in Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer Progressed on or Following Gemcitabine-based Therapy
Study results for MM-398 in combination with 5-fluorouracil and leucovorin
  • Patients on the combination therapy of MM-398, dosed at 80 mg/m2 Q2W with 5-FU and leucovorin, achieved an overall survival of 6.1 months versus 4.2 month survival demonstrated by the control arm of 5-FU and leucovorin alone (HR=0.67, 95% CI [0.49-0.92], p=0.01).
  • The combination arm demonstrated a statistically significant median PFS of 3.1 months compared to 1.5 months in the control arm (HR = 0.56, 95% CI [0.41-0.75], p=0.0001).
  • Safety and efficacy data for patients treated with MM-398 were consistent with previously reported top line data and results from earlier MM-398 clinical studies. Hematologic grade 3 and higher adverse events in the combination arm included neutropenia, which was observed in 20% of patients as determined by objective laboratory values, and febrile neutropenia which was observed in 2% of the patients. The most common non-hematologic grade 3 and higher adverse events were fatigue (14%), diarrhea (13%) and vomiting (11%).
  • The overall response rate in the combination arm was 16% versus 1% in the control arm which was statistically significant (p<0.001).
  • A reduction of CA19-9 levels was observed in 36% of patients in the combination arm versus 12% of patients in the control arm. The reduction of CA19-9, a pancreatic tumor marker indicative of patient response to MM-398, was defined by a greater than or equal to 50% decrease in baseline CA19-9 levels.
Study results for MM-398 as a monotherapy
  • MM-398, dosed at 120 mg/m2 Q3W, had a 4.9 month median overall survival compared to 4.2 months in the control arm (HR=0.99, 95% CI [0.77-1.28], p=0.942).
  • Patients on the MM-398 monotherapy arm achieved a median PFS of 2.7 months versus 1.6 months in the control (HR = 0.80, 95% CI [0.62-1.04]).
  • Neutropenia was observed in 16% of the patients on the monotherapy arm and febrile neutropenia was observed in 4% of patients. The most common grade 3 or higher adverse events included diarrhea (21%), vomiting (14%) and hypokalemia (12%).
  • The overall response rate of MM-398 alone was 6% versus 1% in the control arm.
  • A reduction of CA19-9 levels was observed in 31% of patients on the MM-398 monotherapy arm versus 12% of patients in the control arm.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9807 / 27 June 2014 / 11:26:19 o'clock CEST

item.title: Acquisition of Ulthera is the Largest in Merz's History [comp:Merz, sub:Aesthetics, headline]
item.description: Acquisition of Ulthera is the Largest in Merz's History [comp:Merz, sub:Aesthetics, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Acquisition of Ulthera is the Largest in Merz's History [:Neurology:comp:Merz, :Neurology:headline, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7633 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 27 June 2014 | 10:27

Comment: Merz has acquired the medical device company for up to $600M, to expand its portfolio of treatment options. The Ulthera® System is the first and only energy-based device to receive U.S. FDA clearance for a non-invasive aesthetic lift indication. It is used in a procedure known as Ultherapy®, which is an FDA-cleared treatment to lift skin above the eyebrow, on the neck and under the chin.
The transaction is expected to close in the third quarter of 2014.
Marketing Status
The Ulthera® System has been available internationally since 2008, and in the US since September 2009.

Ulthera SnapShot

Founded in 2004 and based in Mesa, Arizona.
Ulthera is a privately held company backed by top-tier venture capital firms New Enterprise Associates and Apposite Capital.
In March 2014, Ulthera acquired Cabochon Aesthetics. The FDA-cleared system developed by Cabochon -- used in a procedure to improve the appearance of cellulite -- will allow Ulthera to expand its technology offerings for physician practices worldwide.
Source: Merz

item.title: ANDA Filing By Activis For Acorda's MS Drug [news]
item.description: ANDA Filing By Activis For Acorda's MS Drug [news]
item.content:encoded:
ANDA Filing By Activis For Acorda's MS Drug [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7632 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 26 June 2014 | 15:46

Comment: Acorda Therapeutics, has announced receipt of a Paragraph IV Certification Notice Letter advising it that Actavis Laboratories FL, Inc has submitted an ANDA to the U.S FDA requesting permission to manufacture and market a generic version of AMPYRA® (dalfampridine) Extended Release Tablets, 10 mg.
Next Steps
Acorda is reviewing the Notice Letter and has 45 days from the date of receipt to commence a patent infringement lawsuit against Actavis Laboratories FL, Inc. in order to trigger a statutory stay period under the Hatch-Waxman Act. This would restrict the FDA from approving an ANDA until July 2017 at the earliest, unless a district court issues a decision adverse to all of Acorda’s asserted Orange Book patents prior to that date.
AMPYRA's Current IP Status
AMPYRA is currently protected by five patents listed in the FDA’s Approved Drugs Product List (Orange Book), four of which extend into 2025, 2026 and 2027, respectively. AMPYRA also has Orphan Drug status, which extends into January 2017.
Acorda has stated that it intends to vigorously defend its intellectual property rights.
Source: www.acorda.com

item.title: Eisai Files First Market Authorization for Lenvatinib (Thyroid Cancer) in Japan [:Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
item.description: Eisai Files First Market Authorization for Lenvatinib (Thyroid Cancer) in Japan [:Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
item.content:encoded:
Eisai Files First Market Authorization for Lenvatinib (Thyroid Cancer) in Japan [:Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:mkt:Japan]
Endocrinology7704 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 26 June 2014 | 14:11

Comment: The drug has received orphan designation in EU and the US, where filings have been planned for Q3:2014. Eisai's ambition is to establish lenvatinib as gold standard treatment for refractory thyroid cancer.
Company's Strategic Ambitions
Submission Plans
Thyroid Cancer Unmet Need in Japan
The number of patients with thyroid cancer in Japan is estimated to be between 13,000 and 29,000.
Although treatment is possible for most types of thyroid cancer, there are few treatment options available once thyroid cancer has progressed, therefore it remains a disease with significant unmet medical needs.
Potential Indications - Liver and Lung Cancer
- Ph3 results in HCC are expected in 2H 2015 (plan to submit in FY2016).
- Good Ph2 outcomes were released at ASCO in June for lenvatinib in NSCLC 3rd line), but Ph3 trial design has yet to be fixed (Eisai aims for filing in or after Q3:2019).
Drug Detail
Lenvatinib is an oral multiple receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) inhibitor with a novel binding mode that selectively inhibits the kinase activities of various RTKs including VEGFR, FGFR, PDGFRα, KIT and RET, involved in angiogenesis and tumor proliferation
Source: Esai

item.title: Strategic Rationale of AbbVie Possible Acquistion of Shire [:GastroEnterology:news, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:prod:Lupron]
item.description: Strategic Rationale of AbbVie Possible Acquistion of Shire [:GastroEnterology:news, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:prod:Lupron]
item.content:encoded:
Strategic Rationale of AbbVie Possible Acquistion of Shire [:GastroEnterology:news, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:prod:Lupron]
PharmaWorld10901 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 26 June 2014 | 11:56

Comment: Yesterday AbbVie presented strong arguments for the Shire acquisition. Strategic rationale reported by management include the tax inversion opportunity and the operational synergies. On the other hand, the combined company would 1/ lower AbbVie’s risk profile in lowering dependence on Humira (threat of biosimilars around 2017-2018), 2/ have a market leading position in the gastrointestinal segment. Please find below key messages.
Background of AbbVie's offers
  • AbbVie last offer valued Shire at roughly $46bn
  • Shire turned down three offers from AbbVie
Why Buy Shire ?
With its speciality niche, high margins and strong single-digit compound annual sales growth potential, Shire is likely to appeal to larger pharmaceutical peers.
The effective corporate tax rate among the lowest in the world also makes Shire an attractive takeover candidate.
  • Allergan, BMS, Biogen, Amgen, AbbVie and Gilead are among those cited in the press in recent weeks as seeking “tax inversion” deals
Strategic Rationale for AbbVie
AbbVie believes the combination has strategic rationale for all shareholders.
Key Messages from the AbbVie Presentation
The combination would create a leadership postition with growing therapeutic areas, a diversified portfolio of launched products, and stronger growth platforms
Combined Pipeline
Gastrointestinal Franchise
Shire has 2 key products in the Gastrointestinal unit, namely Lialda and Pentasa.
  • Combined sales of Lialda and Pentasa amounted to USD810m in 2013 or 16% of total revenues (below sales split in Q1 2014)
Gastro Sales Estimates
Gastro Pipeline
  • SHP555 is in the ph3 stage in the US and Shire is currently planning discussions with FDA to determine potential clinical development pathways. Based on the lack of available options for the treatment of chronic constipation, and what seems to be a better cardiac profile than for Cisapride, we see a strong probability of this drug being approved by the FDA
  • ph3 treatments for 8 rare and devastating hepatic diseases
  • LUM002 for the treatment of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis could potentially also come under this business unit, if launched.
Source: Shire; AbbVie

item.title: re: The First Approval OF PARP Inhibitor Is Underway
item.description: re: The First Approval OF PARP Inhibitor Is Underway
item.content:encoded:
re: The First Approval OF PARP Inhibitor Is Underway
Oncology9805 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 26 June 2014 | 10:57

The First Approval OF PARP Inhibitor Is Underway [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca]
Comment: Today FDA Oncologic Drugs Advisory Committee announced that the committee is planning to discuss application submitted by AstraZeneca for olaparib on 25 June. Olaparib is the most advanced PARP inhibitors in development, followed by rucaparib by Clovis Oncology and Niraparib by TesaroBio.  ...
Jenny Wu / Oncology9637 / 24 April 2014 / 13:35:23 o'clock CEST
Comment: Yesterday FDA held the Oncologic Drugs Advisory Committee and agency advisors voted 11-2 for AstraZeneca should complete a study to confirm olaparib's benefit before an approval decision can be made. If the FDA requires AstraZeneca to complete a confirmatory study before deciding on approval, the company is estimated to lose $150 million in sales through 2016, Bloomberg Industries said. Most importantly, A delay also would raise questions about AstraZeneca’s view that its experimental medicines were undervalued by Pfizer in the proposed acquisition, according to Bloomberg Industries..
After the committee meeting, Brent Logan (panel member and biostatistics professor at the medical college of Wisconsin) commented after the vote “there are a number of issues that raise concern about the benefit of olaparib helping patients to survive without their disease progression. That produces a magnitude of uncertainty.” AstraZeneca’s reanalysis of the drug, known as Study 19, found ovarian cancer patients with the BRCA mutation who took olaparib lived 11.2 months without their disease progressing compared with 4.1 months for those on a placebo. FDA staff members questioned whether the reanalysis skewed the results. If the difference in progression-free survival isn’t as pronounced, the risks associated with olaparib may outweigh the benefit. Safety concerns include bone marrow suppression, fatigue, nausea and abdominal pain as well as a “small but concern risk” of developing a certain kind of leukemia, according to the report.
AstraZeneca is attempting to gain accelerated approval of olaparib based on a Phase II clinical trial, the middle of three stages of trials usually required for approval. Early FDA clearance would require the drugmaker to complete a final-phase study, called SOLO-2, to stay on the market. Results from that study are expected to be available at the end of 2015.The FDA is expected to decide whether to grant olaparib accelerated approval by Oct. 3. AstraZeneca also is studying the drug in lung and breast cancers.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9805 / 26 June 2014 / 10:57:32 o'clock CEST

item.title: CEA-Leti and Akrivis to Develop Nanomed Platform
item.description: CEA-Leti and Akrivis to Develop Nanomed Platform
item.content:encoded:
CEA-Leti and Akrivis to Develop Nanomed Platform
Oncology9804 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 26 June 2014 | 10:57

Comment: French CEA-Leti and US-based Akrivis intend to develop a new, more efficient and safer platform to deliver high payloads specifically to targeted cells. The resulting targeted nanoparticles will be optimized in a first phase for research and pre-clinical in vitro and in vivo applications. Then, in a second phase, they will be further developed clinically for in vitro diagnostics, in vivo imaging and targeted therapy.
Details of the Deal
Technology
The new platform will be based on Akrivis Technologies' proprietary Z-TECT technology that targets and detects unusually low levels of proteins and molecular targets and Leti's Lipidot nanovector delivery capability.
  • Z-TECT combines nanotechnology, molecular detection and immunology to provide high sensitivity and detection levels across multiple immunoassays and other assay formats, from colorimetric to fluorescent detection in vitro and imaging in vivo.
  • The Lipidot technology is a versatile nano-delivery platform based on very small droplets of oil that encapsulate and carry drugs, fluorescent imaging agents or any other lipophilic payload to targeted cells for diagnosis or treatment.
Rationale
  • New theranostic platform will Combine ultrasensitive detection, high payloads and more efficient cell targeting.
Source: CEA-Leti; Akrivis

item.title: Allergan Tests BOTOX for Myofascial Pelvic Pain (MPP) [class:BotulinumToxins, comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Allergan Tests BOTOX for Myofascial Pelvic Pain (MPP) [class:BotulinumToxins, comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Tests BOTOX for Myofascial Pelvic Pain (MPP) [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Neurology7630 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 25 June 2014 | 17:59

Comment: The BotoxMPP Ph1 study, sponsored by the University Hospital Case Medical Center will determine whether or not injections with onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) improve symptoms of pain and tenderness. The PE will measure efficacy at 1 month post treatment versus placebo.
Rationale
Chronic pelvic pain affects 15-20% of the female population aged 18-50 years and accounts for up to 10% of gynecologic visits each year resulting in a cost of 2.8 billion dollars annually to the health care system. It is defined as non-menstrual (non-cyclic) pain that occurs on an average of two weeks per month for at least six months' duration; localized to the anatomic pelvis, anterior abdominal wall below the umbilicus, buttocks, or lumbosacral back.
Trial Details
Reference NCT02173405
Principal Investigator Sangetta Mahajan, MD
Recruitment: approx 40
  • Females age 18 years to 65 years
  • MPP for at least 6 months with pain ranked > 7/10 by VAS

Timeline This Ph1 has been planned to start this month and complete Sept 2015 / Sept 2016

Design of the two-arm study

Treatment Group : 20 patients randomly assigned to receive 100 U onabotulinumtoxinA reconstituted in 20 ml saline sequentially injected bilaterally into the pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, coccygeus, obturator internus, and piriformis muscles.

Placebo Group: 20 patients randomly assigned to receive 20 ml of saline bilaterally into the same pelvic floor muscles

Location: USA (2 sites)

item.title: re: ASIS Device for Botox in ULS and in Chronic Migraine
item.description: re: ASIS Device for Botox in ULS and in Chronic Migraine
item.content:encoded:
re: ASIS Device for Botox in ULS and in Chronic Migraine
Neurology7629 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 24 June 2014 | 17:27

ASIS Device for Botox in ULS and in Chronic Migraine [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :Neurology:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, :PharmaWorld:sub:Devices]
Comment: ASIS Corporation has been developing Automatic Subdermal Injection System for the correct injection of almost every Injectable products into a bloodless space just outside of the fascia, which exists subdermally (between the skin and muscle), or interfascially (between the deeper muscles). Two Ph1/2 will be starting in Q2:14 with details provided below.  ...
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Neurology7440 / 03 March 2014 / 18:16:42 o'clock CET
A new trial has been added for cervical dystonia (CD). The purpose of the study is to assess the safety and efficacy of Botox (onabotulinumtoxinA) administered intramuscularly and subdermally
Reference ASIS in CD NCT02074293
Over 6 months usage will demonstrate ASIS device's consistent performance on 60 adult subjects with cervical dystonia in which Gadolinium will be injected with ASIS subdermally in 30 subjects or conventional intramuscularly in other 30 subjects for these 7 muscle groups: Splenius, Scalene, Sterno-cleido-mastoid, Levator scapulae, Semispinalis, Trapezius, and Longissimus. An MRI will be taken immediately after Gadolinium injection, as starting reference, to which subsequent MRI taken at 6 hrs, 12 hrs, and 24 hrs later will be compared for Persistent %.
Over 12 months usage of Botox, instead of Gadolinium, will demonstrate the advantages of ASIS device subdermally over intramuscularly, for the same 60 adult subjects with cervical dystonia, on these particular 7 muscle groups: Splenius, Scalene, Sterno-cleido-mastoid, Levator scapulae, Semispinalis, Trapezius, and Longissimus.
A total of 60 subjects are planned to be enrolled in the study
Timelines Start date June 2014 - Completion date June 2015 / June 2016
Brigitte DESCHAMPS / Neurology7629 / 24 June 2014 / 17:27:14 o'clock CEST

item.title: DNA Vaccines Enters Ph2 for Prostate Cancer Before ADT
item.description: DNA Vaccines Enters Ph2 for Prostate Cancer Before ADT
item.content:encoded:
DNA Vaccines Enters Ph2 for Prostate Cancer Before ADT
Oncology9800 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 24 June 2014 | 17:07

Comment: Madison Vaccines, a clinical stage biopharmaceutical company, has announced enrollment begun in the expansion of a Ph2 trial of its lead product candidate MVI-816 (pTVG-HP). MVI-816 targets prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP), and can be delivered to patients by simple intradermal injection. The Vaccine is readily manufactured in a cost-effective manner, and is highly stable compared to protein or peptide vaccines.
Trial Details
Recruitment: The expansion will add 50 patients to the original cohort of 56 patients.
Criteria: The trial is enrolling non-metastatic prostate cancer patients who have rising PSA after their primary treatment (surgery or radiation), but before patients require androgen deprivation therapy (castration therapy).
Objective: The trial is seeking clinical evidence that MVI-816 can delay the onset of metastatic disease in these patients.
Sponsor/Collaborator: The trial is funded by the company, with patient recruitment currently underway at the University of Wisconsin, and future enrollment anticipated at the University of California, San Francisco and at least one other site later this year.
Source: MVI

item.title: AntiAndrogen May Also Have A Role In Triple Negative Breast Cancer [class:Antihormonals, comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: AntiAndrogen May Also Have A Role In Triple Negative Breast Cancer [class:Antihormonals, comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
AntiAndrogen May Also Have A Role In Triple Negative Breast Cancer [:Oncology:class:Antihormonals, :Oncology:comp:Astellas, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Oncology9798 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 24 June 2014 | 16:00

Comment: A new study being presented today at the Endocrine Society Annual Meeting shows that even triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) expressing very low levels of androgen receptor may benefit from antiandrogen therapy. TNBCs were recently divided into further subtypes including a subtype with high androgen receptor expression (Lehmann, JCI 2011). Recent work shows that while these cancers lack oestrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and aren’t driven by the gene HER2, up to a third of these tumours express the androgen receptor. Currently there is an ongoing phase 2 study to evaluate safety and efficacy of enzalutamide in TNBC patients who express the androgen receptor (NCT01889238).
Triple Negative Breast Cancer patients historically represent a subset of breast cancer patients with worst prognosis. They do not respond to HER2 targeted therapy and neither to hormonal treatment due to their phenotype of HER2 negative, and lack of oestrogen and progesterone receptors. Lehmann (2011) published an article in JCI and showed that TNBCs include a subtype with high androgen receptor expression. Based on these findings, Barton and colleagues treated cell lines with the drug enzalutamide and with shRNAs designed to knock down androgen receptor levels to find out how different subtypes could respond differently to anti-androgen receptor therapy. We all know that enzalutamide is in wide use for prostate cancer as prostate cancer is mainly driven by and dependent on androgen receptor.

“This line of work is starting to change our thinking about who and when – the timing and patient selection for anti-androgen receptor therapy in triple-negative breast cancer,” says Valerie Barton, the study’s first author and PhD candidate in the lab of CU Cancer Center investigator Jennifer Richer, PhD.

In vitro models showed that not only does anti-androgen receptor therapy reduce the ability of androgen-receptor-expressing triple-negative breast cancers to proliferate, migrate and invade, but for these cells, androgen receptor seems essential to survival. When Barton and colleagues blocked androgen receptor in these cells, the cells died. Interestingly, but it was not only the high androgen-receptor-expressing cells that were affected. However, this is still early data and requires clinical evidence to support the future development.
Currently Medivation/Astellas is recruiting for a Ph2 study to evaluate enzalutamide in triple negative breast cancer patients.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT01889238
Expected Enrolment = 95
Estimated Primary completion Date May 2015
Experimental Arm: 160 mg administered as four 40 mg soft gelatin capsules orally once daily

item.title: 6-Month Ped Ph2 Data of Versartis' Monthly hGH and OPKO/Prolor's Lagova (hGH-CTP) Presented @ ENDO [class:GrowthHormone]
item.description: 6-Month Ped Ph2 Data of Versartis' Monthly hGH and OPKO/Prolor's Lagova (hGH-CTP) Presented @ ENDO [class:GrowthHormone]
item.content:encoded:
6-Month Ped Ph2 Data of Versartis' Monthly hGH and OPKO/Prolor's Lagova (hGH-CTP) Presented @ ENDO [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone]
Endocrinology7703 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 24 June 2014 | 15:24

Comment: Versartis reported that the data are reinforcing the attractive profile of the drug and are viable for a Ph3 trial (design to be discussed with FDA in August). OPKO indicated the study allows selection of a dose for a Ph3 study, which is due to start in 2015 (adult Ph3 interim data are expected end of 2015).
VRS-317 - Efficacy and Safety Data
The monthly dose showed a smaller decrease versus semi-monthly. Annualized growth rates at six months were: 5.0 mg/kg monthly: 7.9 cm/yr vs. 8.15 cm/yr at three months. 2.5 mg/kg semi-monthly: 8.7 cm/yr vs. 9.21 cm/yr at three months. 1.35 mg/kg weekly: 7.6 cm/yr vs. 7.8 cm.yr at three months.
Safety at six months was very clean, with the vast majority of AEs reported as mild. Specifically, no nodules or lipoatrophy were seen at injections sites. More than 80% of patients had two or fewer occurrences of injection site reactions. One investigator stated that simply changing the injection site completely resulted in zero injection site reactions in one of his patients.
hGH-CTP - Efficacy and Safety Data
Management highlighted that ' ... very good safety profile of our product. Without any evidence for any problems with injection site reaction. And this is actually aligned with our technology which enables us to inject our product into very small volumes and high concentration using a single injection and using a 30 1G needle which you are all familiar from the insulin product. So we really feel comfortable with the data and then we are actually going to move forward with that into our ph3 study'.
Competition - OPKO/Prolor 6-Month Data
  • Specifically, base height and age are keys for predicting growth trends with daily GH, with differences making cross trial comparisons tricky and often inaccurate.
Versartis Management reported " ... there's a 2 year difference almost between their mean age and our mean age and our study. That effect alone can account for several centimeters per year different in growth rates just because of the difference in age.
The other major difference when one tries to compare against trials is the height standard deviation score. And because as I understand it, their trial was conducted in Eastern Europe and other parts of where growth hormone's not available, their height standard deviation scores were closer to minus 4 and our were obviously minus 2.5.
So they have a lot more growing to do, and if we had done our study in Eastern Europe, we probably would have gotten similar height velocity results. But we thought it was appropriate to actually do a study in where we plan to market this product, which is in the United States".
  • Prolor conducted its Ph2 study in Eastern Europe, where patients are severely growth hormone deficient, which is well known to give very high growth rates.
  • Versartis conducted its Phase 2 study in US patients, who are more representative of the normal population.

  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (68,6 KB)

item.title: Shire's "10 x 20" Strategic Plan Presented to Investors [:GastroEnterology:news]
item.description: Shire's "10 x 20" Strategic Plan Presented to Investors [:GastroEnterology:news]
item.content:encoded:
Shire's "10 x 20" Strategic Plan Presented to Investors [:GastroEnterology:news]
PharmaWorld10897 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 24 June 2014 | 13:07

Comment: Shire has hosted an investor call in response to AbbVie's unsolicited offers. Management has reported that $10bn in product sales by 2020 (even before additional M&A and in-licensing) will come from rare diseases, neurosciences and GI franchises. Positions in "attractive" adjacent therapeutic such as ophthalmology and hematology/oncology will be delivering superior outcomes and sustainable growth. Key messages and slides are provided below.
Ambitions of the Plan
Management believes that Shire now has the key elements in place with the right strategy, the right team, enhanced pipeline, and future investment opportunities, to deliver sustainable growth and strong returns on investment.
Leading Positions in Three TAs
Management indicated that " ... The broader GI market is estimated to grow 5% from 2013 through 2020. We have the number-one position in the 5-ASA market. Our substantial commercial expertise, including the number-two ranked GI sales force will enable us to promote additional products, such as liver disease treatments acquired from Lumena to the benefits of patients and shareholders.
Lialda remains the largest product in this franchise, and has a formulation patent that expires in June of 2020. In order for a generic version of Lialda to be commercialized, a generic manufacturer must accomplish the following: Number one, it must successfully address the Orange Book listed formulation patent. Number two, it must get its ANDA approved by the FDA, and number three, if not the first filer, the generic manufacturer must wait until the first filer's exclusivity period has lapsed. As a result, we expect the GI franchise to remain a sizeable portion of our business, with over $1.3 billion in net product sales in 2020 ...).
Adjacent Therapeutic Areas
Potential Upside
  • The acquisition of Lumena, with two moleculed targets in cholestatic liver disease (see PharmaWorld10856: Shire To Acquire Lumena For $260m)
  • The recently-announced Fibrotech transaction (yet to be closed)
  • Future M&A and licensing
Existing Pipeline
Product Acquisitions

About the product

Trial Details

Reference NCT02169817

Recruitment approx. 759

Infants or children with acute community-acquired diarrhea (≥3 liquid or watery stools occurring in a 24-hour period):

  • with less than 48 hours duration
  • aged between 6 months and 5 years of age
  • whose parents or legal guardians have given their written informed consent
  • with clinical indication for ORT per formula of World Health Organization

item.title: Ex-Ipsen Joins Versartis [class:GrowthHormone, :PharmaWorld:sub:People]
item.description: Ex-Ipsen Joins Versartis [class:GrowthHormone, :PharmaWorld:sub:People]
item.content:encoded:
Ex-Ipsen Joins Versartis [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone, :PharmaWorld:sub:People]
Endocrinology7702 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 23 June 2014 | 16:42

Comment: Bert Bakker has been appointed Sr VP, Medical Affairs. With George Bright, MD heading the clinical development, the company expects adding significant value to the regulatory and commercialization plans of VRS-317 (GHD in adults/children).
Bakker's Background
Dr. Bakker was Global Brand Medical Director, Global Medical Affairs at Novartis Oncology where he led and developed the global medical affairs strategy for the use of two somatostatin analogs in neuro-endocrine tumors and oversaw a number of early clinical development studies.
At Ipsen, he was Vice President Medical Affairs and led all activities of the US Endocrine Medical Affairs group which scientifically supported the company's products.
At Genentech, he was a key contributor as Medical Director in the Clinical Development group, where he covered all four stages of drug development, from early clinical development to post marketing studies for products including human growth hormone, anti CD-20 and anti-VEGF.
Education
  • began his medical career as a pediatric endocrinologist and Assistant Professor at the Academic Medical Center, University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
  • received his MD from the Medical School at the University of Leiden, the Netherlands and his PhD in Medical Sciences, from the University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
  • was a Pediatric Endocrinology Fellow at Stanford University and the University of Utrecht, the Netherlands, where he also completed his pediatric residency.
  • Is widely published and while at Genentech was one of the lead authors of the National Cooperative Growth Study Registry. His most cited publication is on the first year growth results with daily growth hormone in pediatric growth hormone deficiency.
Source: Versartis

item.title: Valeant Responds to Allergan's Assertions
item.description: Valeant Responds to Allergan's Assertions
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Responds to Allergan's Assertions
Neurology7625 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 23 June 2014 | 14:18

Comment: Valeant has responded today to what it claims are the many inaccurate and missleading comments made by Allergan in its presentation of the 11th June arguing against the Valeant takeover. Valeant launched a hostile exchange offer for Allergan last Thursday. The offer is scheduled to expire at 5:00 p.m., New York City time, on August 15, 2014, unless the offer is extended
Valeant's Claim About The Inaccuracies has stated the following:-

"Allergan has based most of their analysis on IMS's US prescription data, including products that we do not own and missing many products, geographies and businesses that we do own.

US IMS data will cover less than 30% of Valeant’s business and, for that portion of Valeant’s business IMS covers, the IMS data will not properly collect sales through a numbers of channels (e.g., specialty pharmacy, physician dispensed sales, corporate accounts, and alternative fulfillment).
Given the information being used, the conclusions from Allergan’s analysis are both inaccurate and based on a fraction of our overall business"
The full facts are included in the lengthy Word Document attached.
Source: www.valeant.com

item.title: China's Luye Pharm to Attempt Relisting [:GastroEnterology:news, mkt:China]
item.description: China's Luye Pharm to Attempt Relisting [:GastroEnterology:news, mkt:China]
item.content:encoded:
China's Luye Pharm to Attempt Relisting [:GastroEnterology:news, :PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
PharmaWorld10895 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 23 June 2014 | 09:58

Comment: Luye Pharma Group Ltd. is seeking to raise up to $764M in an IPO in Hong Kong, after it delisted from the Singapore stock exchange in 2012. The company's core products include CMNa® (the only cancer radiotherapy sensitizer in the PRC), Lipusu® (the first Paclitaxel Liposome product which has independent intellectual property in PRC). Of note, the company sells SAILIMAI, a smectite dispersible tablet.
About the IPO
The Chinese drug company, partly owned by 3 Chinese private-equity firms, is selling 999.6 million shares, of which 33.2% are from existing shareholders.
The deal's indicative price range is HK$5.38 to HK$5.92 a share, according to a term sheet seen by The Wall Street Journal Monday, which represents 24.2 times to 26.6 times the company's 2014 forecast earnings.
What is SALIMAI ?
Please see @ http://www.luye.cn/en/products/?fid=1109&id=68
Important Strategic Milestone for the Company
2013, obtained the GMP certificate issued by EU.
2009, passed Chinese GMP accreditation, and obtained Australian TGA certification.
Company Profile
The company launched around 30 products in oncology, cardiovascular, orthopaedics, gastroenterology and central nervous system areas with independent in
These products marketed in a vast majority of chinese provinces, autonomous regions and municipalities, and have encompassed over 8,000 hospitals and exported to a number of foreign countries and regions.
Source: Luye Pharm; WSJ

item.title: Zytiga Is The 10th Top Selling Oncology Drug in 2013 Globally
item.description: Zytiga Is The 10th Top Selling Oncology Drug in 2013 Globally
item.content:encoded:
Zytiga Is The 10th Top Selling Oncology Drug in 2013 Globally
Oncology9797 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 20 June 2014 | 18:04

Comment: According to EvaluatePharma's sales data, J&J's abiraterone (Zytiga) is the 10th top selling oncology drugs in 2013 globally with the sales of $1.70 billion. On the top 10 list includes Mabthera (rituximab), followed by Avastin (bevacizumab), Herceptin (trastuzumab), Gleevec (imatinib), and Neulasta (pegfilgrastim). One thing to note is that Alimta (pemetrexed, Eli Lilly) and Zytiga are the only two drugs from the top 10 list with one indication only (NSCLC, and Prostate, respectively). A quick comparison of the global figures and US figures reveals that the United States accounts for a large portion of global sales.
Table : Global Top 10 Selling Oncology Drugs in 2013. (Source: Evaluate Pharma, Medscape).
The top 5 best sellers in the United States match up closely with the global list. The top-selling cancer drug in the United States in 2013 was also rituximab, with sales of $3.59 billions. That was followed by bevacizumab at $2.78 billion, lenalidomide at $2.49 billion, imatinib at $1.94 billion, and trastuzumab $1.93 billion.
The implications to learn from this include:
  1. US will remain a main strategic market for big phamra organisations. The success in the US market can increase the chance of success globally.
  2. The success in one big indication could ensure the success of the drug, however, the risk could remain high due to fast evolving therapy landscape.
  3. Zytiga is one of the latest launched drug on the top 10 list - this demonstrated a unique clinical profile that revolutionises disease paradigm could guarantee the launching success

item.description: Astellas Funded A Randomised Controlled Study of Degarelix vs GnRH Agonist + Bicalutamide In Japan [dis:Prostate, class:Hormonals]
item.content:encoded:
Astellas Funded A Randomised Controlled Study of Degarelix vs GnRH Agonist + Bicalutamide In Japan [:Oncology:class:Hormonals, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9795 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 20 June 2014 | 17:16

Comment: An exploratory Ph2 trial was registered in 12th June to evaluate degarelix monotherapy and complete androgen blockade (CAB) with GnRH agonist + bicalutamide for metastatic hormone sensitive patients. Japan is the only country and led by Clinical Research Support Center Kyushu.
Trial ID: KYUCOG-1401 (unblended)
Anticipated Start date: 01/July/2014
Expected last follow-up date: 1/March/2019
Primary Objective: safety and efficacy
Primary endpoint: PSA PFS
Secondary endpoint: Time to CAB Treatment failure, OS, PFS in image diagnosis, rPFS, change of PSA, effect on hormone dynamics, change of bone metabolic markers, effect on lipid metabolism, adverse event
Intervention arm: degarelix 240 mg sc at day1 and thereafter every 4 weeks (in the case of PSA recurrence, bicalutamide 80 mg daily is offered)
Comparison arm: leuprorelin or goserelin sc + bicalutamide 80 mg daily
Source: https://upload.umin.ac.jp/cgi-open-bin/ctr/ctr.cgi?function=brows&action=brows&recptno=R000016585&type=summary&language=E

item.title: Key Insights From The MDS Congress Part 1 - New Spasticity Data & Merz Development Programme [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Spasticity, headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:MDS]
item.description: Key Insights From The MDS Congress Part 1 - New Spasticity Data & Merz Development Programme [class:BotulinumToxins, dis:Spasticity, headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:MDS]
item.content:encoded:
Key Insights From The MDS Congress Part 1 - New Spasticity Data & Merz Development Programme [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :Neurology:headline, :PharmaWorld:congress:MDS]
Neurology7624 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 19 June 2014 | 17:28

Comment: The spasticity content of the meeting was minimal compared to other topics but some of the data on the posters is worth noting and importantly soft intelligence was gained on a new development programme that Merz has planned to treat paratonia in Alzheimer's disease. A patent was aparently filed last week with discussions now ongoing about a large phII POC study.
The SPACE Trial
Interim Results Of Merz's SPACE trial were presented in poster form covering the analysis of 648 patients who had completed 1 treatment cycle with incobotulinumtoxin Xeomin (67.1%), onabotulinumtoxin (Botox) (21.3%) or abobotulinumtoxin A (Dysport) (11.6%). The one poster on display focused on patient-rated and investigator -rated assessments of efficacy (PGAE & IGAE respectively) and investigator-rated global assessment of tolerability (IGAT). The other poster from the SPACE study on QOL assessments was only provided in abstract form. We belive SPACE was set up in the UK with the idea of trying to demonstrate a difference in antibody formation between the different toxins. To date no such evidence has been found.
.
Another poster Merz elected to show was that based on two satisfaction surveys undertaken in post-stroke spasticity patients and physicians.
Merz's other key poster display on the spasticity poster day was one focusing on the safety of higher dosages (see below). It appears as though it could be the data that has supported the evaluation of higher doses in the phIII TOWER study, which Merz will utilise for filing purposes alongside the PLUS & PURE data.
The conclusions of this study are of interest in that they potentially point to future studies in patients with more severe hyperactivity conditions.
Outside of the company sponsored posters, interesting data was presented by Dr Kleiner-Fisman on a preliminary small proof of principal study undertaken in 10 patients in a Toronto care home. As shown below, the data demonstrated a positive outcome with regards to careburden in incobotulinumtoxin A patients. Many such patients are in care homes with little focus on this condition which if rectified could ease the burden of care for these patients.
The PI of the study volunteered that Merz was "excited by the data" and as of that day had a filed a patent covering the indication. She also noted that plans are underway to conudct a larger POC study with around 50-100 patients. Discussions are apparently ongoing with the FDA/EMA regarding the study design. Before this starts there needs to be further validation of the careburden scale undertaken as the scale used in the study is an adapted scale to cover both arms.
Dr Kleiner-Fisman noted that Allergan had also expressed interest in this potential indication focusing more on the lower limbs but that there had been some difficulty in defining an appropriate scale for a primary endpoint. Whether it has suceeded and this is the new undisclosed phII indication it has referred to remains to be seen.
She stated that this is potentially a big commercial opportunity for toxin usage bearing in mind demongraphic trends and the huge increase in the no of Alzheimer patients expected over the next 30 years and the careburden associated with that.
Source: MDS Congress

item.title: NICE to Conduct an Oral Appeal Hearing for Ferring's Firmagon [prod:Firmagon, :PharmaWorld:mkt:UK, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing]
item.description: NICE to Conduct an Oral Appeal Hearing for Ferring's Firmagon [prod:Firmagon, :PharmaWorld:mkt:UK, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing]
item.content:encoded:
NICE to Conduct an Oral Appeal Hearing for Ferring's Firmagon [:Oncology:prod:Firmagon, :PharmaWorld:mkt:UK, :PharmaWorld:sub:Pricing]
Oncology9792 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 19 June 2014 | 16:35

Comment: Ferring has confirmed that its drug Firmagon (degarelix) will be the subject of an appeal hearing by NICE on June 25.
Background
See Oncology9390: UK's NICE Backs Ferring's Firmagon for PCa Subgroup.
The original Appraisal Consultation Document (ACD) recommended the use of Firmagon for patients "at risk" of spinal cord compression.
However, the Final Appraisal Determination (FAD) in April restricted the use of Firmagon to prostate cancer patients who present with "signs and symptoms of spinal cord compression", rather than those considered at risk –thereby reducing the number of patients to less than a third of those eligible for treatment per the ACD.

Drug Status in the UK and Scotland

Firmagon has been available in the UK since 2009 but was only reviewed by the NICE as part of a Single Technological Appraisal (STA) in 2014.

Firmagon has been previously reviewed and recommended by the Scottish Medicines Consortium (SMC) in 2011 and by the All Wales Medicine Strategy Group (AWMSG) in 2012 for all patients with prostate cancer.

Whilst the FAD will not change the guidance in Scotland, the FAD guidance would supersede the current recommendation from AWMSG and reduce the approved availability of this treatment for men in Wales.

Comment: At the Jefferies H/C Conference last week, Auspex Pharmaceuticals presented some key data illustrating the PK profile and potential therapeutic application of its novel analogue of tetrabenazine (Xenazine), a drug used quite widely to treat Huntington's disease (sales of $253m in 2013.) SD-809 which is in phIII development for Huntington's disease is a deuterated form of tetrabenazine (Xenazine Lundbeck). The latter has some limitations in terms of its side-effect profile, which hopefully SD-809 will overcome.

item.title: Takeda Ends WW Development of Orteronel for Prostate Cancer [comp:Takeda, dis:Prostate, prod:Orteronel, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
item.description: Takeda Ends WW Development of Orteronel for Prostate Cancer [comp:Takeda, dis:Prostate, prod:Orteronel, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
item.content:encoded:
Takeda Ends WW Development of Orteronel for Prostate Cancer [:Oncology:comp:Takeda, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:prod:Orteronel, :PharmaWorld:sub:Termination]
Oncology9789 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 19 June 2014 | 12:31

Comment: The decision follows the results of 2 Ph3 in mCRPC. The studies found while orteronel+prednisone could extend the time patients lived before their cancer progressed, it did not extend OS in these patients. The suspension of TAK-700 (orteronel) has not come to a surprise, and may have few implications for share price.
After careful consideration of the data from these trials, the company has determined that the drug has not demonstrated a clinical profile sufficient to move forward in mCRPC, given the availability of other therapies.
Background - Drug Failure
On May 14, 2014, Takeda announced results from ELM-PC4, a pivotal, international, double blind, randomized Ph3 trial in men with mCRPC who had not received chemotherapy, which showed that orteronel plus prednisone improved radiographic progression free survival (rPFS) compared to prednisone alone, one of the study’s two primary endpoints, but did not show a statistically significant improvement in the study’s second primary endpoint of OS.
A previously reported Ph3 trial, ELM-PC5, in men with mCRPC that had progressed during or following chemotherapy, was unblinded in 2013 after a pre-specified interim analysis indicated that orteronel plus prednisone would likely not meet the primary endpoint of improved overall survival when compared to the control arm. The interim analysis did show an advantage for orteronel plus prednisone for the secondary endpoint, radiographic progression-free survival over the control arm. There were no significant safety concerns in either study.
  • Feddback from ASCO > Please see Oncology9773: ASCO Highlight 1 - Progress On Development of New Anti-Androgenic Agents.
Source: Takeda

item.title: BOTOX® for Scleroderma-Associated Raynaud's Syndrome [prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, comp:Allergan]
item.description: BOTOX® for Scleroderma-Associated Raynaud's Syndrome [prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, comp:Allergan]
item.content:encoded:
BOTOX® for Scleroderma-Associated Raynaud's Syndrome [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :Neurology:prod:Botox, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Neurology7622 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 18 June 2014 | 16:53

Comment: This randomized, doubled-blinded Ph3 trial has been planned to start in September 2014. The trial will be sponsored by the Johns Hopkins U. in collaboration with Allergan. The primary outcome measure is blood flow to the fingers, as measured by non-invasive laser Doppler imaging.
Raynaud Syndrome
In this syndrome, the fingers of both hands are very sensitive to cold, and they remain cold and blue-colored after exposure to low temperatures. This occurs in nearly all cases of scleroderma, both limited and diffuse. It is caused by abnormal changes in small blood vessels. These changes cause the vessels to narrow, and blood flow is temporarily interrupted, usually in the fingers.
Trial Details
PI: Scott D Lifchez M.D
Reference NCT02165111

Study participants at the first study visit will complete study questionnaires, their hands will be assessed clinically for digital ulceration, and their hands will undergo non-invasive laser Doppler imaging to assess blood flow.

After this initial assessment, the patients will undergo peri-arterial injection of Botulinum toxin A in one hand, and of sterile saline solution (placebo) in the other, in a randomized, blinded manner.

Patient will report the severity of their Raynaud's symptoms weekly over the four month study period. At one month post-injection, the patient will complete study questionnaires, their hands will be assessed clinically for digital ulceration, and their hands will undergo non-invasive laser Doppler imaging.

At four months post-injection, the patient will again complete study questionnaires, their hands will be assessed clinically for digital ulceration, and their hands will undergo non-invasive laser Doppler imaging. In addition, patient will be given the option of one week post-injection visit, at which point the same assessment will be performed.

Recruitment approx 40

  • Aged 18 years and older
  • Diagnosed with scleroderma.
  • Symptoms of Raynaud's syndrome affecting both hands (not necessarily to equal extents)

    • Timelines: completion date Sept 2016 / Dec 2016

      1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (27,9 KB)

item.title: Key Takeaways From Novartis's Investor Update [class:SomatostatinAnalogue, comp:Sandoz, comp:Novartis, dis:Cushing, dis:Acromegaly, dis:MidGutNET]
item.description: Key Takeaways From Novartis's Investor Update [class:SomatostatinAnalogue, comp:Sandoz, comp:Novartis, dis:Cushing, dis:Acromegaly, dis:MidGutNET]
item.content:encoded:
Key Takeaways From Novartis's Investor Update [:Endocrinology:class:SomatostatinAnalogue, :Endocrinology:comp:Novartis, :Endocrinology:comp:Sandoz, :Endocrinology:dis:Acromegaly, :Endocrinology:dis:Cushing, :Endocrinology:dis:MidGutNET]
Endocrinology7697 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 18 June 2014 | 15:40

Comment: Novartis has this week hosted a 2-day investor event focusing on the "New Novartis - A More Focused Company". Whilst the full-day presentation covers all aspects of the businesss and additionally Novartis's approach to resource allocation, the event is unusual in format. Breakout sessions have been organised for smaller groups to facilitate more interactive sessions with management and these have not been broadcast. Amongst the headlines, Sandostatin LAR still features as one of the pharma business's blockbusters both now and as of 2018, whilst Signifor (pasireotide) is described as a potential "best in class agent". No reference is made to the development of the fluid crystal octreotide formulation.
Key slides are highlighted below:=-
Product Orientated Highlights/Key Development Programmes
Novartis's Approach To Resrouce Allocation
Sandoz's Performance
Research & Development

item.title: Valeant Retaliates Regarding Allergan's Misrepresentations [class:BotulinumToxins, comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Valeant Retaliates Regarding Allergan's Misrepresentations [class:BotulinumToxins, comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Retaliates Regarding Allergan's Misrepresentations [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :Neurology:comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7620 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 17 June 2014 | 18:28

Comment: Valeant hosted another business update call today to address the " the erroneous statements and misrepresentations that have been made not only by Allergan, but also by others" and discuss its next steps in its bid to acquire Allergan
Mike Pearson & colleagues focused on the following key points about value creation, next steps and misrepresentations noting that a more exhaustive response will be issued later this week.
Value Creation
Allergan shareholders stand to realize over 90% accretion in stock price from the unaffected stock price prior to announcement, and Valeant shareholders would realize a 45% increase based on the unaffected Valeant stock price prior to announcement.
Goldman Sachs rated Allergan a neutral with a $125 stock target as the analyst at Goldman saw limited near-term pipeline catalysts for the company. The transaction creates enormous value for shareholders, and we believe there is a clear path to allow shareholders to express their views and to complete a transaction.
The Process Going Forward Breaks Down Into Four Steps.
Step one, we expect to launch our exchange offer this week. Pershing Square is concurrently pursuing a process to call special meeting to remove six of Allergan instructors. They filed their solicitation materials with the SEC two weeks ago, and should be in a position to mail up the proxies in the near-term. Pershing has also commenced litigation in order to clarify that actions in connection with requesting that meeting will not trigger the poison pill.
Step two, once Pershing reaches a 25% threshold to call for meeting, they will move forward to solicit support for removable of Directors at the special meeting as soon as possible. We could be in a position to hold a special meeting as early as August if Allergan looks up the date we suggest, but in any event it should be by the end of the year.
At that special meeting, we believe shareholders will support Pershing’s resolution to remove directors. And Pearson will propose independent replacement directors who will act in the interest of Allergan’s shareholders.
Step three, after the special meeting, assuming we have successfully removed our directors, an application will be made to the Delaware Court to order a shareholder meeting to elect replacement directors. Shareholders holding 10% of the organic shares can make that application. So, given Pearson’s ownership, this will only require shareholders only an additional 0.3% to make that application. We think that needs to be able to be held within approximately two months of the court application.
Step four, as a final step, we would expect the new Board of Directors to engage with Valeant, so that the terms of the transaction can be negotiated and obstacles to closing are removed. At that time, this change applicant be completed and the transaction closed.
Product & Revenue Growth Misrepresentations
I am pleased to update all of you that our business is continuing to perform well. I find it very odd that Allergan continues to suggest that our Q2 and in particularly our Q3 results will demonstrate weakness. I am very confident that we will meet expectations in Q2 and the rest of the year.
Organic growth and cash flow will continue to improve over the course of the year. We are now on a path to deliver organic growth of greater than 10%, and I am confident that we will continue to do so for the rest of the year. In short, our business is strong. And I can assure you our operating model is both durable and sustainable.
In the Allergan’s investor presentation dated June 10, 2014, they asserted that Valeant has experienced volume decreases in 11 of its top 15 worldwide pharmaceutical products. First, the products listed in the presentation are not Valeant’s top 15 products by revenue, only six of the products illustrated are in Valeant’s top 15 products. The presentation also claim that most of our products are not growing, but in fact 13 of our top 15 products are growing and 9 of the top 15 are growing by volume, not just price.
Next, the Allergan slide imply that all of the products worldwide, but in fact we only have worldwide rates on 11 of the 15 products listed, in other parts of the world these products are sold by other companies. So it is unclear as to what data Allergan was using.
Finally, Allergan continue to represent that IMS Health is an accurate proxy for both volume and price increases or decreases realized by our products. IMS Health does capture retail and pharmacy sales product information. However, it does not capture revenue that flows through specialty pharmacies, alternate fulfillment channels and physician dispensaries, thus significantly under reporting the true revenue figures for many of our dermatology RX products. We expect to go through each and every one of the other mischaracterizations later this week and will post the facts to our website.
Accounting Misrepresentations That Were Partially Addressed & Will Be Elaborated on Later This Week
Number one; that the assets of acquired companies are written down at the date of acquisition in order to benefit earnings in future periods.
Number two; that normal operating expenses are classified as one-time acquisition related, restructuring or integration expenses.
Number three; the Valeant’s disclosure regarding these expenses are inadequate.
Number four; that existing royalties paid to Galderma were classified as one-time acquisition related cost at the time of Medicis acquisition.
Source: www.valeant.com

item.title: Clovis Oncology Enrolled First Patient To Evaluate Their PARP Inhibitor For Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [class:KinaseInhibitors, news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Clovis Oncology Enrolled First Patient To Evaluate Their PARP Inhibitor For Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [class:KinaseInhibitors, news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Clovis Oncology Enrolled First Patient To Evaluate Their PARP Inhibitor For Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [:Oncology:class:KinaseInhibitors, :Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Oncology9784 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 17 June 2014 | 13:07

Comment: Clovis Oncology announced first patient enrolled in RUCAPANC study to evaluate their PARP inhibitor, rucaparib, as treatment for locally advanced or metastatic pancreatic cancer with BRCA mutation. All the PARP inhibitors in clinical development are being evaluated in ovarian cancer or breast cancer as BRCA mutation is found most prominent in ovarian and breast cancer (Oncology9400: PARP Inhibitors Are Bouncing Back in Oncology).
Dr Susan Domchek (MD, Director of the Basser Research Center for BRCA in the Abramson Cancer Center, and PI of the PUCAPANC study) stated that given pancreatic cancer represents a very difficult-to-treat disease with limited options following disease progression and BRCA mutations do exist in other cancer than ovarian or breast cancer, the rationale to explore rucaparib in the treatment of BRCA mutant driven pancreatic cancer is apparent.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02042378
Study Expected Completion Date: April 2017
Primary Completion Data: August 2016
RUCAPANC Study is a Phase 2, open-label study exploring rucaparib monotherapy in patients with locally advanced or metastatic pancreatic cancer and a known deleterious BRCA mutation (including both germline or somatic) who have progressed on 1-2 prior therapies (i.e. 2L+ patients). The study is expected to enrol up to 100 patients with the primary endpoint of overall response rate, and secondary endpoints including duration of response, PFS, OS, and safety.
Previous data shown that several patients treated with rucaparib showed a few notable responses. Patients with a BRCA2 mutation experienced a robust partial response to rucaparib therapy following failed 1L FOLFIRINOX treatment. The best response observed was with a 52% target lesion shrinkage at cycle 6. In addition, one patient who failed previous 1L gemcitabine based therapy achieved a best response of 43% target lesion shrinkage at cycle 4. PFS for these patients was 7.5 and 5.9 months, respectively. Note that no significant toxicity was observed in these two patients.
These results provided a good rationale to evaluate rucaparib in a larger Ph2 trial. From Clovis Oncology perspective, pursuing rucaparib in metastatic pancreatic cancer could lead to a potential accelerated submission path should the data from this study support it.
Source: http://www.rucapanc.com

item.title: Update on TTY Biopharm's Leuprolide Launch [headline, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, prod:Leuprorelin, :Oncology:news]
item.description: Update on TTY Biopharm's Leuprolide Launch [headline, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, prod:Leuprorelin, :Oncology:news]
item.content:encoded:
Update on TTY Biopharm's Leuprolide Launch [:DKPHybrids:headline, :DKPHybrids:prod:Leuprorelin, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:news]
DKPHybrids244 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 17 June 2014 | 12:19

Comment: TTY aims to develop liposomes containing leuprolide acetate (Leuprolide) for prostate cancer. The company expects to launch in EU and the US in FY15 and FY16 respectively.
Leuprol (leuprorelin) Presence
Presence on the market has been identified in Greece (March 2012, for Leuprol 3.75 mg; September 2012, for Leuprol 11.25 mg).
TTY Biopharm's Global Deployment is Gradually Taking Shape
The company looks to ink new licensing deals with a few multinational pharmaceutical heavyweights this year, further solidifying its foothold in the international landscape in FY15-16.
About TTY Biopharm
Principally engaged in the manufacturing, processing and distribution of drugs.
The Company provides cardiovascular medicines, orthopedics medicines, gastrointestinal medicines, anti-infection medicines and tumor medicines, among others, including oral solutions and pastes.

The Company's products include Lipo-Dox, UFUR, Thado, Oxalip, Asadin, Gemmis, Epicin, Tyxan, Irino, Anazo, Zobonic, Cubicin, Maxtam, Exacin, Metacin and Flusine, among others.

The Company distributes its products primarily in Taiwan and the rest of Asia.
About PharmaEngine
- Development arm of TYY Biopgharm.
- PharmaEngine is a biopharmaceutical company established in Taipei, Taiwan in 2003.
- Business model: “no research, development only”.
- Focus on the development of new drugs for the treatment of cancer and Asian prevalent diseases.

The company licensed the Asian and European rights of PEP02 (nanoliposomal irinotecan, aka MM-398) to Merrimack Pharmaceuticals, Inc., which is in a global ph3 study for the treatment of metastatic pancreatic cancer. In addition, the company licensed the Asia-Pacific rights of PEP503 (crystalline hafnium oxide, aka NBTXR3) from Nanobiotix, Inc. which is in a ph1 clinical trial in France.

Source: TTY Biopharm; PharmaEngine; Fubon Research Report

item.title: Medtronic To Acquire Covidien To Accelerate Its Growth Strategies [:PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, dis:Dystonia, dis:Huntington, dis:Parkinson, dis:Spasticity]
item.description: Medtronic To Acquire Covidien To Accelerate Its Growth Strategies [:PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, dis:Dystonia, dis:Huntington, dis:Parkinson, dis:Spasticity]
item.content:encoded:
Medtronic To Acquire Covidien To Accelerate Its Growth Strategies [:Neurology:dis:Dystonia, :Neurology:dis:Huntington, :Neurology:dis:Parkinson, :Neurology:dis:Spasticity, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7617 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 16 June 2014 | 19:27

Comment: This $42.9bn transaction is all about access to cash, the future of device distribution and Medtronic's structural position according to analysts from Morgan Stanley. It takes advantage of the Irish tax inversion process and creates some synergies for Medtronic in terms of key growth areas namely its Peripheral Vascular Business & Neuroscience strategy (examples of which were evident at the MDS meeting in Stockholm last week)..
This deal is seen as potentially the first of many in the device sector. Structural pressures have it is claimed made it more critical for device companies to use their balance sheets to achiev lower tax rates, drive cost synergies, or return greater cash to shareholders. In addition, large cap companies may need to gain scale and expand geographically to compete more effectively in the future environment. The deal excludes Covidien's pharmaceutical business, which was spun -off in June 2013 to form Mallinckrodt Inc Medtronic already has an agreement in place with Mallinckrodt covering its intrathecal baclofen technology and assets (see Neurology7343: New Deal To Focus On Increased Awareness & Adoption Of Intrathecal Therapies For Pain & Spasticity)

Evidence of Medtronic's neuroscience expansion strategy was seen last week at the MDS meeting in Stockholm, where application of its Deep Brain Stimulation technology was highlighted in terms of its application in Parkinson's disease, Dystonia, Cervical Dystonia, Tourettes and Huntington's Disease. Further details on this will be reported in the MDS Insight Reviews.

The sldies below highlight the key aspects about the deal.
