item.title: Otsuka To Release Extension Trial Data With Tolvaptan In ADPKD at the ERA-EDTA Congress [class:SomatostatinAnalogue, news]
item.description: Otsuka To Release Extension Trial Data With Tolvaptan In ADPKD at the ERA-EDTA Congress [class:SomatostatinAnalogue, news]
item.content:encoded:
Otsuka To Release Extension Trial Data With Tolvaptan In ADPKD at the ERA-EDTA Congress [:Endocrinology:class:SomatostatinAnalogue, :Endocrinology:news]
Endocrinology7689 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 30 May 2014 | 18:06

Comment: Otsuka will release data from an extension trial of its TEMPO 3:4 trial in ADPKD patients this weekend at the European Renal Association Meeting in Amsterdam. The new data demonstrates that continuous tolvaptan treatment confers sustained protection of renal function and that the slope of eGFR decline during treatment remains improved relative to placebo through 5 year sof therapy. Interestingly, the meeting also includes a poster highighting the positive results seen with Lanreotide in a limited number of ADPKD patients.
Abstract details from the two studies are highlighted below
SO016] TOLVAPTAN-TREATMENT OF ADPKD CONFERS PERSISTENT EGFR IMPROVEMENT: RESULTS FROM THE TEMPO 4:4 EXTENSION TRIAL

Vicente E Torres1, Arlene B Chapman2, Olivier Devuyst3, Ronald T Gansevoort4, Eiji Higashihara5, Ronald D Perrone6, John Ouyang7, Susan E Shoaf8, Ann Dandurand9, Robert D Mcquade10, Frank S Czerwiec11
1Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN;2Emory University Medical Center, Atlanta, GA;3University of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland4University Medical Center Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands5Kyorin University School of Medicine, Tokyo, Japan6Tufts-New England Medical Center, Boston, MA;7Otsuka PDC, Rockville, MD;8Otsuka PDC, Rockville, MD;9Otsuka PDC, Princeton, NJ;10Otsuka PDC, Princeton, NJ;11Otsuka PDC, Rockville, MD.
The TEMPO 3:4 trial demmonstrated that the V2-receptor antagonist tolvaptan slowed the increase in total kidney volume by 49% and the deline in kidney function (eGFR) by 26% over 3 years in CKD stage 1-3 ADPKD patients (1). The data below shows the persistence of tolvaptan's effect on eGFR.
Key Findings
Included were data from 976 ADPKD patients. An intra-subject comparison of 304 DT subjects participating in both trials, showed a significant improvement in the eGFR slope after switching from placebo to tolvaptan (from -3.59 to -2.85 mL/min/1.73m2/yr, treatment effect 21%, p=0.048) despite the time difference leading to an increased proportion starting in CKD 3 at TEMPO 4:4' s baseline compared to their own earlier TEMPO 3:4 baseline (37 vs. 15%) (see Figure). Analysis of the separation in eGFR between 512 ET and 212 DT subjects post-treatment withdrawal in TEMPO 3:4 demonstrated sustained protection of renal function during the two year open label extension (p<0.05 for 11/12 time points, see Figure). A third analysis indicated that the 5-year ET slope (N=554) in TEMPO 3:4 and TEMPO 4:4 combined remained significantly different from the DT placebo slope (N=422) in TEMPO 3:4 (-2.92 vs. -3.63 mL/min/1.73m2/yr, treatment effect 20%, p<0.0001)
1Torres VE et. al., N Engl J Med 2012 Dec 20; 367(25):2407-18
SP022] LANREOTIDE IN POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE: A LIGHT AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL?

Serge Treille1, Jean-Marie Bailly2, BenoÃ®t Guillaume3
1CHU de Charleroi, Charleroi, Belgium2CHU de Charleroi, Charleroi, Belgium3CHU de Charleroi, Charleroi, Belgium.
Two different mutations have been identified in ADPKD: a mutation on chromosome 16 (PKD 1), found in 85% of cases, and a mutation on chromosome 4 (PKD 2), which is found in 15% of cases . These mutations result in the production of abnormal polycistin-1 and polycistin-2, respectively, both of which cause changes in the structure of the cilia of renal tubular epithelial cells.
The consequences of these mutations -cellular proliferation, secretion of large volumes of fluid and dedifferentiation - together create a favourable climate for the development of cysts. However, the mechanisms underpinning the formation of cysts remain unclear. One major theory supports a continuum of dedifferentiation, maturation and apoptosis.
Nephromegaly resulting from ADPKD probably plays a key role in the deterioration of kidney function and in maintaining arterial hypertension. The CRISP study showed that in ADPKD patients at high risk of renal failure the kidney volume increased by 6.76 ± 3.78% per year with a parallel decrease in their glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of 5.04 ± 5.86 ml/min/year. The secretion of large volumes of fluid into cysts and changes in the structure and mobility of the cilia of the renal tubular epithelium can lead to nephromegaly. This in turn often causes deterioration of kidney function and arterial hypertension. In recent clinical studies, somatostatin analogues have demonstrated efficacy in isolated polycystic liver disease and, to a lesser extent, in polycystic kidney disease. Since the publication of these clinical studies, several patients have been referred to us for somatostatin analogue treatment.
METHODS: Six patients received lanreotide autogel 120 mg every 4 weeks over 6, 12 or 18 months in our centre. All patients had kidney function with a GFR above 30 ml/min/1.73 m2. No-one had diabetes mellitus or symptomatic gallstones, biliary sludge. The women observed should not be pregnant, lactating or potentially childbearing without any adequate contraception. Those with cancer, major systemic disease or proteinuria greater than 1g/day were not approached. No patients had received previous treatment with a somatostatin analogue, sirolimus or vasopressin antagonist. The potential side effects of the treatment, such as diarrhoea, abdominal pain or pain at the site of injection and potential vesicular lithiasis were discussed and were part of the patients' informed consent.
RESULTS: We observed a mean decrease in volume of 4%, with mild to moderate side effects.
CONCLUSIONS: The results obtained in this limited series seem encouraging, and might offer a new perspective for patients with ADPKD. It is notable that we observed a decrease in volume that persisted over 18 months, though these findings need to be confirmed in larger controlled clinical studies. If these data are confirmed on a larger scale and since lanreotide has an acceptable tolerance profile, this treatment might offer a new strategy for the treatment of ADPKD patients. Is there any light at the end of the tunnel?
Source: 51st ERA-EDTA Congress Amsterdam 31st May - 3rd June

item.title: GSK To Divest 50 Older Products [news]
item.description: GSK To Divest 50 Older Products [news]
item.content:encoded:
GSK To Divest 50 Older Products [:PharmaWorld:news]
PharmaWorld10882 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 30 May 2014 | 10:10

Comment: Sky News reported yesterday that GSK has invited private equity firms to consider bids for a range of 50 older drugs sold in Western markets.
Meanwhile, Reuters is quoting three people with direct knowlege of the matter as the source of the disclosuire.
The news tallies with a statement by CEO Andrew Witty last month that the company could dispose of individual medicines or a broader portfolio of older established products.
GSK is apparently being advised by Lazards on the divestment
What does the older established portfolio (EP) contain?
GSK in its Q1 results this year, highlighted for the first time the sales performance of some of its major "established products", however, there are clearly a number of others that make up the £290m in Other sales. The biggest drugs amonst the grouping are the anti-epileptic Lamictal and the lipid regulator Lovaza. Other well known products are the migraine drug Imigran, the Parkinson's drug Requip and the antidepressant Paxil. The majority of the EP group are facing generic competition and declining sales.
Q114 Sales Figures
Total USA Europe Emerging Markets Japan
£m CER% £m CER% £m CER% £m CER% £m
GSK is believed to be in "no rush" to dispose of the 50 or so older medicines in the division and notably it does plan to retain rights to most of the products in emerging markets, where they form an important part of its business.

item.title: New Tourette's Drug Has A Promising Profile For Pediatric Patients [news]
item.description: New Tourette's Drug Has A Promising Profile For Pediatric Patients [news]
item.content:encoded:
New Tourette's Drug Has A Promising Profile For Pediatric Patients [:Neurology:news]
Neurology7597 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 May 2014 | 16:28

Comment: Psyadon has announced the start of its first phIIb study with its lead product ecopipam in patients with Tourette's Syndrome aged 7-17.
What is Exopipam?
Ecopipam is a first-in class molecules that selectively blocks the action of dopamine at its receptor Ecopiipam blocks dopamine at D1 receptors in contrast to all currently marketed dopamine blockers which block the D2 receptors.
Previous significant results from an open-label study in adults were encouragin enough for the FDA to grant the drug orphan designation to treat Tourette's Syndrome in children ages 7-17.
PhIIb Study Design
Study PSY302 is a multicentre, double-blind, placebo-controlled randomised two-way crossover study designed to assess the efficacy and safety in subjects with Tourett's Syndrome. Patients will take ecopipam 50 or 100mg/day or placebo over an 8-week treatment period comprised of two four-week treatment periods.
Efficacy will be measured using the Yale Global Tic Severity Scale.
Four sites are currently open and enrolling patients with further sites expected to open soon.
ClinicalTrials Identifier NCT02102698 n=30
About Psyadon Pharmaceuticals
Psyadon is a company dedicated to the discovery & development of drugs for serious neurological & psychiatric disorders. The company is focusing its efforts on orphan drug products for diseases with high unmet need.
The US Montgomery County company is a private venture backed organisation.
Source:- www.psyadonrx.com
.

item.title: Good News For Takeda Re UC & Crohn's Drug [dis:IBD, news]
item.description: Good News For Takeda Re UC & Crohn's Drug [dis:IBD, news]
item.content:encoded:
Good News For Takeda Re UC & Crohn's Drug [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :GastroEnterology:news]
GastroEnterology1975 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 29 May 2014 | 15:56

Comment: Takeda announced yesterday that the EMA had granted approval across all its member states and other EU markets for the group novel gut-selective mAb Entyvio (vedolizumab). The drug has been approved to treat patients with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis or moderate to severe Crohn's disease.
This positive news follows the announcment on May 20th that the drug was approvable in the US to treat the same types of patients.
Specific Labelling
Specifically, the EMA and FDA labels position Entyvio for UC and CD patients who have failed, lost response to, or are intolerant to the standard therapies, including corticosteroids, purine analog immunosuppressants, and/or TNF blockers.
Entyvio Has A Differentiated Profile
A key strength of Entyvio is it is the first biologic with gut sepcificity. There are other "me-too" drugs in the pipeline and interestingly Roche's etrolizumab jumped from phIIa to an accelerated phIII development programme earlier in May upon promising phII results.
The drug also appears to offer a good safety profile relative to the TNF blockers, something that is likely to appeal given the costs that can be incurred with managing such side-effect issues.
Source; www.takeda.com

item.title: Hikma Pharmaceuticals Completes Transformation Deal By Acquiring Bedford Labs From Boehringer Ingelheim [sub:Generics, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.description: Hikma Pharmaceuticals Completes Transformation Deal By Acquiring Bedford Labs From Boehringer Ingelheim [sub:Generics, mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.content:encoded:
Hikma Pharmaceuticals Completes Transformation Deal By Acquiring Bedford Labs From Boehringer Ingelheim [:PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:Generics]
PharmaWorld10879 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 28 May 2014 | 18:03

Comment: Hikma's purchase of leading US generic injectable supplier Bedford labs for $300m propells it into the big league in this space, particularly in oncology. As a MENA partner of GP Pharms for its branded leuprolide Lutrate-1M, there could be potential for extension of this partnership into the US.
Hikma has been gradually expanding its partnership with GP Pharm to a broader range of territories (see Oncology9185: Hikma Expands License and Supply Agreement for GP Pharm's Lutrate® in Germany and Portugal). We know that GP Pharm is keen to conclude a US agreement and as such speculation may start to focus on Hikma as a potential partner that now has a much wider geographic footprint and critical mass.

item.title: Valeant Sells All Toxin & Filler Assets To Nestle For $1.4bn in cash [class:BotulinumToxins, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Valeant Sells All Toxin & Filler Assets To Nestle For $1.4bn in cash [class:BotulinumToxins, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Sells All Toxin & Filler Assets To Nestle For $1.4bn in cash [:Neurology:class:BotulinumToxins, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7595 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 28 May 2014 | 17:05

Comment: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has announced that it has entered into an agreement with Nestle S.A. to sell all rights to Restylane, Perlane, Emervel, Sculptra, and Dysport owned or held by Valeant for $1.4 billion in cash (5x sales). Valeant notes that "the agreement dovetails well with its proposed acquisition of Allergan". Of course if this was succesful, this is something the SEC would insist upon for monopolistic reasons.
First Step In The Transaction
Nestle expects to complete its acquisition of Galderma S.A. in July and would then expect to operate the acquired assets through Galderma. The acquisition is attractive for Galderma in enabling it to extend Galderma's aesthetic franchise throughout North America.
The transaction is subject to customary closing conditions, including clearance or early expiration of the waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino (HSR) Act and is not contingent upon a successful transaction with Allergan, Inc.
Commenting on the transaction Michael Pearson Chairman & CEO stated:-
"We are pleased to enter into this transaction. Galderma, under the leadership of Humberto Antunes, CEO of Galderma, not only has a history of building strong businesses, but is firmly committed to the aesthetic dermatology. It is a clear testament to the performance of Valeant's aesthetic commercial team that Galderma recognizes their efforts and the value of the franchise they have developed. Galderma has already built a strong franchise with Restylane, Perlane, Dysport and Emervel outside North America and, with the addition of Sculptra, will now have the ability bring their expertise to the U.S. and Canada."
Source: www.valeant.com

item.title: Valeant Raises Its Offer For Allergan Including The Cash Component [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, headline]
item.description: Valeant Raises Its Offer For Allergan Including The Cash Component [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition, headline]
item.content:encoded:
Valeant Raises Its Offer For Allergan Including The Cash Component [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :Neurology:headline, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7593 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 28 May 2014 | 16:15

Comment: Valeant has raised its offer for Allergan to $166.16 per share, 8.6% higher than its previous bid of $153 and valuing the company at $49.44bn. Its offer includes $58.30 per Allergan share in cash $10 higher than previously. In a webcast following the announcement, Valeant defended its business model by giving clear examples of its growth businesses, the people involved and their depth of experience in big pharma and their commitment to the Valeant business model. CEO Mike Pearson provided an effective rebuttal against most of Allergan's accusations and highlighted the need for a different pharmaceutical model better adapted to the current more challenging competitive environment.
In a very lengthy 176 slide presentation, Valeant provided a very open in-depth perspective of its geographic activities, pipeline activities and acquisition driven growth. It also challenged many of the assumptions made by Allergan in its prior day presentation.
The slides below firstly highlight Valeant's rebuttal to Allergan's accusations, next the adaptation of the Valeant decentralised model to the new industry environment, and then provide insight by geography/business area into some of its key operational growth themes.
Amongst all 10 presentors, there was a common theme on how different the working model feels compared to big pharma from the perspective of accountability, empowerment and the drive for growth. To quote one presentor "It looks scary from the outside but it is exciting from the inside".
How The Industry Needs To Change To Adapt To The Current Paradigm
Business Orientated Presentations
R&D Counter Claims Vs Allergan
Financial & Operational Perspective On The Bausch & Lomb Acquisition
Value Of The Newly Revised Offer

item.title: Debiopharm Extends Commercialisation Of Triptorelin Through Agreement With Orient EuroPharma [news, comp:Debiopharm]
item.description: Debiopharm Extends Commercialisation Of Triptorelin Through Agreement With Orient EuroPharma [news, comp:Debiopharm]
item.content:encoded:
Debiopharm Extends Commercialisation Of Triptorelin Through Agreement With Orient EuroPharma [:Oncology:comp:Debiopharm, :Oncology:news]
Oncology9749 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 27 May 2014 | 18:46

Comment: Orient EuroPharma Co. Ltd a specialty pharmaceutical company focused on marketing and commercialisation of products across Hong Kong, Malaysia, Signapore & Phillipines has announced a distribution agreement for Pamorelin® (triptorelin) with Debiopharm covering South East Asia. Alongside the agreement, the launch of Pamorelin® in Signapore has been announced today.
Commenting on the collaboration Thierry Mauverany Dekegate of the board of Debiopharm Group stated "The collaborations opens up an important new market for our backbone therapy of advanced prostate cancer (locally and metastatic. After successful launch in 74 countreis, we look forard to bringing Pamorelin® to several South East Asian markets.together with Orient Europharma."

Source: debiopharm.com

item.title: Takeda Has Initiated A Ph1 Japanese Trial To Evaluate Relugolix In ADT Treatment Naive Prostate Cancer Patients [comp:Takeda, dis:Prostate, class:Hormonals]
item.description: Takeda Has Initiated A Ph1 Japanese Trial To Evaluate Relugolix In ADT Treatment Naive Prostate Cancer Patients [comp:Takeda, dis:Prostate, class:Hormonals]
item.content:encoded:
Takeda Has Initiated A Ph1 Japanese Trial To Evaluate Relugolix In ADT Treatment Naive Prostate Cancer Patients [:Oncology:class:Hormonals, :Oncology:comp:Takeda, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9747 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 27 May 2014 | 16:35

Comment: Takeda has planned to initiate a Phase 1, open label, multicentre, multiple-dose, placebo-controlled, randomized, single arm assignment study to evaluate the tolerability, safety, PK and efficacy of TAK-385 (relugolix) with androgen deprivation treatment naïve nonmetastatic prostate cancer. This trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT02141659) and approved by Japan Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare. It is currently a Japan only trial.
The study consists of two parts - Part A is a dose escalation study and Part B will be an expansion phase. A total of 30 patients are planned for enrolment in the study.
Expected Completion Date: 1 July 2017 (Duration planned - 3 years 2 months)
Primary Outcome Measures include:
  • Does-limiting toxicity(DLT): Does resing phase - Up to 48 weeks
  • Percentage of participants with markedly abnormal advers events - Up to 48 weeks
  • An Adverse Event (AE) is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a clinical investigation participant administered a drug
  • DLT, adverse events, clinical laboratory tests, vital signs, and 12-lead ECGs
Secondary Outcome Measures include:
  • Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) - Up to 48 weeks
  • Plasma concentration of TAK-385 - Up to 48 weeks
  • Serum testosterone concentration - Up to 48 weeks

item.title: Another Antibody-Drug Conjugate Candidate - ADCT-401 - Targeting Prostate Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA) Is Progressed Into Clinical Trial For Prostate Cancer [comp:AstraZeneca, dis:Prostate]
item.description: Another Antibody-Drug Conjugate Candidate - ADCT-401 - Targeting Prostate Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA) Is Progressed Into Clinical Trial For Prostate Cancer [comp:AstraZeneca, dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
Another Antibody-Drug Conjugate Candidate - ADCT-401 - Targeting Prostate Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA) Is Progressed Into Clinical Trial For Prostate Cancer [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9746 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 27 May 2014 | 16:01

Comment: Medimmune has entered into a collaboration agreement with ADC Therapeutics to jointly develop two ADC Development Programmes in Oct 2003. ADC Therapeutics, an oncology drug development company that specializes in the development of proprietary Antibody Drug Conjugates (ADCs) targeting major cancers, announced that it has selected its first IND candidate under its joint development agreement with MedImmune, the global biologics research and development arm of AstraZeneca.

Earlier this year, Progenics Pharmaceuticals presented positive data from their Ph2 trial of PSMA ADC in post-docetaxel setting (Oncology9641: Progenics Pharmaceuticals Announces the Completion of Enrolment of Chemotherapy Naive Cohort in Phase II Trial of PSMA Antibody Drug Conjugate). ADC Therapeutics and Medimmune announced that their first IND, ADCT-401, is entering clinical trial. ADCT-401 targets Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA) a cell-surface antigen specifically expressed by prostate cancer cells based on encouraging pre-clinical data in a number of in vivo models for prostate cancer. This will be second ADC targeting PSMA entering clinical development in CRPC. Note that Roche is also investigating ADC technology in prostate cancer, with a different target strategy - STEAP which is a six-transmembrane epithelial antigen of the prostate and it is overexpressed in prostate cancer.
ADCT-401 comprises an anti-PSMA monoclonal antibody coupled with a pyrrolobenzodiazepine (PBD) warhead using a proprietary linker licensed from London-based Spirogen (Oncology8224:AstraZeneca to Bolster its Portfolio with a New Type of Cancer Therapy), a wholly owned subsidiary of MedImmune. Initial clinical studies will focus on hormone-refractory prostate cancer and an IND filing is anticipated in 2015. This will be ADCT’s second ADC program into the clinic from its pipeline of eleven programs with an IND filing expected in the first of these programs by the end of this year.

item.dc:creator: jew60237

item.title: Allergan Fights Back In Advance Of A Potentially Raised Offer From Valeant [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.description: Allergan Fights Back In Advance Of A Potentially Raised Offer From Valeant [comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
item.content:encoded:
Allergan Fights Back In Advance Of A Potentially Raised Offer From Valeant [:Neurology:comp:Allergan, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
Neurology7589 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 27 May 2014 | 15:21

Comment: Allergan has just filed a presentation with the SEC, ahead of an Investor meeting it has scheduled tomorrow. Essentially it has retained two nationally-recognized financial consultants and forensic accountants, Alvarez & Marsal and FTI Consulting, to evaluate certain concerns about the inherent value of Valeant's business model and stock. The presentation fully outlines the risks.
Background
Apparently, Allergan has taken this action in response to feedback from numerous Allergan stockholders and analysts. Allergan and its legal and financial advisors carefully analyzed publicly available data on Valeant and the opaque nature of Valeant's pro-forma driven financial reporting.
The presentation raises a number of important issues about Valeant's business model and stock value that Allergan's stockholders need to be aware of.
  • What is Valeant's real organic growth?
  • How have its two largest acquisitions performed under Valeant's ownership?
  • Does Valeant have any experience promoting products of Allergan's scale?
  • How stable is Valeant's management team?
  • Can Valeant cut $2.7bn of Allergan's expenses without disrupting the performance of the business?
  • What is the relative distribution strength of Allergan vs Valeant in the important emerging markets?
  • Is Valeant's low tax rate sustainable?
  • Are Valeant's accounting practices clearly consistent with others in the industry?
  • Is a business model centered on serial acquisitions and a cost cutting strategy sustainable?
Several of the key slides from the presentation are highlighted below with the full presentation attached.
Source: www.allergan.com

item.title: New Information On Allergan's Pipeline Including Medy-Tox's BTX-A [headline, prod:Botox, sub:Aesthetics]
item.description: New Information On Allergan's Pipeline Including Medy-Tox's BTX-A [headline, prod:Botox, sub:Aesthetics]
item.content:encoded:
New Information On Allergan's Pipeline Including Medy-Tox's BTX-A [:Neurology:headline, :Neurology:prod:Botox, :Neurology:sub:Aesthetics]
Neurology7585 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 27 May 2014 | 14:24

Comment: Subsequent to Allergan's Business Update Call, it has become apparent that Allergan shared a different version of its presentation with some of the buy-side analysts, which included more material on its early stage pipeline. Interestingly, the in-licensed Medytox formulation, assumed to be the liquid formulation, is cited as in PhII confirmatory development both for aesthetics and therapeutics (no trials are listed in ClinicalTrials.gov).
Other new indications or programmes are highlighted in red and for toxins include:-
Aesthetic
  • PhIII Forehead lines
  • PhII Masseter indication (see Neurology7307: Allergan to Test BOTOX® for Bilateral Masseter Muscle Hypertrophy (MMH))

Therapeutic
  • PhII New indication (unspecified)
  • Pre-clinical AGN-1867 Migraine
  • Pre-clinical BTX-X potential for higher dose and or longer duration going into PhI. Whilst not newly highlighted the specificity about its status is new.
Allergan is due to provide a further update to investors tomorrow presumably in response to a revised offer from Valeant.
Source: Leerink Analyst Report May 20th

Comments
It is interesting to see that the development in Masseter is confirmed in Allergan.
Anne-Gaelle BENOIT / Neurology7592 / 28 May 2014 / 09:41:13 o'clock CEST

item.title: Pfizer Abandons Bid For AstraZeneca [sub:Acquisition, news]
item.description: Pfizer Abandons Bid For AstraZeneca [sub:Acquisition, news]
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer Abandons Bid For AstraZeneca [:PharmaWorld:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:Acquisition]
PharmaWorld10878 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 27 May 2014 | 10:21

Comment: Late yesterday, Pfizer finally abandoned its pursuit of AstraZeneca stating that it "did not intend to make a further offer" after AZ's board rejected its most recent offer which it felt was compelling and attractively valued AZ's business prospects.
Limitations Now In Place
Pfizer cannot propose another offer for the company now for the next six months under UK takeover regulations.
AstraZeneca's Perspective
Following the release of Pfizer's statement, AstraZeneca chairman Leif Johansson said "we welcome the opportunity to continue building on the momentum we have already demonstrated as an independent company." He further highlighted AstraZeneca's "attractive growth prospects and a rapidly progressing pipeline," adding that "in the coming months, we anticipate positive news flow across our core therapeutic areas, which underpins our confidence in the long-term prospects of the business."
Implications For AZ
AstraZeneca will now be under a lot of pressure to deliver on its pipeline hopes having predicted that its 71 drugs in development could generate peak sales of as much as $63bn. This may, it is predicted, lead to an acceleration of partnerships designed to fast-track some of these programmes.
Source: Firstword

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Negative Opinion from the CHMP for AB Science's Masitinib in Pancreatic Cancer
item.description: Negative Opinion from the CHMP for AB Science's Masitinib in Pancreatic Cancer
item.content:encoded:
Negative Opinion from the CHMP for AB Science's Masitinib in Pancreatic Cancer
Oncology9745 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 23 May 2014 | 15:03

Comment: CHMP of the European Medicine Agency has adopted a negative opinion on the conditional marketing authorization for Masiviera (Masitinib mesylate) for the first line treatment of non resectable locally advanced or metastat ic pancreatic cancer. This decision is on the appeal filed by the cmpany following a previous negative opinion adopted by the CHMP in January 2014.
Rationale for the Decision

The evidences presented in the pain and in the genetic subgroups were very promising, but the benefit was not sufficiently demonstrated since the data were derived from subgroup analysis.

Company's Next Actions

AB Science intends to file for marketing authorization with data from the phase 3 confirmatory
study to be initiated in the first line treatment of non resectable locally advanced or metastatic pancreatic
cancer.

Source: AB Sciences

item.title: BIND Therapeutics-Key Takeaways From The UCB Conference Highlighting The Enhanced Therapeutic Profile That Accurin Nanotechnology Can Confer [:PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery, dis:Prostate, class:Cytotoxics]
item.description: BIND Therapeutics-Key Takeaways From The UCB Conference Highlighting The Enhanced Therapeutic Profile That Accurin Nanotechnology Can Confer [:PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery, dis:Prostate, class:Cytotoxics]
item.content:encoded:
BIND Therapeutics-Key Takeaways From The UCB Conference Highlighting The Enhanced Therapeutic Profile That Accurin Nanotechnology Can Confer [:Oncology:class:Cytotoxics, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :PharmaWorld:sub:DrugDelivery]
Oncology9740 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 22 May 2014 | 18:42

Comment: BIND Therapeutics focused not only on the Accurin technology and how its application results in therapeutics with improved profiles but also some of the key data that has started to emerge with its drug BIND-014 and AstraZeneca's new aurora kinase inhibitor, ongoing development of which had been limited by the drug's low therapeutic index. This has now been resolved and the efficacy and safety profile of the drug significantly enhanced. Similarly, the docetaxel profile that could emerge in terms of BIND-014's mCRPC activity could be quite different to the drug's current profile.
Management explained how small molecules traffic throughout the body easily but are often non-specific in terms of their targeting, whilst Accurin technology can confer tissue specificity typically only see with a biologic.
.
Accurins start with a polymeric backbone and then have a PEG coating to form a hydration shell which is essentially ignored by the body's immune system. On the surface are placed targeting ligands e.g. peptides aptamers and then the therapeutic payload is contained within.
Accurins use two forms of targeting, biophysical and ligand targeted binding. By comparison with ADCs which use a toxin payload of low single digit numbers and require cellualar uptake, Accurin nanoparticles don't require cellular uptake and can deliver high multiples of payload. They can also work with a broad range of payloads and ligands and are significantly less costly to produce.
BIND's first product BIND-014 targets PSMA and inside contains a docetaxel payload. Since
BIN-014 targetst PSMA and drug inside is docetaxel. As the outer shell doesn't acutally bind to docetaxel, registration of such a product can take advantage of the 505 B 2 regulatory route as the particles are essentially viewed as excipients to docetaxel.
BIND has completed two phase I studies the results of which are shown below
These findings have helped to guide the choice of the next phII study the group plans to undertake in bladder, choliangocarcinoma, NET and cervical cancer.
However, initial studies are being undertaken in NSCL and mCRPC. Topline results of which will be known by the year-end.
Commenting on the profile of BIND-014 vs docetaxel, it was noted that docetaxel is quickly excreted. It very quickly reaches peak concn in the tumours and then quickly dissapates.
BIND-014 by contrast shows a slow sustained release over a longer time period and results in a prolonged response giving a 5-7 fold higher concentration resulting in a higher AUC
In a prostate Xenograft model BIND has shown that BIND-014 is active one month after administration and no re-growth is seen, whereas re-growth occurs almost immediately you stop docetaxel therapy.
The focus of the presentation then turned to the 3 partnerships BIND has announced, all involving situations where the partner has taken the product into clinic seen a promising efficacy signal but a low therapeutic index and has curtailed ongoing development but then sought assistance from BIND to try and overcome this.
Amgen and Pfiser have not disclosed the drug involved but AZ has and highlighted the results it has seen at the recent AACR meeting with its aurora kinaase inhibitor AZD1152.
As a class all aruora kinase inhibitors are associated with a high level of bone marrow toxicity
souce: www.bind.com

item.title: re: Nymox Reports Top-Line Results From Localised Prostate Cancer Study
item.description: re: Nymox Reports Top-Line Results From Localised Prostate Cancer Study
item.content:encoded:
re: Nymox Reports Top-Line Results From Localised Prostate Cancer Study
Oncology9739 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 22 May 2014 | 17:37

Nymox Reports Top-Line Results From Localised Prostate Cancer Study [:Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:news]
Comment Top-line results from the Nymox's 146 patient NX03-0040 Phase 2 U.S. prostate cancer study indicate an overall benefit in terms of reduced progression in patients with low grade localized (T1c) prostate cancer treated with a single injection of NX-1207. However, results have been overshadowed because of the high percentage of false negative biopsies in the untreated group which meant that the study overall was unable to achieve its main goal of showing a higher number of patients with undetectable PCa after 45 days of treatment. Nymox is actively pursuing potential partnerships with pharmaceutical companies for US and global marketing agreements for this indication.  ...
Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK / Oncology9670 / 01 May 2014 / 13:05:06 o'clock CEST
Comment: Nymox Pharmaceutical Corporation reported new positive data confirming the advantageous side effect profile of the Company's lead compound NX-1207. Results from the Brief Male Sexual Function Questionnaire (BMSF) in the Company's recently completed NX03-0040 trial of NX-1207 2.5 mg and 15 mg for the treatment of low grade localized prostate cancer indicate that targeted treatment with NX-1207 at either dose had no significant effect on reported sexual function score post-treatment. Current approved drugs for prostate enlargement (BPH or benign prostatic hyperplasia) can produce significant sexual side effects such as impotence, decreased libido, ejaculation disorders, and male breast enlargement. NX-1207 has been shown not to have these sexual drawbacks in results to date. As well, certain of the approved BPH drugs, including the combination drug therapies, are also associated with an increased risk of high-grade prostate cancer. By contrast, the area of the prostate targeted with NX-1207 treatment showed less prostate cancer progression with less radiation and surgery due to cancer progression as compared to controls in the recent NX03-0040 trial.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9739 / 22 May 2014 / 17:37:49 o'clock CEST

Comments
Comment: Nymox Pharmaceutical Corporation announced on 10th Sept their new positive outcome results for their prostate cancer Ph2 US trial. The new findings extend the previously reported study results which showed that patients with NX-1207 treatment after 2 months had less clinical progression and significantly less Gleason grade progression, lower average PSA levels, lower numbers of biopsy cores showing greater malignancy, and lower total volume of more malignant cancer compared to controls. NX-1207 is now in Phase 3 development in the US and Europe for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
146 patients were enrolled in the NX03-0040 Phase 2 U.S. trial and either randomized to one of two doses of NX-1207 (2.5 mg or 15 mg) or to active surveillance. The drug was injected into the area of the prostate where the cancer was detected and repeat biopsies were then performed on all patients, drug treated and controls. The patients in the active surveillance group in the study who were eligible could elect crossover drug treatment after their first follow-up rebiopsy. Follow-up studies are being conducted of all consenting patients in the study to continue to monitor outcome and safety data.
To date, NX-1207 has had an excellent safety profile as both a treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and localized low-risk prostate cancer. In the current trial, a new high dose of drug (15 mg) was safely used without drug-related adverse effects. NX-1207 has shown safety in repeat injection studies (NX02-0020 and NX02-0022). The drug does not lead to immune responses such as antibody formation which can cause significant drug toxicity and/or limit usage to single treatments due to drug neutralizing effects.
Clinical outcomes were determined at 8 months from the initial treatments. A controlled comparison was conducted of patients who required and received radiation and surgery treatments for their cancer based on blinded post-treatment upgraded evaluations of their pre-treatment initially positive lower grade cancers. The study found after 8 months for NX-1207 single-injection treated patients that there was a statistically significant reduction compared to controls of more than 75% (p=.002) in the proportion of patients who had upgraded blinded biopsy and laboratory results and went on to require and receive radiation therapy and/or surgery. The new results also indicated that the NX-1207 treated patients had 67% less progression to surgery and/or radiotherapy compared to controls (p=.008) for all reasons (including elective surgery and/or radiotherapy with no biopsy or laboratory upgrades).
Jenny Wu / Oncology9941 / 11 September 2014 / 11:14:18 o'clock CEST

item.title: SOTIO Announced First Patient Enrolled in its Ph3 VIABLE Study for DCVAC/PCa in Combination With Chemotherapy [dis:Prostate, class:Vaccines]
item.description: SOTIO Announced First Patient Enrolled in its Ph3 VIABLE Study for DCVAC/PCa in Combination With Chemotherapy [dis:Prostate, class:Vaccines]
item.content:encoded:
SOTIO Announced First Patient Enrolled in its Ph3 VIABLE Study for DCVAC/PCa in Combination With Chemotherapy [:Oncology:class:Vaccines, :Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9737 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 22 May 2014 | 17:34

Comment: DCVAC/PC is an active cellular immunotherapy treatment for prostate cancer patients. VIABLE is a randomized, double blind, multicenter, parallel-group, Phase III study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of DCVAC/PCa as an add-on therapy to 1st line standard of care chemotherapy in men with metastatic Castration Resistant Prostate Cancer (mCRPC), which is based on overall survival (OS) in mCRPC patients treated with DCVAC/PCa versus placebo with standard of care chemotherapy.
SP005 VIABLE (Eudra CT: 2012-002814-38; IND: 015255): A Randomized, Double Blind, Multicenter, Parallel-Group, Phase III Study to Evaluate Efficacy and Safety of DCVAC/PCa Versus Placebo in Men with Metastatic Castration Resistant Prostate Cancer Eligible for 1st Line Chemotherapy.
The first patient was enrolled into the study in Hungarian Army Medical Center (Magyar Honvédség Egészségügyi Központ), Department of Oncology. The VIABLE study will recruit patients through cooperation with medical centers in 20 countries: Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Serbia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Turkey, the United Kingdom and the United States. The initiations of individual countries have already started and the first patients will be enrolled in the coming weeks. SOTIO’s aim is to enroll a total of about 1,170 prostate cancer patients in the study from Europe, Russia and the United States.
It is a combined chemo-immunotherapy clinical trial that explores the combination of standard care chemotherapy and dendritic cell based immunotherapy treatment with DCVAC/PCa. Dendritic cells are separated from patients’ monocytes and introduced to a prostate cancer cell line killed by high hydrostatic pressure. While the chemotherapy treatment decreases tumor cell load, the cancer immunotherapy treatment with DCVAC/PCa may induce an immune response directed against multiple tumor antigens and therefore control the growth of tumor cells. The VIABLE study will thus test the hypothesis that the combination of two treatment modalities synergizes and leads to the prolonged survival of treated patients.”
SOTIO is the first company from the CEE region to initiate a Phase III clinical trial in the area of cellular immunotherapy. This milestone is due to all the hard work and the cooperation of Charles University and University Hospital in Motol in Prague as well as many years of research by a dedicated group of scientists and we are now focused on delivering the results of the trial in our efforts to further the treatment of prostate cancer on a global scale.”
Source: http://www.sotio.com/, www.viablestudy.com

Comments
Comment: Ph3 VIABLE study for DCVAC/PCa (a cellular immunotherapy) is enrolling the first US patient and the total target recruitment in US is 250 patients. (Source: Satio Company Press Release)
Jenny Wu / Oncology10117 / 20 November 2014 / 10:46:06 o'clock CET

item.title: FTIM Study of AZD5312 for Patients with Androgen Receptor Tumours [comp:AstraZeneca, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.description: FTIM Study of AZD5312 for Patients with Androgen Receptor Tumours [comp:AstraZeneca, dis:Prostate, headline]
item.content:encoded:
FTIM Study of AZD5312 for Patients with Androgen Receptor Tumours [:Oncology:comp:AstraZeneca, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:headline]
Oncology9736 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 22 May 2014 | 17:06

Comment: AZD5312 is an antisense drug designed to treat patients with prostate cancer by inhibiting the production of the androgen receptor (AR). Because the drug can inhibit the production of all known forms of AR, including variants of the AR gene, AstraZeneca believes that the drug could be an effective treatment for all stages of prostate cancer, including in patients resistant to current therapies that largely involve countering androgens by blocking ARs or removing circulating androgens.
Trial Design
Objective: Ph1study to determine the Maximum Tolerated Dose, Recommended Ph2 dose, safety, tolerability and Pharmacokinetics of AZD5312
Recruitment: Approximately 90 patients
Timelines
Start date: May 2014 - Completion dates: May 2016
Location: USA; UK
Source: NCT02144051
Strategic Alliance with Isis Pharm
In 2012, Isis entered into a collaboration with AstraZeneca to discover and develop antisense drugs to treat cancer.
On June 3, 2013 Isis announced that AstraZeneca has added a second development candidate, ISIS-ARRx (AZD5312), to its collaboration with Isis.

the drug designed to treat patients with prostate cancer by inhibiting the production of the androgen receptor (AR). AstraZeneca is planning to develop ISIS-ARRx broadly to treat patients under a variety of settings during the course of prostate cancer treatment, including both as a single agent and in combination therapy.

Source: AstraZeneca; Isis Pharm.

item.title: Servier And Novartis Ink Global Oncology Deal [comp:Novartis, news]
item.description: Servier And Novartis Ink Global Oncology Deal [comp:Novartis, news]
item.content:encoded:
Servier And Novartis Ink Global Oncology Deal [:Oncology:comp:Novartis, :Oncology:news]
Oncology9734 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 22 May 2014 | 10:56

Comment: The objective of the strategic collaborative agreement is to develop and commercialize a series of novel drugs candidates issued from the Servier research programs partnered with Vernalis in oncology which are targeting the apoptosis regulation pathways. The collaboration covers the worldwide co-development of BCL-2 selective inhibitor candidates that are now entering into clinical development.
Terms of the Transaction
- Financial terms: not disclosed
- Servier will remain responsible for research activities and will share responsibilities with Novartis to conduct a clinical development program aimed at moving swiftly to a first indication for the benefit of patients.
- Commercialization rights to products arising from the collaboration will be allocated between the parties on a geographic basis.
Collaboration Vernalis / Servier
Vernalis first collaboration with Servier started in 2007.
The most advanced programme from this collaboration entered pre-clinical testing in September 2012.Vernalis will continue to receive fees as well as research and clinical milestones on these collaboration programmes as they progress, together with a potential share in the downstream success of these programmes through royalties.
Source: Vernalis; Servier

item.title: Altor Biosciences to Evaluate Drug Candidate for BCG-naive NMIB Cancer
item.description: Altor Biosciences to Evaluate Drug Candidate for BCG-naive NMIB Cancer
item.content:encoded:
Altor Biosciences to Evaluate Drug Candidate for BCG-naive NMIB Cancer
Oncology9733 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 21 May 2014 | 18:04

Comment: As a leading developer of an IL-15-based platform, Altor has created the proprietary IL-15 superagonist complex, ALT-803, with increased ability to bind IL-2Rβγ and enhanced immunostimulatory activity compared to IL-15. For the purpose of this Ph1b/2 trial, BCG and ALT-803 will be mixed together (with saline) and administered via intravesical instillation.
Trial Details

The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety, identify the Maximum Tolerated Dose (MTD) of ALT-803 and determine the Recommended Dose (RD) level of ALT-803 combined with BCG in patients who have BCG-naive nonmuscle invasive bladder cancer. The anti-tumor activity of BCG+ALT-803 will also be assessed. In addition, the study will characterize the molecular, immunogenicity and pharmacokinetic profile of BCG+ALT-803.

Protocol The study includes a dose escalation phase (Ph1b) and a dose expansion phase (Ph2). The dose escalation phase is concluded when the MTD is determined. A dose level (RD) will be designated for the expansion phase of the study. The expansion phase consists of a noncomparative randomized design of patients receiving ALT-803 at the RD level in combination with BCG or BCG alone

Recruitment: 18

Timelines Start date May 2014 - Completion date: May 2018 / August 2018

Source: NCT02138734

Ongoing Clinical Programs

Altor chose to focus the first Phase I/II clinical trial on metastatic melanoma based upon a solid foundation in this disease for various immunotherapies in preclinical and clinical settings. A Phase I/II trial is currently underway to evaluate ALT-803 in patients with metastatic melanoma.

item.title: New Ultrasound Contrast Agent in the Assessment of Prostate Cancer [dis:Prostate, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, sub:Diagnostic]
item.description: New Ultrasound Contrast Agent in the Assessment of Prostate Cancer [dis:Prostate, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, sub:Diagnostic]
item.content:encoded:
New Ultrasound Contrast Agent in the Assessment of Prostate Cancer [:Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:sub:Diagnostic, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Oncology9732 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 21 May 2014 | 17:49

Comment: Bracco Diagnostics, the sponsor of the trial is the U.S.-based subsidiary of Bracco Imaging SpA. The company develops and markets imaging agents for use in X-ray/Computed Tomography (CT), Nuclear Medicine and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in the U.S. and Canada. The Ph1/2 pilot trial will evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of BR55 targeting for prostate cancer nodules with Gleason score greater than or equal to 7. PE to measure the sensitivity and specificity of BR55.
Trial Details
Principal Investigator: Juergen Willmann M.D Stanford U.
Recruitment: approx 21
  • Male, age between 50-70 years old
  • Increased PSA level >4 ng/mL
  • Known prostate cancer
  • Scheduled for prostatectomy not earlier than 3 days and not later than 30 days following BR55 administration (with the exception of training cases where this requirement is not applicable)
Timelines: start planned next month Completion date in February 2015
Location: USA
Source: NCT02142608
Bracco's R&D Strategy
Bracco Imaging is focusing its efforts in some specific R&D areas:
  • Cardiovascular disease: identification of patients at risk due to the presence of unstable plaque and ability to monitor response to treatment;
  • Oncology: targeted agents to visualize and characterize angiogenesis in order to identify and monitor patients responding to novel anti-angiogenic therapies;
  • Degenerative diseases: agents able to visualize and characterize disease progression to enable the doctor to monitor response to treatment

item.title: re: Progress With New Prostate Cancer Tests
item.description: re: Progress With New Prostate Cancer Tests
item.content:encoded:
re: Progress With New Prostate Cancer Tests
Oncology9731 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 21 May 2014 | 17:25

Progress With New Prostate Cancer Tests 
Comment: New data from Myriad's Prolaris test demonstrates that the test can predict the risk of cancer recccurence following radical prostatectomy. Meanwhile, scientists at Cambridge Universtiy have demonstrated that a test assessing the level of a protein NAALADL2 can correctly distinguish aggressive prostate tumours.  ...
Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK / Oncology9476 / 24 February 2014 / 18:33:52 o'clock CET
Commmet: Myriad Genetics Inc presneted new data from a clinical validation study of Prolaris at the AUA 2014 in Orlando on 20th May 2014. Tis study is the largest validation study to date of any gene based prognostic test in patients with prostate cancer who were diagnosed by needle biopsy. Prolaris test can accurately differentiate newly diagnosed patients who were likely to die from prostate cancer within 10 years from thos with lower risk disease. This is thought to be a much stronger indicator of clinical outcomes than Gleason score or PSA. A quote from the study investigator " currently, with standard clinical tools like Gleason Score or PSA, we can't adequately define prognosis. The Prolaris test provides useful new information and is highly prognostic or disease specific death among men being conservatively treated."
The objective of the study was to validate the test score in 761 conservatively managed prostate cancer pateints diagnosed by needle biopsy. The primary end point was prostate cancer death and the median follow up time was 9.5 years. The resutls showed that for each one unit increase in the PRolaris score, patients had approximately double the risk of dying from prostate cancer.In the second study featured in AUA, 230 men who had pathologic Gleason Scores of either 3+4 or 4+3 were examined. The Prolaris test signifcanlty outperformed the current practice of upgrading to Gleaseon 3+4 or 43 in predicting which patients would experience biochemical recurrence after a radical prostatectomy. This finding should lead to improved initial decisions on the most effective treatment for each patient based on the patient's own riskk of disease progression.
Jenny Wu / Oncology9731 / 21 May 2014 / 17:25:26 o'clock CEST

item.title: New AUA CRPC Therapeutic Guidelines [dis:Prostate]
item.description: New AUA CRPC Therapeutic Guidelines [dis:Prostate]
item.content:encoded:
New AUA CRPC Therapeutic Guidelines [:Oncology:dis:Prostate]
Oncology9730 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 21 May 2014 | 15:45

Commnet: The American Urological Association (AUA) as part of its recent meeting has announced three updates to the organization’s guideline on the management of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC). All the modifications are specific to the potential uses of radium-223 in men with late stage metastatic disease.
The three updates are as follows:
  • Clinicians should offer radium-223 to patients with symptomatic, metastatic CRPC (mCRPC) with good performance status and no prior docetaxel chemotherapy with symptomatic bone metastases and without known visceral disease (Standard; Evidence Level Grade B).
  • Clinicians may offer radium-223 to patients with symptomatic mCRPC with poor performance status and no prior docetaxel chemotherapy with symptomatic bone metastases and without known visceral disease in select casts, specifically when the performance status is directly related to symptoms related to bone metastases (Expert Opinion).
  • Clinicians should offer radium-223 to patients with good performance status who received prior docetaxel chemotherapy with symptomatic bone metastases and without known visceral disease (Standard; Evidence Level Grade B).

item.title: Celgene and ADDi Ink License Agreement for Nanotechnology-Based Approach for Bladder Cancer [dis:Bladder, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, news]
item.description: Celgene and ADDi Ink License Agreement for Nanotechnology-Based Approach for Bladder Cancer [dis:Bladder, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial, news]
item.content:encoded:
Celgene and ADDi Ink License Agreement for Nanotechnology-Based Approach for Bladder Cancer [:Oncology:dis:Bladder, :Oncology:news, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
Oncology9729 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 21 May 2014 | 11:41

Comment: AADi, a clinical stage biopharma company focused on diseases uniquely suited for nanotechnology approaches, has in-licensed ABI-009 from Celgene. The drug candidate is the nanoparticle albumin-bound (nab®) version of the mTOR inhibitor sirolimus or rapamycin. AADi is currently raising capital in an initial round and plans to seek additional financing to fund its research programs through the end of ph 2 clinical studies.
Ongoing Trial in NMIBC
status: enrollment of the first three patients in the new multi-center phase 1/2 clinical trial for the treatment of non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.
collaboration: trial is funded in-part through a Fast-Track STTR grant awarded to AADi from the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health.
Columbia University, with its expertise in bladder cancer, is a consortium partner for AADi as part of the awarded grant and will be the primary clinical trial site. Vanderbilt University will also be involved in the clinical trial.
rationale: strong scientific and biological rationale for the use of ABI-009 in bladder cancer where the mTOR activation plays a key role in progression of the disease.
Terms of the Transaction
As part of the licensing agreement, AADi plans to develop ABI-009 initially in oncology and cardiovascular indications. A phase 1 trial for ABI-009 has been completed in patients with advanced non-hematologic malignancies in which the drug was well tolerated with evidence of activity in heavily pretreated patients.
Celgene has the option to reacquire ABI-009 at various stages in development.
About AADi
led by Dr. Neil Desai, an inventor of ABRAXANE® and the nab® technology platform.
AADi aims to develop the full potential of the albumin-bound mTOR inhibitor in diseases where the mTOR inhibitors have not or cannot be effectively exploited due to problems of effective drug delivery, safety or effective targeting to the disease site.

item.title: Combination of CK2 Inhibitor with Gemcitabine/Cisplatin to Enter Ph1/2 for Cholangiocarcinoma
item.description: Combination of CK2 Inhibitor with Gemcitabine/Cisplatin to Enter Ph1/2 for Cholangiocarcinoma
item.content:encoded:
Combination of CK2 Inhibitor with Gemcitabine/Cisplatin to Enter Ph1/2 for Cholangiocarcinoma
Endocrinology7688 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 20 May 2014 | 17:50

Comment: Senhwa Biosciences aims to develop innovative drugs through POC. This study considers the safety and tolerability of increasing doses of CX-4945 in combination with gemcitabine plus cisplatin to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD), followed by a randomized study that compares antitumor activity in cholangiocarcinoma patients receiving the standard of care gemcitabine plus cisplatin versus CX-4945 at the combination MTD with gemcitabine plus cisplatin. PE will evaluate MTD.
About the Trial
Recruitment approx. 100
  • Presence of an unresectable liver mass consistent with cholangiocarcinoma, for which treatment with gemcitabine plus cisplatin is intended.
  • For patients enrolled in the Dose Escalation Phase, one or more tumors measurable on radiograph or CT scan, or evaluable disease defined as non-measurable lesions per RECIST v. 1.1 (e.g., malignant ascites). All patients enrolled to the Randomized Study Phase must have measurable disease only.
  • Laboratory data as specified below:
    • Hematology: Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) >1,500 cells/mm3, platelet count >100,000 cells/ mm.cu. and hemoglobin > 9 g/dL
    • Hepatic: bilirubin <1.5 X Upper Limit of Normal (ULN); alkaline phosphatase (ALP), alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) < 5.0 X ULN
    • Renal: serum creatinine within normal limits (WNL), defined as within 25% of the institution's stated reference range, or a calculated creatinine clearance >45 mL/min/1.73 m. sq. for patients with abnormal, increased, creatinine levels.
    • Coagulation: International Normalized Ratio (INR) < 1.5 times normal, activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) < 1.5 times normal. Patients receiving therapeutic doses of anticoagulant therapy may be considered eligible for the trial if INR and aPTT are within the acceptable therapeutic limits for the institution.
  • Estimated life expectancy of at least 3 months.
  • Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) Performance Status 0 - 1.

Timelines

Start date May 2014 - Completion dates: June 2016 / Dec 2016

Locations USA
Source NCT02128282
About the Drug
CX-4945 has demonstrated favorable safety, pharmacokinetic characteristics and pharmacodynamic responses in Ph1. Clinical observations show that CX-4945 hits the CK2 target and modulates the expected pathways without displaying toxicity. The monitoring of circulating tumor cells demonstrates the ability of CX-4945 to kill cancer cells in patients with solid tumors. CX-4945 achieved clinical benefit as a single agent CK2 inhibitor, demonstrating stable disease and extended duration on treatment in a several patients.
About the Company
http://www.senhwabiosciences.com/company/

item.title: Dr Falk to Start Registration Trial of Phosphatidylcholine for UC [dis:IBD, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.description: Dr Falk to Start Registration Trial of Phosphatidylcholine for UC [dis:IBD, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
item.content:encoded:
Dr Falk to Start Registration Trial of Phosphatidylcholine for UC [:GastroEnterology:dis:IBD, :PharmaWorld:sub:ClinicalTrial]
GastroEnterology1974 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 20 May 2014 | 16:50

Comment: Two years ago the company acquired the EU rights of the drug from Lipid Therapeutics. LT-02 is a delayed release formulation of phosphatidylcholine designed to improve the barier function of the mucosal layer of the colon. PE will assess rate of clinical remission.
Trial Details
PI: Alex Dignass, MD
Title: PROTECT-1 Randomized, Double-blind, Double-dummy, Placebo-controlled, Phase III Clinical Trial on the Efficacy and Safety of a 12-weeks add-on Treatment With LT 02 vs. Placebo in Patients With Ulcerative Colitis Refractory to Standard Treatment With Mesalamine.
Recruitment approx 762
  • Established diagnosis of ulcerative colitis
  • Active ulcerative colitis disease extent ≥ 15 cm
  • Active disease despite treatment with mesalamine
Timelines
Start date June 2014 - Completion dates: Sept 2016 / December 2016
Location: Germany
Source NCT02142725
Synchronized Global Ph3 in US and EU
The Ph3 trials in the US and Europe will be conducted as part of a synchronized global pivotal plan.
Lipid Therapeutics intends to conduct the US portion of the program with a partner, in parallel with the trials to be conducted in Europe by Lipid Therapeutics’ European licensee for LT-02, Dr. Falk Pharma GmbH.
The combined clinical program will involve over 700 patients in each of two induction studies, with the objective of achieving remission based on the primary endpoint of reducing the patient’s Mayo Score. The two induction trials will be followed by a single global maintenance trial.
In the planned global Ph3 program LT-02 will be tested as add-on therapy to mesalazine. This is a significant area of high unmet medical need as approximately 40% of patients receiving the maximum dose of mesalazine, the standard 1st line therapy for ulcerative colitis, continue to experience flares of disease activity and therefore require additional treatment.
Source: Lipid Therapeutics

item.title: Immunomedics Reports Positive Data With Its Radiopharmaceutical In Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [class:MonoclonalAntibody, news]
item.description: Immunomedics Reports Positive Data With Its Radiopharmaceutical In Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [class:MonoclonalAntibody, news]
item.content:encoded:
Immunomedics Reports Positive Data With Its Radiopharmaceutical In Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer [:Oncology:class:MonoclonalAntibody, :Oncology:news]
Oncology9728 | Posted by Jacquelyne CANTLE MEYRICK | 20 May 2014 | 12:00

Comment: Immunomedics has reported an increased survival advantage with patients receiving multiple cycles of its radiopharmaceutical 90Y-clivatuzumab tetraxetan in an early stage trial in patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The data has been selected for presentation by the AACR for a special press conference on pancreatic cancer that will occur today.
Immunomedics has demonstrated that 90Y-clivatuzumab tetraxetan, when used with low-dose gemcitabine, is a safe, low-side effect therapy that can prolong survival for at least some patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer, even when no chemotherapy options exist.
Its studies imply that radiolabeled antibodies are safe to use in advanced pancreatic cancer, and that it may be possible to attach other anticancer agents besides 90Y to clivatuzumab tetraxetan to fight pancreatic cancer.
Key Study Findings

A total of 58 patients with pancreatic cancer who had received two or more prior therapies were enrolled in this multicenter study. Twenty-nine patients received the combination of 90Y-labeled-clivatuzumab tetraxetan once-a-week for 3 weeks and gemcitabine given weekly for 4 weeks (Arm A) while another group of 29 patients were administered 4 doses of 90Y-labeled-clivatuzumab tetraxetan alone (Arm B). This treatment cycle was repeated every 4 weeks until unacceptable toxicity, patient deterioration or patient withdrawal. Twenty-three patients completed more than one cycle of treatment, with 12 patients in Arm A and 11 in Arm B.
Notwithstanding the late-stage setting with a difficult-to-treat cancer patients the results were as follows:-
  • Arm A had a median overall survival (OS) of 7.9 months, which was statistically significant (p = 0.004)
  • Arm B had a median overall survival (OS) of 3.4 months in patients treated repeatedly with the radiolabeled antibody alone.
  • Additionally, 2 patients in Arm A had a partial response and 2 patients are still alive 13 and 15 months after the start of their combination treatment.

    The only clinically significant side effect was reduction in blood counts, especially platelets, which was transient and manageable.
As a result of this data Immunomedics has launched the Phase III PANCRIT-1 registration trial to confirm these results. Patient accrual is planned to be complete by the middle of 2015, with top-line results expected in the first half of 2016.
About PANCRIT-1
The PANCRIT-1 trial was designed to enroll approximately 440 patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer who had received at least two prior therapies. A majority of these patients will be recruited at clinical trial sites across the U.S., with additional sites in Canada, Europe and Israel participating. Eligible patients will be randomized 2 to 1 to the treatment arm of 3 doses of 90Y-clivatuzumab tetraxetan plus 4 doses of gemcitabine at 200 mg/m2 per cycle or placebo plus 200 mg/m2 gemcitabine. All patients will receive best supportive care. Treatments are administered during the initial 4 weeks of each 7-week cycle, and may be repeated up to a maximum of 6 cycles.
Source: www.immunomedics.com

Add a Comment on this Article
item.dc:creator: jac89886

item.title: Data Will Be Presented From ELM-PC4 And ARMOR2 Study In mCRPC Chemo Naive Setting During ASCO Chicago [comp:Takeda, prod:Orteronel, dis:Prostate, class:Hormonals, news]
item.description: Data Will Be Presented From ELM-PC4 And ARMOR2 Study In mCRPC Chemo Naive Setting During ASCO Chicago [comp:Takeda, prod:Orteronel, dis:Prostate, class:Hormonals, news]
item.content:encoded:
Data Will Be Presented From ELM-PC4 And ARMOR2 Study In mCRPC Chemo Naive Setting During ASCO Chicago [:Oncology:class:Hormonals, :Oncology:comp:Takeda, :Oncology:dis:Prostate, :Oncology:news, :Oncology:prod:Orteronel]
Oncology9724 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 19 May 2014 | 20:28

Comment: Abiraterone is the first agent received FDA approval in chemo naïve mCRPC setting, since then, Enzalutamide has also demonstrated significant survival benefit from PREVAIL trial. The positive data was presented in ASCO GU this year and European subpopulation analysis was presented as the 'late breaker' in EAU this year. The landscape of this setting could well be rattled further as more data will be presented in ASCO Chicago this month - featured by TAK-700 (ELM-PC4 trial) and Galeterone (ARMOR2).
Ahead of ASCO that will take place in Chicago end of this month, Takeda announced data from ELM -PC4 , a pivotal, international, double blind, randomized Phase 3 trial comparing TAK-700 (orteronel) with prednisone alone in mCRPC patients who have not received prior chemotherapy. TAK-700 (orteronel) plus prednisone reduced the risk of radiological progression free survival (rPFS) by 30% compared to placebo plus prednisone (median rPFS 11.0 vs. 8.3 months). Although there is a 'numerical improvement in median OS of 1.9 months, the improvement was not statistically significant (p=0.314).
Michael Vasconcelles MD, Global Head of Takeda Oncology Therapeutic Area Unit, commented during the press release " the significant rPFS advantage observed for orteronel combined with prednisone in the ELM-PC4 study is consistent with the previously reported rPFS improvement observed in ELM-PC5 study, where orteronel was also studies with prednisone in men with mCRPC who had previously received chemotherapy. We are carefully analysing these data to fully inform future decisions in the orteronel programme."
In the third interim analysis from COU-AA-302 study, abiraterone did not demonstrate significant survival benefit (p=0.0151) despite of significant rPFS improvement (median rPFS: 16.5 months vs. 8.2 months; p<0.00001). Although TAK-700 appears to be in the similar situation, the data may indicate that TAK-700 is inferior. Be cautious of this comment, as there is not a result of a direct comparison trial and this is merely an indirect comparison of different patients population. The rate of discontinuation is quite high in TAK-700 treatment arm (30% vs 18%). This may also highlight the possible toxicity issue. The future of TAK-700 (orteronel) is certainly a big question mark. The detail of the data will be presented at ASCO (ab # 5008, Oral Abstract Session, Sunday 1 June).
The other data will be presented during ASCO is updated Phase 2 clinical data on Tokai's Galeterone in advanced prostate cancer. The results of a phase 2 ARMOR2 Study will be presented on Saturday during poster highlights session (poster board 44). ARMOR2 study has a unique design where it includes 4 patient cohorts, Mo CRPC (non metastatic treatment naïve), M1 CRPC (treatment naïve), abiraterone refractory and enzalutamide refractory patients. This is only a phase 2 study so it has a very small patient cohort. PSA response of both M1 (n=24) and M0 (n=6) cohorts appear to be promising. It will be very interesting to hear about the details during ASCO.

item.title: TOLMAR Regains Sales & Marketing Rights to ELIGARD [prod:Eligard, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.description: TOLMAR Regains Sales & Marketing Rights to ELIGARD [prod:Eligard, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica]
item.content:encoded:
TOLMAR Regains Sales & Marketing Rights to ELIGARD [:Oncology:prod:Eligard, :PharmaWorld:mkt:NorthAmerica]
Oncology9718 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 19 May 2014 | 10:32

Comment: TOLMAR, the original developer of the drug, has regained the S&M rights for the drug in the U.S and Puerto Rico.
Company's Actions
TOLAMR is working to ensure both physicians and patients have a continuity of product supply, and unmatched support and patient care services.
The company has communicated directly with distributors and prescribing physicians regarding the availability of ELIGARD.
QLT Divestment of ELIGARD
During the first quarter of 2014, "Investment and Other Income" was $1.5 million compared to $0.8 million for the same period in 2013.
For both periods, this primarily related to gains of $1.5 million and $0.8 million, respectively, for the Fair Value Changes in Contingent Consideration. These fair value gains resulted from the revaluation of the Company's contingent consideration asset, which was recorded as the present value of future expected payments with respect to Eligard®. The $0.7 million increase in the Company's fair value gains is primarily due to a $17.0 million payment (the "Sanofi Prepayment") received from TOLMAR Holding, Inc. on March 17, 2014 in accordance with a consent and amendment agreement (the "Consent and Amendment Agreement") to the stock purchase agreement with Tolmar (the "2009 Stock Purchase Agreement"), under which QLT had formerly divested the Eligard product line to Tolmar.
Pursuant to the terms of the Consent and Amendment Agreement, in exchange for QLT's consent to certain transactions proposed by Tolmar that would affect its license agreement with Sanofi Synthelabo Inc. ("Sanofi License Agreement"), QLT received the Sanofi Prepayment as pre-payment and full satisfaction of the remaining contingent consideration owing with respect to royalties under the Sanofi License Agreement. Under the Consent and Amendment Agreement, Tolmar and its parent corporation, Dodley International Ltd., also guaranteed payment of the remaining $10.0 million of contingent consideration owing under the 2009 Stock Purchase Agreement on or before November 30, 2014.
Source: TOLMAR; QLT USA

item.title: Chinese Authorities Ramp Up Their Visits to Foreign Pharma Firms [mkt:China]
item.description: Chinese Authorities Ramp Up Their Visits to Foreign Pharma Firms [mkt:China]
item.content:encoded:
Chinese Authorities Ramp Up Their Visits to Foreign Pharma Firms [:PharmaWorld:mkt:China]
PharmaWorld10863 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 19 May 2014 | 10:00

Comment: According to an article published today by Reuters, the GSK Chinese case may be just the beginning. Drug-company executives, sales staff, lawyers and compliance experts say China's crackdown on drugmakers and other healthcare firms is intensifying as prosecutors grow bolder in the wake of the GSK case, threatening to stymie the growth of any firms caught in the crosshairs of the prolonged corruption crackdown.
Ongoing Investigations
Lawyers estimate that more than half of all drugmakers operating in China are being investigated in some capacity, from large multinational firms to Chinese state-owned enterprises.
Last year authorities visited Novartis AG , AstraZeneca Plc , Sanofi SA , Eli Lilly & Co and Bayer AG.
Source: Reuter

item.title: BMS Releases Results Of Phase1b Nivolumab (Anti-PD1) As A Single Agent (Study-003) [comp:BMS, news]
item.description: BMS Releases Results Of Phase1b Nivolumab (Anti-PD1) As A Single Agent (Study-003) [comp:BMS, news]
item.content:encoded:
BMS Releases Results Of Phase1b Nivolumab (Anti-PD1) As A Single Agent (Study-003) [:Oncology:comp:BMS, :Oncology:news]
Oncology9715 | Posted by Jenny Wu | 16 May 2014 | 18:11

Comment: Study-003 is a Phase 1b dose escalation study (n=306) to evaluate the safety, antitumour activity and pharmacokinetics of nivolumab as a single agent. Patients recruited include advanced melanoma (n=107), NSCLC (n=129), RCC (n=34), castration resistant prostate cancer (n=17) or colorectal cancer (n=19). The protocol was amended and survival was being included as endpoint.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier NCT00730639
Nivolumab is one of the most promising anti-PD1 agents and the results being released on 15th May (Thursday) were from the advanced melanoma cohort of this Phase 1b study.
  • Sustained activity in heavily treated patient population: 48% and 41% of this heavily pre-treated patient population hat received nivolumab as a single agent was alive at 2 and 3 years
  • No new tolerability issue was concluded with this longer follow up (treatment related adverse events were consistent with those previously reported in the publication)
Although only a small cohort of CRPC patients is included within the trial and given that negative results in mCRPC post-docetaxel setting, it will be interesting to watch the development of this trial and how BMS intends to take this forward.
On the same day, BMS also received FDA's breakthrough designation granted for nivolumab for the treatment of patients with Hodgkin lymphoma after failure of autologous stem cell transplant followed by brentuximab. The designation is based on data from a cohort of patients with Hodgkin lymphoma of current ongoing Phase 1b study of relapsed and refractory haematological malignancies.

item.title: Update on Zosano's Transdermal Microneedle Patch Delivery of Peptides [class:GrowthHormone]
item.description: Update on Zosano's Transdermal Microneedle Patch Delivery of Peptides [class:GrowthHormone]
item.content:encoded:
Update on Zosano's Transdermal Microneedle Patch Delivery of Peptides [:Endocrinology:class:GrowthHormone]
Endocrinology7678 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 May 2014 | 15:41

Comment: The company, spun out as a private company from ALZA/J&J in 2006, is advancing a pipeline of drug candidates based on the ZP Patch Technology, capable of delivering peptides, proteins, small molecules and vaccines. Preclinical results of transdermal microneedle patch delivery of rhGH will be presented @ENDO.
Presentation @ENDO (June 23)
Thanks to Mireille Bonnemaire from the Endocrinology Franchise who has forwarded the abstract below.
Pipeline
ZP-PTH Lead Product - Zosano is pursuing a 505(b)(2) regulatory strategy that leverages existing PTH safety and efficacy data of the marketed product Forteo®. Unlike Forteo® the ZP-PTH patch is needle-free patch that requires no refrigeration and demonstrated excellent safety and efficacy through Ph2.
Patents & Publications
http://www.zosanopharma.com/index.php/20091118147/Research/Patents-and-Publications/Patents-Publications.html
Business Development

Q1:14, Zosano entered into a license agreement with Novo Nordisk to deliver Semaglutide using Zosano’s Microneedle Patch System

Q3:11 Zosano and Asahi Kasei Pharma entered exclusive licensing agreement for a weekly Transdermal Patch Formulation of Teribone™ (teriparatide acetate) for osteoporosis
Source: Zosano Pharm

item.title: Takeda Not Interested in M&A [comp:Takeda, :DKPHybrids:comp:Acino, :DKPHybrids:news]
item.description: Takeda Not Interested in M&A [comp:Takeda, :DKPHybrids:comp:Acino, :DKPHybrids:news]
item.content:encoded:
Takeda Not Interested in M&A [:DKPHybrids:comp:Acino, :DKPHybrids:news, :Oncology:comp:Takeda]
Oncology9712 | Posted by Brigitte DESCHAMPS | 16 May 2014 | 14:39

Comment: Today, Takeda's CFO reported that the company has no interest in synergy or tax-driven M&A. However, "strategic acquisition" such as the Millennium acquisition remains still possible.
Strategic Acquisition Still Possible
The recent appointments of four ex-Takeda at the leadership positions of Acino have been questionning on whether an acquisition is likely to occur between the two companies.
DKPHybrids239: Two Ex-Takeda Appointed at Acino
DKPHybrids237: Second Ex-Takeda to Join Acino
Oncology9474: Ex-Takeda to Join Acino as New CEO
Qoting F-X Roger (CFO):
"If we go back to acquisitions we would focus again on strategic acquisitions and what they bring to us. Millennium brought us access to oncology, so I have access to a new franchise and a better footprint in the U.S."
" ... At the end of the day it's about being agile, being able to move fast, and being efficient in what you do."
